PETITION.TITLE: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the threats caused by logging to the integrity and continued existence of what remains of the forests of south eastern Australia.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his government
(1)to phase out woodchipping for export;
(2)not to renew a long-term export licence to Harris Daishowa;

(3)to ensure that sensitive environmental areas, and specifically the proposed national park and wilderness areas of Coolangubra, Cathcart, Egan Peaks and the Tantawangalo catchment, are protected and excluded from the proposed woodchip export licence; and

(4)to promote ecologically sound and sustainable forestry practices including: re-afforestation and plantation of native hardwoods on already cleared land to reduce pressure on native forests; and minimisation of wasteful uses of forest products.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ferguson (from 332 citizens), Mr Free (from 362 citizens), Mr Gorman (from 361 citizens), Mr Langmore (from 106 citizens), Mr Melham (from 412 citizens), Mr Peter Morris (from 291 citizens) and Mr West (from 363 citizens).

That the House take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee's first report on its inquiry into the prescription and supply of drugs was tabled in the House on 24 March this year. The second report of the inquiry was tabled on 8 October. I wish to direct my comments to the second report, titled Prescribed health: prescribing and medication management. In gathering evidence for this report, the Committee heard from witnesses in Adelaide, Alice Springs, Canberra, Melbourne, Newcastle and Sydney. A number of issues were addressed in the report. One of the more important, perhaps, was the undergraduate training of general practitioners. We found, in looking and in talking to hospital personnel and to practitioners in the community, that much of the prescribing habit of doctors was learnt in the actual hospital itself, in their years as an intern. The quality of their prescribing depended very much on what took place in those internship years.

PARA.TAB: Hospitals vary in the way they treat their interns. Some are thrown in and left to survive, while others—as happens at Flinders Medical Centre, the medical school near where I live, near my electorate—give their interns extensive training. We have recommended that it be a requirement for all medical courses that interns be given special training in interactive skills and communication with their patients. There should be special intern support programs, as there are at Flinders University.

I mentioned communication. This was taken in the report as a very special issue, because one of the big problems that we are finding in the community is a breakdown of communication between doctors and patients. This is not necessarily the fault of the doctor. The doctor gives what he believes are very clear instructions, but what happens is that the patient, for one reason or another, misunderstands those instructions. Frequently, it is because the patient is embarrassed to ask for clarification. We had one particularly horrific report of a patient being prescribed liniment for her arthritis. She understood it to be a medicine, ate it, and died. That is not a single report. There are others, perhaps less dramatic, out there in the community.

When we speak of communication, it is not just that doctors have to pick up their speaking skills and have the ability to inform their patients. Rather a whole course in communication is needed so that they can start to recognise the signs when the consumers themselves are not picking up on these types of things. Consumers have to take responsibility for learning what they have to do and it is part of the doctor's training to know that consumers have in fact taken that responsibility.

Consumers are a focus of the report. There is concern growing in the community that consumers are not given enough responsibility for their health and that doctors traditionally have not trusted consumers with all the information. A few doctors said to us that consumers do not want to know. I do not think this is the answer and in the report Committee members do not think it is the answer. We think it is important that consumers realise that they have responsibility for their own medication, to follow the prescription and to understand what is happening to them. There are many consumer groups out there who are acting with that in mind.

Another issue the Committee addressed was polypharmacy, which is a growing problem in the community. Particularly in the older community, consumers will take medicine from one doctor and then, for whatever reason, will go to another doctor for medicine which may contraindicate the first, but the second doctor does not know the patient is taking the first medication and the patient gets a reaction.

There also can be a build-up of drugs. Quite coincidentally, I got a fax from my office yesterday relating a rather horrific story of a gentleman who had died. His daughter went to his house to clean it out and gathered together two green garbage bags full of medication. She was absolutely horrified. She said there was also a drawer absolutely full of Medicare slips and prescription slips. We have not followed the story up and we do not know exactly how this one person could have had so many medications in his house, but certainly his daughter is very concerned and so are we. This is a point addressed in the report, and how to stop polypharmacy going on has to be looked at.

One of the ways is a computerised system, whereby every time somebody goes into a chemist's shop and takes a particular drug it is registered on the computer. This in itself has problems for privacy and I do not know how that issue can be resolved. When I went recently to a chemist's shop which I had not visited for a year and then only once, I found he could press a button and tell me what I had got in a prescription exactly one year ago. Frankly, I felt my privacy had been violated. Yet that same system could have prevented somebody who was older taking a drug that was contraindicated by a drug she was already taking. These are some of the issues that we address in the report and some of the issues that society has to address with regard to what is happening in this area.

The Committee has also recommended that education about drugs be started at a very early age when children are at school so that they understand what is happening when they do take drugs and when they abuse them. We also suggest—I think a little hopefully—that non-drug remedies be looked at, including a change in diet and exercise rather than sleeping pills and other types of medication. Perhaps that has been a little hopeful or optimistic on the Committee's part. However, certainly there is room for doctors to look at alternative therapies, but we have to acknowledge that the time doctors are given to see patients is limited.

I recommend this report to the House. In doing so, I wish to congratulate members of the secretariat, particularly Bjarne Nordin, on the work done on this report, on the one preceding it and on the one that will follow it. I make the comment, as I always do at this stage, that I do not think the secretariats get enough acknowledgment for the amount of work that they put into producing these reports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker Mr F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Standing Committee on Community Affairs presents the second volume in the Prescribed health trilogy entitled Prescribing and medication management, I am pleased to add my support to the words of the Chairman, the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), and Deputy Chairperson, the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus).

PARA.TAB: This report was prepared in a context of considerable activity by other government bodies on the subject. Jenny Macklin, in preparing the Government's national health strategy, released two papers on the future of general practice and pharmaceutical drug use, which tended to cover the field of this report. The Trade Practices Commission produced a draft on self-regulation of the advertising and promotion of therapeutic goods. It then finalised that report and dealt with issues such as rational prescribing practice and promotional activities that distort such practice. Most importantly, the Pharmaceutical Health and Rational Use of Medicines Working Party, which is called PHARM, published a draft policy relating to education and strategies to encourage the better use of medicines. The Committee took these three valuable works under close consideration in finalising its wider report on the functions and responsibility of prescribers and consumers in the drug distribution chain.

For those who would imagine that all is rosy in the world of drug prescribing, expert testimony before the Committee indicated that some 1,400 Australians die each year from the misuse of prescription drugs and some 40,000 are hospitalised. The report estimates that the cost to the Australian taxpayers could be as high as $69m annually. I notice that Dr Shepherd wanted to challenge those statistics, which are drawn from learned studies published in the National Health Strategy Issues Paper No. 4. However, the Australian public has learned to treat Dr Shepherd's utterances with a great deal of caution. What he will not admit, and what some members of his own profession admit, is that considerable responsibility for these tragic statistics lies in bad prescribing practices by Australian doctors, whose initial training and continuing education leaves much to be desired.

However, the evidence would seem to suggest that the largest problem lies in the field of communication between doctors and patients. In the matter of the education of doctors, the report makes a series of recommendations to take measures that I am sure the general public assumed were happening anyway. Principally, that consists of codifying a core curriculum in clinical pharmacology to be taught in all medical schools. Some schools of medicine provide little education in prescribing, and clinical pharmacology is a low priority subject in most universities.

It is hard to imagine that highly educated members of our community, such as doctors, may be lacking in communication skills, but there was overwhelming evidence before the Committee that that was the case. As the Consumers Health Forum pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: It is no good treating someone if the person does not understand what the treatment is about.

For those who still find this problem hard to believe, anecdotal evidence was put before the Committee detailing cases—and they were referred to by the honourable member for Hawker—such as where a pensioner who had been prescribed a liniment for arthritis, ate it and died. Suppositories were taken orally, and massive confusion reigned in patients' minds over the timing and quantities of prescribed medications, frequently leading to serious illness and death. That is why the Committee has recommended that the interactive skills of medical undergraduates be honed and that communication units be incorporated in their studies. The Committee also recommended that these students be given work experience with general practitioners. The evidence pointed to the likelihood that prescribing habits acquired during internship had a great deal of influence on the prescribing patterns of GPs.

PARA.TAB: As with all disciplines, medicine is besieged by rapidly changing technology, with new drugs and treatments appearing daily. Continuing medical education is naturally vital if the GP is to cope. The quality and the content of that education are very important. These days, most continuing education emanates from drug companies, which lack the objectivity that is absolutely essential in matters involving life and death. That is why a range of recommendations, including support for independent academic detailers, is included in the report.

Improvement in the drug database was another area that the Committee felt that the Government should give higher priority to. Of necessity, that involves the cooperation of the States, which is always difficult in our federal system, plagued as it is by childish State rights disputes. One of the most important aspects of this issue was the need for public hospitals to strengthen the adverse drug reporting processes as well as encouraging professional and consumer associations to find better ways to facilitate reporting.

The Committee believes a computerised national drug information service is the way to go. The Committee, cognisant of the development of a national health strategy, also made a series of recommendations relating to the strategic application of Federal funds to improve Australians' health so far as prescribed drug usage was concerned. The work of the PHARM working party was seen as vital, particularly in developing a national centre for the quality use of medicines. The Committee thought that the centre would be best located in Academe and that it should be primarily government funded to give it the objectivity essential to the development of acceptable policies.

The Committee also urged the Government to rationalise the current cumbersome general practice consultative process. Consumers, of course, were not forgotten in the report. Indeed, the report is characterised by its consumer orientation. The Committee accepted the fact that quality drug use could be achieved only by a team approach to health care in which the health professionals and their patients had a mutually informed interdependent relationship which, of necessity, should also involve interaction between the various health professionals involved.

The Committee's first concern was with the consumers' right to be fully informed about the drugs that they were taking. That, of course, is not a one way process. Educated consumers can play a very important role in providing the professional with information which will ensure the highest quality of drug use. Consumer education programs are essential and government funding of such programs is vital.

An issue that cropped up frequently in this context was polypharmacy; that is, adverse reactions from multiple medications. This is especially important in the case of elderly patients, who tend to suffer multiple medical problems. One obvious solution is to find alternatives to drug treatments for some of the patient's maladies. For example, problems such as insomnia, constipation and mild hypertension can often be simply treated not by drugs but by changes in diet and regular exercise.

A related concern in this area is the inadequacy of medication record management. Patients frequently have a number of medical advisers who often have difficulty keeping track of their colleagues' prescriptions. Unfortunately, the real civil liberties issues raised by the computerisation of a patient's medical records have left this problem unresolved. However, the Committee remains optimistic that telecommunications networks and smart cards can be devised that will overcome the proper Big Brother fears of the community.

Finally, I wish to say something about the role of nurses in ensuring quality drug usage. Nurses play a vital role in monitoring drug treatment and ensuring patient compliance. In particular, nurses in remote rural areas play a truly heroic part in delivering health care where neither doctors nor pharmacists are available to dispense drugs. That is why the Committee recommended extension of a nurse's licence to dispense drugs such as antibiotics.

I was concerned to read the response of Malcolm Roberts on behalf of the hospital pharmacists opposing this particular recommendation. No group that came before the Committee impressed me as much as the hospital pharmacists, but they simply do not understand the problems of remote Australia. The highest professional standards are easy to impose in our public hospitals but, if one is a nurse treating a serious infection suffered by a tribal Aborigine in the Kimberleys without the benefit of a doctor or a pharmacist, then the distinction between prescribing and dispensing is meaningless. I was honoured to serve on that Committee and to work with the secretarial service that supports that Committee. I give my support to this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for the opportunity to address this report, the second volume of Prescribed health entitled Prescribing and medication management. It is a pleasure to stand in this House without the hurly-burly of Question Time. We have just heard the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Walker) give an outline sketch of the work of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs in this report.

PARA.TAB: The work of parliamentarians in these areas of health is very important to the Australian community. These issues will be addressed not only by the current Keating Government but also by the incoming Hewson Government. The issue of prescribed drugs, at great cost to the Australian community as a whole through government services, has to be addressed over a long period by the committees of the Parliament.

There are many people in the community who have no idea of the work done in the background by parliamentarians. It may not involve the big issues such as unemployment or the political issues that are raised at Question Time or those issues that hit the front pages of our newspapers each day, such as the comments of our leaders, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). Committees deal with other issues that occur in the Federal Parliament on a daily basis. These issues are then analysed for the benefit of the Australian people.

Although 14 members of parliament have been members of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, I want to mention a few who have extended themselves to make sure that they have been on top of the issues. They have had a major input into the report as individuals on behalf of the Parliament, as distinct from the Executive, or as politicians from a political party.

In a committee a group comes together on behalf of the Australian community and works to make the processes of government better for the Australian community and therefore for their constituents. The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) chairs the Committee and has been diligent in his approach to this inquiry, as he was in the previous inquiry into prescription drugs. The honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus) is the Deputy Chairperson of this Committee and has been involved in the extensive work that we did as a parliamentary committee working for the benefit of others.

I am a Committee member and I have an interest in health, especially in the area of disability. The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) is a member. He is currently ill and so we wish him all the best. He is actually receiving some of the prescription drugs into which we inquired. The honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) is a member. As a result of her background she has had a major input into this report and she should be congratulated. The honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) is also a member. Not only has she worked diligently within the Committee but she has always added a spark of humour and enthusiasm. The honourable member for Robertson (Mr Walker), given his experience as a Minister in the Wran Government, was often outstanding in his questioning of witnesses as we went through the public hearing stages.

It is important to say that the Parliament as a whole works outside the Executive arm of government. The honourable member for Robertson outlined the terms of reference, the report and the roles of the individuals who worked within our health system. I would like to support his remarks on nurses in Australia. They deliver health services where the pressure points are. This report identified where the pressure points are in our health system.

We are doing some very good things within our health system in Australia. As the parliamentary inquiry progressed, we were able to see how we are moving forward to make sure that prescription drugs were delivered to people who have psychological disabilities or physical disabilities. We have new processes such as new packaging of prescription drugs to make sure that in every household across Australia where prescription drugs are used they are used in the most effective way.

There is a practical reason for our inquiring into these particular issues and it is as simple as this: 20 per cent of people who were admitted to our hospitals in Australia were there as a result of the inappropriate use of prescription drugs. The cost to the Australian community as a result of that is enormous and any work that we can do in this Parliament that can reduce the cost of the Australian health system, the cost of hospitals and the cost to individuals is very important. Reports such as this can benefit the health system in Australia.

As I said, what a nurse does in Central Australia will not be on the front page of the Australian tomorrow morning. Even after this report is released today, the newspaper will not feature it. It will still feature the million people unemployed or what we have done with 40-odd boat people who have come in across our northern borders and how we will lock them up for a couple of years before we send them back. They are the sorts of issues that will be on the front page of the Australian. It will not feature the issues that are addressed in this report.

As a nation, we need to further consider the issues in the health system. The committees of this Parliament should continue to address these needs. There are parts of the health system that need to be addressed on a daily basis. As a committee, we do have some choice as to which part of the reference from the Minister we put the most emphasis on. However, when the cost to the Australian community is taken into consideration, it is clear that as a parliament we must address these issues in a bipartisan way.

I congratulate the Secretary of the Committee, Mr Nordin, and his assistants, Mr Catchpole and Mrs Hunter, for the work they have put into the Committee. I congratulate the Chairman, not only for the diligence I mentioned before but also for giving me the opportunity to serve on this Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to rise to support this report which my colleagues the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus), the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Broadbent) and the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Walker) have already spoken on this morning. I would also like to convey my thanks to the Committee secretariat and to the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), who chaired this Committee so ably and who will continue to chair it for the duration of our report activities. As has already been mentioned, we do have another report to bring down on this inquiry into the prescription and supply of drugs. We have already tabled one report. The one which was tabled recently by the Chairman is the second in the trilogy.

PARA.TAB: The focus of this report is the professional practice which influences the prescribing of pharmaceuticals and the range and quality of information and education on appropriate drug use, as opposed to commercial promotion and marketing. This is an area that the Committee has given very serious consideration to, as it has a very widespread impact on the costs of health in Australia in monetary and personal terms.

As mentioned by the honourable member for Hawker, the question of doctor communication skills was one which was raised in the Committee's deliberations. The report has attempted to address that question. The other matter that was of considerable concern was the question of consumer education on drugs and whether or not people understand properly the drugs that they are taking and the reasons that their doctors have prescribed the drugs.

Polypharmacy was also mentioned by the honourable member for Hawker as being a continuing problem in the Australian community. People are attending more than one doctor and making it very difficult for any medical person to understand the full situation as regards their health. This is a matter which may be addressed, in part, by changes that the Government has introduced to general practice. There will be more encouragement in the near future for GPs, for instance, to have a steadier clientele and for people to try to reduce the number of doctors that they actually visit.

Consumer education and GP education will also assist in this area. For instance, there is no point in patients going to more than one doctor if they know that a doctor has an understanding of their health needs, and that going to one doctor would actually ensure that they were not taking incorrect drugs or drugs that were not going to assist their condition because they might counteract drugs that they were taking for some other condition. In this regard I draw the House's attention to the situation confronting asthmatics in our society. This is very topical, given that the National Asthma Foundation had a meeting in Canberra this week at the old Parliament House—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you go?

—I was not able to get there because of duties in the House. Nevertheless, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) was there to represent the Government and to make sure that the National Asthma Foundation was fully aware that the Government treats this matter as a very serious problem. This Committee has in its report made mention of this type of problem in the Australian community. The reason why I raise the question of asthma is that it costs Australian society an incredible amount of money but, until this point in time, nobody has identified what that cost might be.

PARA.TAB: We all know that more Australians and New Zealanders suffer asthma than people in any other nation in the world. We do not always know why that is but we certainly know there is a cost involved. The National Asthma Foundation has now identified that cost for the first time in its report Cost of asthma in Australia, and I would like to draw to the House's attention the fact that the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The total 1991 cost burden of asthma to the Australian community is estimated to be in the range of $585m to $720m.

With such a widespread disease—and it is a life threatening disease; there should be no mistake about that—it is absolutely crucial that doctors understand the problem and properly prescribe drugs for people and that consumers of those drugs, the asthmatics themselves, are aware of what their drugs do and why they need to take a complete range of drugs. Hospitalisation of asthmatics frequently occurs because they are taking incorrect medication or incorrectly taking the medication that is prescribed for them.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, I endorse, with all the other recommendations in this report, those recommendations relating particularly to doctor communication, so that the doctor is able to communicate the need for the patient to take those drugs; doctor education on pharmaceuticals, so that the doctors are absolutely up to date with what is the correct medication for a problem such as asthma; and consumer education and consumer awareness, so that the consumer of the drug, the patient, is able to understand what the drugs are, why they take them and what they ought to do if the drugs cease to work.

The national asthma campaign has a very strong emphasis in this particular area and is encouraging people who have asthma to have a card which they take to their GP and the GP will assist them in measuring their capacity to draw oxygen into their lungs and ensure that they actually do receive the correct treatment. As members of this House would know, the treatment of asthma can be preventive as well as spasmodic, and there are two or three different types of treatment which should be administered for all asthmatics at various times.

I think that Bjarne Nordin, the Secretary of the Committee, has done a marvellous job and I express my pleasure, and indeed my honour, to be a member of this Committee with such eminent colleagues as those who have already spoken on the debate. I endorse the report's recommendations, refer them to the Government and hope that the Government treats them with the seriousness that they require and also gives them as speedy approval as it gave the recommendations of the initial report when it came into this House. I recommend the report, I thank my Committee colleagues and I thank the House for having borne with me.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—Order! The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.TITLE: FEDERAL INDUSTRIAL AWARDS: PENALTIES FOR BREACHES

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Mr Les Scott:

That the Government review the penalties for breaches in federal industrial awards by employers with a view to substantial increases in these penalties to ensure employers comply with award conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to speak on this particular motion. It is fair to say that Australian workers now, more than ever, need the protection of the award system. This motion calls on the Government to review the penalties for breaches in Federal industrial awards by employers, with a view to substantial increases in these penalties to ensure employers comply with award conditions. I support this motion wholeheartedly.

PARA.TAB: Since my colleagues the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) and the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) spoke passionately on this motion in May, Australian workers have come face to face with the reality of the Opposition's industrial relations policies. They have come face to face with the policies of a party that not only does not give a damn about breaches of awards, but actually encourages employers and employees alike to breach such awards, a party that would like to abolish awards altogether.

Australians, as we know, have been watching very closely the drama being played out currently in Victoria. Over 150,000 people—men and women, young and old—marched in the streets of Melbourne on Tuesday to protest against the industrial vandalism of the Kennett Liberal Government. In May who would have believed that Mr Kennett would put on such a fine performance? Who would have believed that, in the same week as he arbitrarily robbed workers under Victorian awards of their holiday leave loading, his Minister responsible for industrial relations, Mr Gude, would give himself an $8,000 pay rise in a clandestine late sitting?

We have said often enough in this House that those on the other side are out of touch with the electorate, that they are out of touch with reality. But I must confess that I never, in my wildest dreams, imagined a scenario of such bloody-minded, arrogant stupidity and contempt for the electorate as that displayed by Mr Kennett and his Cabinet in Victoria. No wonder Victorian workers were out there in the rain and hail in their thousands marching in protest.

The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) have applauded the Liberals' actions in Victoria—a little cautiously at first, but now they have shown their true colours and are backing Mr Kennett all the way to the silver service in the parliamentary dining room. Do honourable members believe that the suffering of Victorians is going to be relieved by the introduction of silver service in the parliamentary dining room?

It is a slap in the face to Victorians and a slap in the face to all Australians. While the Liberals rob workers of hard fought for award conditions with one hand, they give themselves a pay rise and silver service with the other—and they expect the electorate to trust them. They expect the electorate to believe that workers will get a fair deal without protection of awards.

I applaud this motion. The Faustian drama being played out in Victoria highlights the need for severe penalties to be introduced for breaches of Federal awards. The need for tougher penalties for award breaches is especially necessary in the Australian shearing industry. In that great industry, workers have had to rely on the enforcement of awards as protection against a deliberate campaign by groups such as the NFF and the UGA being prodded along by the extremists in the Liberal and National parties to lower their wages and break down their working conditions.

These groups have been actively encouraging the employment of visitors to Australia in the shearing industry. This has made it increasingly difficult for Australian shearers to find work in that particular industry. At a time of high unemployment, this has led to conflict in many rural communities between Australian shearers and non-Australian shearers. Honourable members on the other side of the House, of course, love a bit of conflict—look at APPM and Robe River. And, of course, we know the honourable member for Bennelong loves it.I have been contacted by shearers in the Longreach, Barcaldine and Blackall areas of my electorate, who have alleged that New Zealand shearers are regularly breaching award conditions. Australian shearers in my electorate do not want conflict; they just want everyone to stick to the rules.

I have nothing against New Zealanders or New Zealand shearers, but I do have a problem with the fact that the industrial relations system that applies in New Zealand is causing Australians to be put out of work, especially Australians in the shearing industry. The statistics back up the perception that it is New Zealand shearers who are posing a threat to Australians in that industry. In 1990 there were 288,900 New Zealand born persons living in Australia, representing 1.7 per cent of the Australian population. I understand that almost 50 per cent of these New Zealanders are shearers. The AWU estimates that 42 per cent of the Australian wool clip is now being shorn by New Zealanders.

I believe there are a number of factors that, added together, have attracted New Zealand workers to Australia in droves. These factors include: the draconian industrial relations policies of the Bolger Government in New Zealand; the favourable taxation position of New Zealand workers in Australia; and the favourable foreign exchange rate for New Zealanders. These factors are working together to put Australian shearers out of work and to break down hard fought for Australian awards and conditions. In view of this, we should renegotiate the closer economic relations agreement between the two nations, and our current open door employment and social security arrangements with New Zealand.

According to the 1986 census, there were about 211,600 New Zealanders living in Australia, making up 1.37 per cent of the population. The number of New Zealanders in the Australian work force as at May 1992 was 184,100, or 2.1 per cent of the work force. The total New Zealand full time labour force, according to the 1986 census, is about 1.2 million, including a component of 17,000-odd Australians. In other words, Australians make up about 1.4 per cent of the New Zealand labour force.

It is obvious from these statistics that more New Zealanders prefer to work in Australia than vice versa. A report on temporary movements of people to Australia, released yesterday, shows that 400,000 New Zealanders came here on a temporary visa in 1991. I think this is understandable, in light of draconian industrial relations and social policies of the Bolger Government. Unions have been decimated and the minimum wage is barely higher than unemployment benefits available in Australia. The fact that only 17,000 Australians have chosen to work in New Zealand shows that New Zealand's deregulated market is not the huge drawcard that the coalition claims it to be. Clearly, New Zealand workers are better off working in Australia where they have the protection of negotiated awards and strong unions.

The threat to the hard fought for award conditions in the shearing industry, posed by the influx of New Zealand shearers, is serious and should concern all workers. As I said earlier, I believe there has been a deliberate attempt by some peak rural bodies to undermine award conditions in the shearing industry. The bona fides of the Troubleshooters group should be investigated. This organisation appears to have embarked upon a deliberate attempt to undermine the AWU and all the hard fought for gains of the Australian union movement. Part of this campaign, I believe, involves the deliberate recruitment of New Zealand shearers. New Zealand shearers generally do not pay tax here and they have the benefit of a favourable foreign exchange rate. This means that some can afford to breach Australian awards by working for less pay or out of hours. Once the award is breached by foreign shearers it puts pressure on Australian shearers to do the same in order to maintain employment.

As honourable members know, New Zealanders currently have open access to the Australian job market and social security benefits. Whilst I appreciate the spirit in which the CER agreement was entered into, I believe that the political situation in New Zealand has changed, to the extent that the Government should reconsider its open door policy. A form of work permits should be introduced so that when there is an Australian worker who can do the job, it should not go to a New Zealander.

It has been estimated by the Bureau of Industry Economics that, per capita, New Zealanders benefit from CER around eight times more than do Australians. As a nation, we cannot afford to continue to carry economic refugees from New Zealand in our work force and thereby displace local workers. Whilst the impact of current policies is being felt markedly in the shearing industry, I believe it applies to other industries as well. Displaced Australian shearers are having to move to other areas which puts pressure on the workers in those particular areas. A system of work permits for New Zealanders should apply across the board. We must protect the award system against the tyranny proposed by those opposite. We must increase the financial penalties for award breaches and we must learn from the tragedy being played out in Victoria and New Zealand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to totally refute the allegation of the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls) about the breaking of award conditions in the shearing industry. He well knows that investigations undertaken in Queensland indicated that the award conditions were being obeyed. It is a total furphy to suggest that the New Zealanders were breaking award conditions. The AWU and people such as the honourable member for Kennedy have gone to great efforts to try to run that line. When it has been investigated, it has been found that award conditions have been adhered to, and that the shearing industry is working quite well.

PARA.TAB: I challenge the honourable member for Kennedy to make a discrimination between a New Zealand shearer and an Australian shearer. On what grounds would he give the job to an Australian shearer as compared to a New Zealand shearer? Since he is a member of a government which is advocating no discrimination—both between females and males, and between New Zealanders and Australians—I challenge him to make that distinction.

This whole debate really goes back to the arguments in May about the shearing industry and about award conditions. It is quite outrageous that Government members are putting forward this motion that there be a substantial increase in penalties, to ensure that employers comply with award conditions. There is no mention, of course, of the rights and responsibilities of the workers, and of what will be the penalties to the workers, if they do not obey the award conditions and do not help in the workplace. It is really just a policeman attitude: the employers will do exactly what the trade union movement wants them to do, and they will be forced to do so by penalties. This is very much against the current approach of the coalition's industrial relations policy, which is one of cooperation, increasing productivity, and making a more flexible workplace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what they said to you in the car park at Flemington about the wage increase. Tell us what the hoi polloi said to you about the workers.

—That is all right. We are talking about exactly what the coalition's industrial relations arrangements are. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand), who is at the table, well knows what our position is, and he would understand quite clearly. He basically agrees with changing the arrangements in the industrial scene in Australia to a more flexible approach. The enterprise agreements have been negotiated, as identified in the Budget Papers. The Minister understands that. The Minister has been in this sort of industrial arrangement, and he understands that we want a more flexible arrangement and more productivity.

PARA.TAB: Under the policy of the shadow Minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), we will have minimum standards and we will have a more flexible approach. We are all for cooperation, and not for confrontation and the increase in the penalties that have been suggested in the motion. Our position is clear, up-front, and well annunciated by the shadow Minister for industrial relations.

I have had an interest in these matters since 1985, and there has been a change in attitude. Even the Government is moving in the direction of a more flexible approach in the workplace, and away from an award conditions position, by making sure that companies and their workers, at the enterprise level, work out their own arrangements.

Mr Ian Spicer, who has a good understanding of these matters, issued a press release on behalf of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry on 2 November 1992. His press release headed `Bringing Industrial Relations to the Workplace' in support of the shadow Minister's position in relation to the coalition's industrial relations policy stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Ian Spicer, Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, commenting on the issues raised in the Industrial Review, said:

PARA.TAB: "The industrial relations policy released by the Coalition points in the direction in which this country must move.

"The Coalition's policy aims to move the industrial relations system towards greater freedom and flexibility. This directional shift is an absolute essential if the Australian economy is to respond to the changing economic environment business finds itself continuously dealing with.

"If workplace change is to be regularly frustrated by unions and tribunals, who by the nature of things have only a remote understanding of the needs of the individual workplace, then change will always be behind times.

SPEECH.PARA: This is exactly what the honourable member for Kennedy is trying to frustrate. Mr Spicer continues:

PARA.TAB: "The Coalition's policy takes industrial relations closer to the work place. It is in that direction that the industrial relations systems must move.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear where the coalition stands, and we stand by that. Let me go back to some of the details of the motion we are debating.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will run you out of Belmont when you go home.

—I will deal with the Minister at a later time, after the debate, because he does not understand. He has been out of the industry for a long while, down there in Warrnambool. Just let him stick to immigration.
—You have never been in industry, you are a blueblood.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, would you restrain the Minister, please.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—Order! The Minister should not interject.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1990-91 annual report of the Department of Industrial Relations, which was tabled in 1991-92, had as the first objective of the Department:

SPEECH.PARA: promoting and assisting the achievement of a competitive, efficient, and flexible labour market.
Note these key words. I do not see the words `additional regulation' or `award compliance' in the report, which is exactly what the honourable member for Kennedy is suggesting. It also mentions:
promoting fair wages and conditions for all workers while assisting Australia's economic and industrial performance.

In June 1991 the Department found compliance with award based superannuation was at a high level, around 80 per cent, and it has further increased. It is exactly as I have been saying. This was found by the market research carried out for the Department of Social Security earlier in that year by Brian Sweeney and Associates, of which I obtained a copy in an answer to a question on notice. The Department's award management section dealt with almost 200,000 requests for information on awards in 1990-91. The award officers—some would call them inspectors—visited more than 12,000 employer establishments, where 3,300 complaints about awards were raised. We can see from the information from the Department itself that awards were being looked at and were being complied with.

PARA.TAB: I totally reject the suggestion that we need an increase in penalties just to ensure that the bosses pull into gear. Despite the best efforts of the ACTU to confuse matters, employees and employers are really in a contractual situation when they are at work. The duties of an employee are relatively straightforward. They generally have to work as directed, although in many industries so far the employees have unfettered rights because of union directives. Employees have to be courteous, they have to be punctual and they have to work to the best of their ability. In the more enlightened work situations they are encouraged to think of ways of improving work productivity.

The obligations of employers are much more onerous. The employers have to meet minimum sick leave and annual leave requirements. Holiday loading, of course, has been changed, as the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs would know. He does not mind giving up his 17 1/2 per cent, I am sure, because he knows that a 17 1/2 per cent loading to go on holiday is an outrage here in Australia. No other country in the world would agree with that. No other person in the world wants to get 17 1/2 per cent to be on holiday, and the Minister would understand that.

Management has to provide the training guarantee levy, the superannuation guarantee levy, maternity leave and paternity leave, and RDOs are incorporated in all those arrangements. Not only have they got to do that, they have to obey health and safety regulations which quite often are introduced as a result of all kinds of union pressures. Especially in the building industry, those regulations are used for industrial purposes. The Minister would fully understand that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an outrageous claim.
—Order! The Minister should not interject. The Minister will resume his seat.

—The Minister would fully understand that, if only he would go onto the building sites in Melbourne. He would know full well that the aspects of the health and safety regulations are used for industrial purposes. Those on this side agree that sensible health and safety regulations are acceptable, but they are not to be used for industrial purposes. Employers have all these responsibilities. Responsible employers look after their work force because they know that in the long run productivity will be improved.

PARA.TAB: The coalition is in favour of a more cooperative arrangement. It is very clearly stated, and that is our position. We are not for confrontation, and we do not agree with increases of penalties for award conditions which impact employers who in most cases are genuinely trying to look after their work force. The Government's record is one million unemployed. The Government has not created jobs here in Australia. It has done nothing for the workers of Australia. All it has done is create the recession we had to have. It has done nothing for those people it purports to represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution to this debate by the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) is one of the most extraordinary I have ever heard. Apart from his claims being completely off the planet, he is utterly factually wrong. It reminds me of the contribution made on the 7.30 Report, I think on Tuesday night, by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). It is probably the most agitated and upset that I have seen the honourable member since prior to the 1987 Federal election when he saw victory slip away. He saw the mad Joh for PM campaign and he believed that was the reason the coalition did not win the 1987 Federal election.

PARA.TAB: Replacing the mad Joh for PM campaign now is the mad Jeff Kennett of Victoria industrial relations campaign, and we see the same thing again: the victory that the coalition thought it could not possibly lose this time is slipping away. Victory is slipping away; the coalition knows it and is getting more and more agitated. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) is not looking forward to another three years on the Opposition benches if he happens to struggle on and hold his seat. In that performance on the 7.30 Report the honourable member for Bennelong was the most agitated I have seen him for a long time, because he could not justify the behaviour of the Premier of Victoria, Mr Kennett.

When Mr Kennett first came out with his industrial relations policy, we saw the honourable member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) try to get away at a million miles an hour. They firstly came up and said, `It is a bit unfortunate that Jeff's gone down this path when he did not really have a mandate'. It had simply slipped his mind to mention to the people of Victoria, `I am going to reduce your wages. I am going to remove penalty rates and I am going to take away holiday leave loading. It is only a minor thing that I am going to cut your wages. I decided not to mention it'. Of course, the first thing the honourable member for Bennelong and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition did—and the Opposition generally—was to walk away from that at a million miles an hour. But once the fight was called on about it—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order.
—This is outrageous. What is the point of order?

—The honourable member for Kennedy is saying my point of order is outrageous and he has not heard it yet. My point of order is that this debate is about a motion moved by the honourable member for Oxley relating to the introduction of new penalties for breaches of Federal industrial awards. It is not a debate about the 7.30 Report of two nights ago or other vicarious matters that are being raised by the current speaker. I would like him to get back to the topic because I would be interested to hear what he has to say since his people are opposed to tougher penalties in Victoria.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Of course, now the Liberal Opposition in this Parliament is 100 per cent behind the Victorian Government. I am not surprised. Let us get this issue down to its simplest form: what is the industrial relations policy of the Opposition about? Let us not go on with this nonsense about wanting flexible working arrangements or co-operative situations between employees and employers. It is all about reducing wages; it is about this perception that the members of the Opposition have that people are paid too much and it is necessary for the Australian economy for wages to be reduced.

PARA.TAB: That is why they are saying that leave loading is unnecessary and an outrage. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), said that Australia was the only country in the world where people were paid more to go on holidays. That is actually factually wrong. Something like one-third of the countries in the OECD have holiday leave loadings, bonuses or other payments for employees on leave.

What does it all boil down to? Holiday leave loading over the course of a year is about 1.3 per cent of an average person's wage. Members of the Opposition are saying that they want to take 1.3 per cent off an average person's wage: that is what it is all about. Let us decode this, let us cut through all the rubbish and the rhetoric. They are saying, `I want to reduce your wage by about 1.3 per cent'; it is as simple as that.

Next they say that penalty rates are outrageous, and they ask why people should get paid more for working from midnight through to the early hours of the morning. They want to take that away because, in their view, it is an absolute outrage that people should get paid more for being away from their family and working hours like that. That is fine, of course, for a shift worker or a nurse or an occupation like that, where a large part of the income comes through the application of penalty rates. They are telling those workers that they want to reduce their wages and that that is going to be good for them and for Australia.

What is the point? They say that the purpose of their industrial relations approach is to produce for Australia a more productive environment, to get higher levels of productivity, because productivity growth is far too low under the current system. They point to this in the Fightback! document and make the point that, during the 1980s, the annual average productivity growth was something like 0.9 per cent. They say that this was a very poor result and that Australia should be able to achieve much better. Then they go on to do their modelling in Fightback and to tell us what effect it will have on productivity.

They give three scenarios in the document: the high road, the middle road and the low road. Let us be generous to members of the opposition and assume that they achieve the best results in their modelling in Fightback and that they get the high road scenario; that is, what they think they can achieve if everything works in well—the industrial relations policy works well, their GST and the food and clothes tax works well. What is going to be the outcome of the high road scenario? Their projection of productivity growth is 0.8 per cent annual growth. That is less than what they proclaimed to be the low rate during the 1980s. That is amazing. We are going to go through all this pain; we are going to reduce people's wages; we are going to have industrial confrontation; we are going to destroy the industrial system of this country, and our outcome, our shining achievement, is going to be a productivity outcome, at its best, with the high road scenario lower than what was achieved by Labor during the 1980s. What a marvellous outcome for people!

Turning to the rest of what they are on about, what is so wrong with the industrial situation at the moment? What is wrong with having industrial disputes at their lowest level in 30 years? I would have thought that was a pretty good result. What is wrong with having inflation at its lowest level in 20 years? I would have thought that that was a pretty good regime.

They say, of course, that the biggest problem confronting Australia is unemployment. This issue is, certainly, what we have to be turning our minds to in this House. But what is going to be the outcome of the Opposition's policies on unemployment? One could imagine going through all the pain, the confrontation, the reduced wages, the lower productivity outcome, if one thought that more people were going to get jobs, if one thought that more families were going to have breadwinners. Then it may all be worth while. However, people know that that is not going to be the case.

We recently had a survey of, I think, 38 leading economists, which was published in the Sydney Morning Herald. They were asked the basic question, `Comparing the Government's policy in the One Nation statement and in the Budget with the Opposition's Fightback policy, what do you believe will be the outcome for employment in three years time, at the end of the next parliamentary term?' What was the answer of the leading Australian economists? Unemployment would be higher under the Opposition's Fightback policies than under the Government's policy. So all of that confrontation can take place; people's wages can be reduced; the industrial system which has produced low inflation and the lowest level of industrial disputes in this country in 30 years can be attacked; and what is the result? The result is more unemployment.

Why are they proposing this? At the end of the day, it is made crystal clear by the activities in Victoria. At the very time that they were reducing people's wages, while they were knocking off leave loading, while they were cutting down on penalty rates, the same industrial relations Minister voted himself and the rest of his colleagues there a massive pay rise. They give themselves a pay rise and they take it off everyone else. They get silver service in their dining room and they get the Speaker to put on the wig and they put on their top hat and tails to go to the Melbourne Cup. It is the return of the old boys, the return of the people who were `born to rule'. At the same time, in their scenario, ordinary people's wages are cut so that we can have more profit and more money for ourselves. But do they achieve anything for the country? Do they get better productivity? No, they get higher inflation through their goods and services tax; they get lower productivity; and, at the end of the day, they get higher unemployment. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker—
—My God, look who they have dragged in now.

—The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is going to interject again in my speech. We ought to export the Minister for Immigration and perhaps we could lift Australia's productivity dramatically. We are going to export him when the election is called, are we not? On the 19th the Minister will be out of office. But let us get back to the topic at hand. The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls) has said that we ought to increase the penalties on bosses if they have the audacity to break any provision of any federal award. That is a reasonable proposition? However, coming from the other side of the House, I suspect it is consistent with all the policy generation that I have seen by the ALP in my 23-odd years in this country. All of that is directed towards kicking the bosses, kicking industry, belting business and getting them out of business if at all possible. Then honourable members opposite sit and wring their hands and wonder why we have over one million unemployed people in Australia today.

PARA.TAB: Access Economics is reported in this morning's newspaper as putting the number of underemployed at almost 1.8 million. That is over 20 per cent of the working population of this country. The honourable member for Kennedy says it is not high enough. Let us have more unemployment and more devastation of families, let us have more children whose parents do not have the opportunity to earn a living. Let us put more on the dole queues and see whether we can raise some more money for social security. Will we borrow the money so that we can pay more money in unemployment benefits? What a terrific economic scenario! I really like it; that is great.

The basis of all this seems to be that the honourable member for Kennedy has some kind of twist in the back of his mind that New Zealanders are stealing Australian jobs. That is true, but they are not stealing them on the farms in North Queensland, they are stealing them out of the factories in Victoria. Do honourable members know why? It is because New Zealanders have figured out how to become more productive. They have figured out how to develop an outward looking, dynamic manufacturing sector that adds value to products. Mark my words, in the next few years that little country over there, those two islands, are going to whip us and they are going to make us look silly when it comes to productivity.

If we look at the latest OECD reports, we find that New Zealand's competitiveness has now placed it on the top of the ladder. It was a laughing-stock a few years ago, an absolute laughing-stock, but the OECD thinks New Zealand is getting its act together. And it has a lot of debt that is a hangover from the 20, 30 or 40 years with the protectionist walls that it hid behind with its import boards, its export controls, with controls stifling every part of the economy. That is what honourable members opposite want to reintroduce into Australia.

We have now this ossified, antiquated, centralised industrial relations system that acts to restrain the ability of individuals to take any control over their own lives. I will tell the honourable member for Kennedy why there is industrial confrontation around Australia today. It is his kinds of policies that have for so very long kept honest, hard working Australian men and women away from the bosses on the other side of the table. We do not allow in this country a cooperative attitude towards the workplace.

The business of business is providing products and services that Australian people want, that we demand and require out of our economy. If we do not make them here and we do not supply them here, Australians will buy them from overseas, and that is what is happening under the Government's policy. That is why we owe the rest of the world over $160 billion. That is why the current account deficit was over $1.6 billion last month and is rising constantly, to the point where Australia is going to become bankrupt if we are not careful.

It is the policies of this Government that have constantly increased our debt from some $23 billion at the beginning of the Hawke-Keating Government to almost $160 billion today. That is disgraceful. The honourable member comes in here and says, `Let's kick the bosses. Let's see what we can do to accelerate the class war'. That is what I heard from John Halfpenny on the streets of Victoria two days ago. What can be expected from those who grew out of the Industrial Revolution at the turn of the century!

The honourable member talks about returning to the turn of the century type of confrontation. I will tell the House where it is coming from—the so-called trade union movement. It is coming from dinosaurs such as John Halfpenny and Bill Deller—the Trotskyites, the old commos under the bed. They are not under the bed any more; they are out on the streets and they are marching again. Isn't that terrific! That is what business and industry needs; that is going to provide more jobs; that is going to let more Australian men and women be productive, find an income and have a decent working life?

The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) wants to bring more people into the country. I agree with him—we should have an active immigration policy; I am one of the immigrants. But we had better figure out how to find some jobs for them. With this Government's policies we certainly have not figured it out. The honourable member for Kennedy simply wants to exacerbate that by kicking the bosses and industry, adding another level of bureaucracy if possible, making industry spend more money and making it conform to more rules, more regulation and more prescription.

We live with this Government's kind of politics from top down—everything is top down. This Government decides at the top and the rest of Australia conforms. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) comes in here and stands at the despatch box day after day. He lectures the Australian people on what a decimated society we will have in this country should the Opposition ever have the opportunity to sit on that side of the House. But he does not talk about what his Government is doing to create jobs.

The honourable member for Kennedy has the obvious answer to the question: how do we create jobs? His answer is to kick the bosses. That will make some more jobs and will encourage more people to go into business? That will encourage us to develop new products, new services, new enterprise and find new jobs for the one million Australians out of work and the 1.8 million Australians underemployed?

The honourable member for Kennedy talks about tyranny. We have tyranny because theoretically, according to him, a shearer or two in his electorate might be working out of hours. The rules of prescription say that people are not allowed to work when it gets dark. They say that people are not allowed to work on Saturday or on Sunday. We had better make sure that we conform to the rules! It does not matter whether the rules are sensible or silly or ridiculous.

When there is a debate about penalty rates, the Prime Minister comes to the despatch box and talks about enterprise agreements, where penalty rates have been rolled into a base hourly rate. It does not matter what time of the week, what day of the week or what hour of the day people work; it is the base rate of pay that carries over. He brags about that as being an example of a modern industrial relations policy in Australia. I happen to agree with him. It is sensible and it is the kind of result that we like to see across the nation. But some 450 workplace agreements under this Government's system—and very few of those encompass a full-week spread of hours—would indicate that the Government's policy is just too slow. Do honourable members know why? Because this Government's policy says that an individual in this country has no rights; the only people that have rights are unions. They have monopoly power and control over the entire system and, believe me, they exercise it. Individuals have no rights under the system. The unions have all the power and all the control. Without change we will never achieve the flexibility that this country needs to become dynamic, outgoing and forward looking as we develop an economy that is relevant in the dying stages of the twentieth century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —That speech by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) was one of the most powerful speeches I have heard for confrontation and division in this country. I am disappointed to hear it coming from the honourable member for La Trobe. He has identified what the Opposition's industrial relations policy is really about. When he attacks Australian workers and their entitlements, he is attacking Australian families. That is what he is on about.

PARA.TAB: What the honourable member is really saying to the people of this country is, `Australian family incomes are too high. Australian family incomes have to be reduced, and if somehow we can reduce them by about one per cent by abolishing holiday leave loading, then prosperity will reign forever'. That is arrant nonsense, but it does indicate the class approach of the honourable member and those who sit around him.

The honourable member for La Trobe talks about New Zealand. He must see through different eyes when he goes to New Zealand. New Zealand is a nation which is in a state of misery. There is bitterness in New Zealand because of the way families are suffering over there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the honourable members please continue their debate outside the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—Order! Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the floor.
—Oh, tough luck.
—I would like the honourable member to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw it.

—The state of misery and bitterness that is in New Zealand today is a legacy that is going to hang around that nation for a long time. Countries cannot achieve better productivity and greater competitiveness by coercing and compelling people. Those things are achieved by working together with people. That is the difference between us and the honourable members opposite.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for La Trobe talked about the industrial relations system being ossified, antiquated and centralised. The move to a consultative environment—a move for change and improvement, with 2 1/2 per cent productivity coming through the system—is very much a result of an initiative of the trade unions.

What the honourable member ignores completely is the mediocrity of much of Australian management. It does not matter how keen the members of the work force are or how eager they are to produce better and more competitively, unless there is leadership from the top of the organisation nothing is going to happen. In many workplaces in this country there is no leadership. People do not know what to do. There is mediocrity.

That is the major problem amongst those 600,000 middle managers in this country. We have to address that problem. We want honourable members on the other side of the House to join us in addressing that problem and not to continue to turn a blind eye to it: there is none so blind as he who will not see. The honourable member for La Trobe ignores the mediocrity of management, and his reference to debt is really a total misrepresentation.

There is international debt, but the vast majority of that debt is not Federal government debt, it is private sector debt, and it is State government and State government instrumentality debt. The motion moved by the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) says:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Government review the penalties for breaches in federal industrial awards by employers with a view to substantial increases in these penalties to ensure employers comply with award conditions.

There would not be a member of this chamber who has not had to deal with complaints from constituents about award breaches, whether they be about pay rates, termination payments, or redundancy entitlements. We have all had to deal with them, and we all know about them, so let us not pretend that they are not there.

PARA.TAB: Most complaints involve small business, notably the hospitality industry and the retail prepared-food business, often in the motel industry. They include failure to pay award rates of pay, determination payments and allowances for work out of ordinary hours. Some of the complaints and the breaches are petty. I dealt with a case where an employer sacked a young girl without notice and then decided, because she had not done her job that day that, even though she had worked for him for several months, he would keep her apron and her uniform. The treatment of that girl caused anguish for her family and made it very difficult for her to get future employment. That is an example of the pettiness of some of these things.

The honourable member for La Trobe said, `Leave it all to the employers. They are good, generous, honourable people. They will look after their employees'. He would say, `Just let that young lady sit down and talk to her employer and he will be reasonable and he will make sure she gets a fair deal'. Again, that is arrant nonsense, as would be obvious to any honourable member who went out in the real world of industry and talked to real businesses and to his constituents.

There is wrong on both sides, at times, but there has to be a mechanism to help employees through those problems. There is a high level of ignorance amongst small business, both on the part of employers and employees. That is particularly the case in the hospitality industry. There is also another aspect in that much of the employment in that industry is of a transient nature; people work there for a few months and move on. It is very hard for people to know what their entitlements are, and that makes it hard for those persons to then try to pursue their proper entitlements. Employees are in a very weak position to initiate complaints. In the main, they do not know whom to approach and they are afraid of losing their jobs.

The State governments do not do very much. They allocate very few resources to police State award provisions. Many of the requests we get deal with State award provisions. We then have to refer them to the State body or department concerned. Federally, through the Department of Industrial Relations and the arbitration inspectoral offices, there is investigation of complaints. According to the annual report of the Department of Industrial Relations, some 16,000 investigations were made last year for people covered by Federal awards. The great majority of those were recovered by voluntary rectification by employers of breaches of the award. In other words, the inspector was able to come to an agreement with the employer.

As I have said, some of those are due to ignorance. That puts a greater onus on employer associations to ensure that their members are kept up to date with award provisions and with what they should be doing for their employees. Inspectors often get disheartened when performing their tasks on behalf of Australian employees and their families. They often get disheartened because, when a case ultimately gets to court, there is a token penalty imposed. They cannot leave the system. The Department has received 16,000 complaints—that is only from people who have come to the Department seeking assistance—so there are 16,000 decisions to be made. That cannot be ignored. That is the tip of the iceberg.

Last year, 200,000 inquiries were made of the Department of Industrial Relations about award provisions—that is, 200,000 out of a employed work force of some 7 1/2 million. It is a very large number. As I said, employer problems often emanate from ignorance, but that is not an excuse by itself. There is a need for government to be involved in the protection of employees' rights. I want to stress that—this is going back to when the honourable member for La Trobe and the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), spoke—70 per cent of employees in the private sector are not in unions. Why do honourable members opposite labour on as though the salvation of the economy rests on hammering the other 30 per cent? Seventy per cent of people in the private sector are not in unions and yet the Opposition attacks the trade union movement. It attacks everything that the union movement is involved in, as though the union movement were responsible for those 70 per cent. The Opposition should get its priorities right.

These award complaints and inquiries are just the tip of the iceberg—most people do not know what to do and they are scared stiff. People will often ring my office but they will not give their names. They are afraid to give their names for fear of their employer finding out. I know that a number of other members have had the same experience. I mean, they have to have. So, in that sense, this is the tip of the iceberg. It really points to the unfairness, and to the inequity, of what the Opposition is about in wanting to abolish awards.

There were 200,000 inquiries last year such as: `What am I entitled to?', `What's my pay?', `I have not been paid.', `I have not got my termination entitlement.', `What can I do?'. The Opposition says, `Forget you. You don't count. Your family doesn't count. You'll do as the boss tells you'. The Opposition wants us to cast all of those employees out into the market and to let employers pay them what they want to pay them. That takes us back to the Industrial Revolution. Awards came in to prevent those abuses. It is nonsense to talk about an employee sitting down with a generous hearted employer, as if there were some sort of equality in a negotiation or discussion position.

I believe there is a need to review the operation of this area. The most important and overriding need of all is to ensure that the incomes of Australian families are protected and that the breadwinners of Australian families are protected. We need to ensure that they get their proper entitlements under the awards—no-one is asking for more than that. We just want to ensure that people get fair treatment, that they get equitable treatment and that they have the opportunity to be paid what they are supposed to be paid.

The honourable member for Macarthur referred to leave loadings; that is, that one per cent of annual labour costs for an employee. They are available in eight other OECD countries, and are generally far more than Australia is paying. In respect of compensation costs per hour, Australia is not a high paying nation; we are sixteenth on the scale in hourly costs. Our on-costs are fifteenth in order. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know why it is that I often find myself following the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) but today's contribution by that honourable member gives me the opportunity to make a few observations.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Shortland has talked constantly about what he purports to be our desire to drive down wages and conditions in Australia. I want to say to the honourable member, as a small businessman and an employer in this country, that this is utter nonsense. It is nonsense because driving wages and conditions down does not work. We know it does not work; the Government has shown us that. That is what it has been doing for 10 years. When the honourable member for Shortland talks about our being sixteenth in terms of compensation for work, he is dead right. Where were we 20 years ago? Well up the list. We are now well down the list. The Government has shown us that lowering wages and entitlements does not work because that is what it has been doing for 10 years: 10 years of declining real living standards; 10 years of buying jobs via debt, which is unsustainable, as we are now seeing—there is $180 billion worth of gross foreign debt now loaded against our children's futures. Unemployment is officially at 11 per cent and unemployment plus underemployment is apparently running as high as 20 per cent in this country. They have just thrown out a President in America because his great crime was to allow unemployment to rise to 7.4 per cent.

The Government has given us a low productivity, low wage, high unemployment economy, and it is plain to see that it has not worked. It is plain to Australian businessmen, whom we expect to provide the jobs; it is plain to enlightened trade unionists; it is plain to intelligent workers; but apparently it is not plain to the Government and it is not plain to its trade union friends outside.

The Government is not interested in pursuing honest debate in this; it is into misrepresentation. It is hand in glove with the Victorian unions. Let me quote from the Melbourne Herald-Sun this morning, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Union chiefs have filled their members with a dread not supported by the facts in the debate over the Victorian Government's new industrial relations laws.
Honourable members opposite want to continue this misrepresentation in this place. The Herald-Sun goes on to say:
Legislative amendments addressing the concerns of workers have been conveniently ignored and the union chiefs—
cop this—
