are like the generals in the Great War of 1914-1918 who ordered their troops over the top with little regard for casualties.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a classy paper you are quoting.
—It does not suit you, so shoot the messenger—the usual line from honourable members opposite. Max Walsh this morning, in another paper not altogether unfriendly to the Government, said this:

PARA.TAB: Where Australia also marched to a different drummer from others was in its engines of growth.

SPEECH.PARA: It is when you look at those facts against the organised resistance of the trade union movement in Victoria to institutional change—a policy which has the support of the Federal Labor Government—the proposition that Australia is the last hold-out of the Luddites is far from ridiculous.

The motion before us is a very interesting one. It seeks to review the penalties for breaches of Federal awards by employers with a view to substantially increasing penalties for employers who fail to comply with award conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just as well you are not operating on a productivity basis; you are the great underachiever.

—The honourable member will keep. Firstly, the proposal is unfair. It does not seek to address the capacity of the AIRC to deal with recalcitrant employees, just employers. Secondly, it is naive. It takes no account of nor does it reflect any understanding of what is actually happening out in recession damaged Australia. Thirdly, it is anti-employment. When the Government, including the honourable member responsible for this piece of nonsense, continually crows about the need to cut the dole queues, it might do better to aid and encourage employers to employ, not impose yet more potential penalties on them for trying to do so.

PARA.TAB: Finally, and ironically, the motion is counter-productive to the Government's stated objective of improving employment at the same time as keeping people in the system. I am sure that the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) neither intended nor realised this potential, but the truth is that the result of the action that he is proposing would be to increase the push on the part of the employers in this country, and enlightened employees as well, to leave the very centralised system that he is so committed to. Maybe on that basis we ought to think about supporting the motion.

To return to my first point, this proposal is simply unfair. Current penalties available for imposition by the AIRC are quite weak. Section 311 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 allows for penalties, if an award or order of the Commission is broken, of just $500 in the case of a natural person or $1,000 in the case of a body corporate. It is the same for either side of the employee-employer divide.

This motion flies in the face of the Australian values of fairness and mateship that the honourable member referred to at some length when he introduced his motion. To suggest that an employer who breaks an award or order should suffer a greater penalty than should an employee who does the same is unfair. Where is the fairness in that? It also flies in the face of a generally acknowledged fact in Australia that it is more often unions and their members who flout awards and orders. In fact, that is one of the reasons why the centralised system has lost so much credibility.

Most of the enforcement provisions available to the Industrial Relations Commission have been widely assumed to be of little or no relevance as a means of ensuring adherence to its instructions. This is one of the major reasons why so many employers have displayed a greater willingness to seek assistance or remedy outside the system by resorting to sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act, for example, or by seeking contractual arrangements for their workplaces.

The honourable member is also plainly unaware of what it is like to try to employ people in recession ravaged Australia. I do not know how many of the gaggle over there have actually tried to run a small business over the last few years, or whether they understand what it is like to try to keep something alive and employ people during the recession that the Government has imposed on this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —More have on this side than on your side.
—Rubbish! Name them. How many are there?
—Order! The honourable member should not respond to interjections.

—Honourable members opposite are not trying to maintain a small business in this recession, as I am. Their lack of business understanding is shown by the fact that they have not really entered into this area. They do not understand it.

PARA.TAB: This motion apparently has its genesis in the shearing industry. It just so happens that, although it may have escaped the notice of those opposite, the wool industry is in a severe crisis in this country. Its future and the jobs that go with it are hanging in the balance. If shearers want to adopt an us and them attitude, aided and abetted in that process by honourable members opposite, and if they want to maintain the work practices developed in the good times through the bad times while the growers go broke, then it stands to reason that they will find that there will not be any good times in the future. There will not be any jobs either.

Workers are more sensible than many of their so-called representatives in the union movement in this place. I recall that 1982 was a year of shocking drought in rural Australia. One major employer whom I knew in New South Wales sat down with his employees and said, `We are going to go broke if we can't find a more sensible approach to surviving this drought'. So they drew up a negotiated settlement which they had to keep secret from the union because it was illegal. However, the net result of that was that the company survived. It survives today and those people still have their jobs, but it was an illegal settlement.

That is an utter nonsense. The employees and the employer could understand that and yet their representatives elsewhere could not. So wake up, there cannot be restraint with equity when honourable members opposite mindlessly try to protect their mates at the expense of the unprotected who then lose their jobs or, in the case of the businesses that provide the jobs, go under.

The net effect of this motion would be directly opposite to its purported objective. It would increase unemployment and it would further undermine the credibility of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and simply serve to drive more people away from a centralised system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bailey Mrs F.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to the rabble opposite I think it is about time we had some commonsense in this place. May 12 this year was declared a day of action on unemployment. Community, church and social welfare groups organised the date to direct the attention of the public and the media to the plight of Australia's growing number of unemployed, and to seek a commitment from members of parliament that they make the reduction of unemployment their top priority. We have seen little evidence that members of the Government have been prepared to do that. Today's unemployment figures once again will be testimony to this Government's lack of will to tackle the causes of the problem of unemployment. One suggestion to try to alleviate our unemployment crisis for young people in particular, and their suffering, however, arose from a meeting in Castlemaine in my electorate of McEwen: a system of voluntary national service for young unemployed Australians. On behalf of those people in Castlemaine I therefore move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)investigates the use of voluntary national service for young unemployed Australians; and
(2)acknowledges the skills that young people would acquire through undertaking voluntary national service.

The term `voluntary national service' is used to describe programs in which young people perform tasks that are not performed by either the private sector or government. Included in that category are activities such as home care for the elderly or disabled, conservation activities and work in non-profit human service organisations. The reasons for a scheme of voluntary national service vary. Some people see such a program in terms of the benefits it will provide to society as a whole. Others view it in the light of the value it will provide to those who participate, either in terms of training or in terms of the community spirit it generates in the youth involved. Whilst the two are not mutually exclusive, I want to focus today on the benefit that a program of voluntary national service will have for young unemployed.

PARA.TAB: Voluntary national service has the potential to help young people by providing them with skills while at the same time providing them with self-discipline and developing in them a sense of responsibility and self-worth. Indeed, it is a way of reducing that alienation that young people so often feel, and instilling in them a greater awareness of the society in which they live. Such awareness can be developed and fostered by providing young people of different social, cultural or economic backgrounds with new experiences, by exposing them to social problems or a side of life that they might not otherwise see.

However, I believe that to determine the important role voluntary national service can play in Australia we need only look to what is happening to those young Australians who are presently unemployed and at the adverse effect unemployment is having on them. In Australia today 31.8 per cent of the population aged between 15 and 19 are unemployed. In fact, the unemployment figures which are to be released today are unlikely to show any marked improvement in that situation. Australia's young are facing bleak employment prospects and are being denied the opportunity to develop their skills and talents. They are obliged to take what little is on offer, whether or not it suits their ambitions or skills. In the rural areas of my electorate, where the youth unemployment rate is much higher, the situation is even more desperate. Many of the jobs that used to be available to teenagers, such as apprenticeships and farm work, are no longer available. Consequently they are forced to leave their homes to look for work in the city, but because of limited training and qualifications they face the prospect of being unemployed and homeless.

The adverse effect on unemployment is incontestable. Unemployment impacts not only in a financial sense but often, more importantly, in a physical, emotional and mental sense. Studies have shown that psychological maturity is the result of a successful transition through a series of development stages—and one of the most important stages is work. But bear in mind that the longer people are out of work, the lower their chances of success in gaining employment. In fact, during the 1980s, on average, nine new jobs were created before one unemployed person obtained work, and 18 new jobs were created before one long term unemployed person obtained work. When one considers that this recession has already more than doubled the number of long term unemployed to over 300,000, the prospects are frightening—particularly for young people.

In Sydney earlier this year, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) convened an open and public meeting on youth unemployment. A range of speakers from a range of backgrounds came together to give their views and ideas on how the pain could be alleviated. The concept of voluntary national service was put forward by the Anglican Archbishop, the Right Reverend Peter Hollingworth. He wanted a civilian national service scheme covering 250,000 people to be introduced. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Through community service young people can be involved in the vital tasks of nation building and of knowing they are making an important contribution by participating in projects of national significance. Such a scheme, offering broader life experiences across cultural and class differences, can be of enormous benefit in breaking down barriers and helping understand one another. The scheme would provide a marvellous opportunity to develop that essential quality of teamwork which comes about when people live and work together in the pursuit of common goals.

However, the Government has ignored that and many other sensible suggestions that were put forward on that day. Instead of trying to tackle the causes of youth unemployment, the Government decided to provide funding for short term programs, which in the past have had poor or dubious outcomes.

PARA.TAB: What is really needed is for government to decide, based on changing demographics and changing marketplace, exactly what the Australian work force is going to be like in the next decade and develop education and training programs to provide our young people with those skills needed to match that very changing work place. The Government needs to develop long term plans, rather than more stopgap measures. A program of voluntary national service has the potential to become one of those long term plans and, with bipartisan support, it can work for the good of all young unemployed Australians.
As Professor Amitai Etzioni of George Washington University, on this very subject in a book titled The moral equivalent of war; a study of non military service in nine countries, said:

SPEECH.PARA: On a more individual basis, national service programs provide young people with an opportunity to better themselves as they serve others. The secret lies in a sociological format known as `total institutions'.
He further adds:

There is no more effective way to reach drug addicts, juvenile delinquents, or overindulged children than to take them out of their corrupting environment and put them in a conservation corp or some other all encompassing service program.

Unfortunately, there is not a lot of Australian information with regard to this subject. However, there is a wealth of American and overseas information which provides a useful insight into some of their ventures into this area.

PARA.TAB: One program which has been hugely successful is the New York City's volunteer corps, known as the CVs. Young volunteers in this scheme have been involved in painting Staten Island ferry boats, providing companionship, performing household chores for the elderly, helping elementary school teachers with supervision of young children and building nature trails.
One of the most positive elements that have come out of this venture is the change in attitudes of the CVs towards the elderly. The first Director of the program said:

SPEECH.PARA: Old people disgusted some of the CV's before they joined the CVC. After working with the elderly they say how much they have to contribute.
In fact, CVs have continued visiting nursing home patients after a team assignment has ended. There have even been cases of CVs moving into hospices to sit with dying patients around the clock.

PARA.TAB: Today I am proposing a voluntary scheme which will provide jobs for those young unemployed people who want them. They can be involved in work in parks, gardens, local hospitals, nursing homes—the agenda is unlimited. However, what I am proposing is not new. In fact, it is already happening in parts of my electorate, albeit on a smaller scale. For instance, the Craigieburn youth involvement project, which has been operating for more than six years, involves young, unemployed people doing work for a small amount of pay. For some of those young people, it is the only work they have ever had.

Although this is on a smaller scale, it is driven by the same motive: to help our unemployed young people; to get them off the streets; to get them doing something productive. I want to harness all that energy and pool it into one coordinated scheme which is practical and flexible and which meets the changing and different needs of Australia's unemployed young.

A discussion paper circulated by the United States Congressional Budget Office in September 1990, titled National service; issues and options, put forward three types of programs which could be run under a scheme of voluntary national service. The first was a sponsorship program that would match young people with non-profit organisations. Participants would function in low skill capacities in a variety of fields.

The second program was the urban service program in which participants would perform a wide range of tasks, such as assisting with urban revitalisation projects and providing care to the elderly or disabled. The distinction between this and the sponsorship program is that the participants would work in teams. The third program was for a conservation corps, where young people would be involved in conservation activities, such as planting trees, grading trails and maintaining parks.

In any design of a program of national service, we need to consider and provide answers to the following questions: who would participate; what would the participants do; would the participants be compensated; what sort of system of accreditation would be put in place; and how much would a national service program cost? One of the reasons that I decided to put forward this motion today was so that we, as a parliament, could agree to work together and find the answers to those questions and put in place a scheme to benefit all young Australians. The whole thrust of the argument for voluntary national service is summed up in the following quote from an editorial in the London Times on this subject:

SPEECH.PARA: There are people, some old, some in ill health, some incapacitated, who need assistance in a form other than cash is unquestionable. There are potential young volunteers with energy and time. What needs hard thought is how to link them . . . Innovation in public policy will entail some scheme by which central Government can better motivate and assist, without smothering or nannying, the myriad of local groups which alone can intimately link the needy and the helpers.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, the problem of youth unemployment is one of the very serious problems that are affecting this country. Our young people are the key to the future of this country. We can no longer allow such a high percentage of young people to be on the unemployment lists. They deserve far better. They deserve the dedication and the commitment of all members of this House. We should work together to find a solution and to attack the causes of the problems that are causing such large numbers of young people to be on those unemployment lists.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—The honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey) will strike a chord on the airwaves this morning, for what she says is the essence of the heart-on-the-sleeve, emotional sweetness that is appreciated by a lot of people. But one should have a much harder look at the reality and the substance of what she is saying.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned about unemployment. I am concerned about youth unemployment, and I am particularly concerned about unemployment among middle-aged people who, in my view, face a much greater problem. What has been put forward by the honourable member for McEwen is breathtaking in its simplicity in sound only, for in reality it is enormously complicated.

Here we have a member of the Liberal Party of Australia talking about one coordinated scheme for the whole of Australia. One can imagine the complexity of the bureaucracy that would be involved in that. The cost of the bureaucracy would be enormous, because the bureaucracy would not work for nothing, as the honourable member wants the unemployed to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be done through local government.

—If it were done through local government, it would not be one coordinated scheme. If the honourable member is going to put forward these schemes, I suggest she has a responsibility to put forward to the Government something which is workable. There is a more workable scheme, and that is simply to extend CDEP—which operates in Aboriginal communities—to the general community. We should let councils enter into CDEPs in which people collect the dole for the work they do. If they work for three days a week, then they get about the equivalent of award wages. In most cases, councils would have the administrative capability to look after these people if they were available on a consistent basis.

PARA.TAB: If the honourable member for McEwen were to put forward a program like that, it would make a lot more sense. However, what she is putting forward is not one coordinated scheme because it relies on using the expertise and resources of local government. With the successes and failures of CDEP, a workable scheme could be sorted out because some local governments would do it very well and others would flounder, as they do at the moment, but at least we would have a model which could be copied.

When the honourable member talks about the things she wants these people to do, at the end of the day there is very little that is productive in it. It is absolute nonsense and hypocritical in the extreme to come into this place and talk about providing these sorts of things when the economy is going to need productivity.

That other professional hand-wringer which the honourable member mentioned, the Right Reverend Archbishop Hollingworth, is a man who is continually bleating about the plight of the poor, but at the same time he is advocating high immigration into this country. It should be obvious to even the eminent archbishop that the two are contradictory. If there is massive unemployment, it will be compounded by bringing migrants into Australia, particularly as many migrants today are of the unemployable kind. If the archbishop cannot see how illogical his own stance is, then I suggest it does give some idea of the weight which we should attach to his views.

I was also interested to hear the honourable member for McEwen talking about what the Government should do. The honourable member tells us openly that the Government should decide what the workplace should be like in the long term and should direct its policies towards that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Someone has to do something about it.

—I agree entirely, and I think in this case the honourable member is absolutely right. I also hold those socialist values. I also believe in a planned economy. Honourable members on the other side of the House blindly advocate the idea of the level playing field, and so it is refreshing to hear at least someone on the other side, even though it is an obscure person, advocating that we do have government planning. More than that, we are also told that the Government needs these long term plans. What has happened to the level playing field? What has happened to the marketplace deciding it?

PARA.TAB: Of course, the marketplace was always nonsense. It is slavish adherence to the marketplace by honourable members opposite and by this Government that is the main cause of unemployment in this country today. I can say now that there will be no full employment in this country unless we get manufacturing industry going. I was at a meeting this morning that was concerned with the great benefits of tourism, yet the Department of Finance officers could not tell us a figure for the net value of tourism to this country. It is significantly less than the $8 billion gross value that is attributed to it. Despite this, we have people saying to us that tourism is much more important than the wool industry. That is arrant nonsense. This country needs to be productive, it needs people producing things.

How can this be achieved? I believe it can be achieved very easily if governments force their public servants, their bureaucrats, to buy locally when making purchases. Remember, even in the wildest of free enterprise economies, even in the feral economy that honourable members opposite contemplate, government will still be the single biggest buyer. Government will always be the biggest single customer. If government were to insist that public servants purchase products on the basis of the real through-life cost, then they would find that Australian manufactured equipment became much cheaper.

I have been looking at examples recently which clearly demonstrate this. People in their mad passion to buy overseas products often buy inferior products. We can see engineering equipment coming out of Germany every day that is not a patch on the quality of Australian equipment, yet it is being bought by Australian industry, by Australian government departments and by semi-government authorities. If governments were to insist that the through-life cost, the real cost, be the criteria of purchasing, then there would be a lot more manufacturing in Australia.

If there were a lot more manufacturing there would be worthwhile jobs for people, jobs where they can earn income and have dignity. Then they can make up their own minds whether they want to sit in hospices. I am sure there will be people who want to do that. I believe that the youth of today is no less compassionate than the youth of the past. I believe that we can motivate some of the middle aged people who are in a much worse situation than youth to get out and contribute their experience to society. But to put forward this program today as some form of salvation is really, in my view, a cop-out.

When we are talking about national service, one of the things that we could look at as a government is the military. I am not advocating national service in the military because I do not think it is in Australia's defence interests. It is not wanted by the Australian Defence Force and it would require a substantial amount of extra spending on defence. But I think it would make a lot more sense if we were to utilise the resources of our military for construction projects in isolated areas.

Opposition to this idea does not come from the unions, it comes from politicians and bureaucrats who believe that the unions would not cop it. I know very well that with proper negotiations unions would agree because they realise that there are benefits to the wider community. For instance, if the Army was to build a few bridges between Alice Springs and Darwin instead of digging holes and filling them in, sooner or later the Alice Springs-Darwin railway would be economically viable. I think that is the sort of thing that we could consider. After all, in the United States, the land of free enterprise, the Corps of Engineers is responsible for all United States internal waterways and it totally controls the operation and construction of all those waterways. I might add, it does so very well.

There is no doubt that unemployment saps the vitality of this nation. I can only urge the Government and the Opposition to support the idea that we look seriously at manufacturing industry in this country. We must stop the nonsense that we have been espousing for so long and do something that is going to provide real long term employment and a future for the kids of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed a pleasure to second and support the motion by the honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey) this morning. I say that for one principal reason which no reasonable person, either inside this House or outside, can dismiss: the fact that unemployment is the scourge of our society. That really is the point that the honourable member for McEwen is making in putting this motion before the House this morning.

PARA.TAB: I am a little disappointed in some of the comments of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). First of all, he really has not addressed the motion. Secondly, the motion is certainly not a cop-out. This highlights the continuing adhockery and political point scoring that goes on in this place and outside it on issues that should have a more national perspective. I would agree that we do need a national manpower strategy plan, and I think that is in some ways what the honourable member was saying. Many of us are searching for solutions and, with due respect to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, he has said nothing in this place this morning which would give me any confidence that he had the solution. I support the honourable member for McEwen in the motion and commend the motion to the House.

All of us are looking for solutions in this area, not least at the local electorate level. I would like to take the opportunity this morning to commend a local schoolteacher in my electorate, Michelle Reid, who is a special school teacher in Toowoomba. This time last week she held a local youth and business community enterprise expo. It was a special youth expo, and the aims of that expo were to provide:

SPEECH.PARA: an opportunity for young people, their families, guardians and teachers to access information about current services and future options available from a wide variety of community clubs and organisations.
Secondly, she tried to provide:
a venue for special young people to show the community their achievements and capabilities through organisation and participation of those organisations in the Expo.

Finally, she tried—very successfully, I think—to provide an opportunity for interaction, both functional and social, between people concerned about the needs of youth across the Darling Downs in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: I come back to a more macro national level. Like the member for McEwen, I would also like to refer to some comments of Archbishop Peter Hollingworth. I have to say at the outset I do not always agree with Archbishop Hollingworth, but on this point I do; and I think that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has not fully appreciated what the archbishop is trying to say. What he said back in March of this year on national service was that we needed `a range of activities, including community projects through to environmental activities'. He said:
I suppose the word national service is a bit of a problem because of what people infer from it, but I do think there's going to be a need for a series of schemes.
I suppose you could call them voluntary-based national service projects for which people could secure an income, gain some skills and feel that they were contributing to society.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say:
We need the thing we don't yet have . . .
And I think that is an important point. This Government certainly has not provided what the youth are seeking. He went on:

PARA.TAB: We need . . . a comprehensive package of programs involving pre-traineeship, traineeship, job placement, work experience, volunteer national service, and job generation activities which would both enhance the work-readiness of people, generate . . . jobs and at least make them productively and creatively involved and not left out in the fringes.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: The national service scheme would not involve military training but would be a voluntary system where young jobless people could do community work and earn a minimal wage.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, and most importantly, he made a point that a lot of Australians need to understand, when he was reported as saying that the nation's young were fast becoming the `lost generation' and needed support.

PARA.TAB: The basic question that we really need to ask this morning, in terms of this motion, is what we mean by national service. Of course, it would be a reasonable thing to say that national service means different things to different people. I would like to suggest to you this morning that national service is an ideal that encompasses a variety of often inconsistent ideas. The core of the concept, as I see it, is the conviction that the nation and its citizens would be far better off if more persons devoted a portion of their lives to some sort of public service.

The various proponents of national service perhaps agree on that much but, outside the core conviction, there is clearly a lot of disagreement. Perhaps the three most significant disagreements concern whether programs should be voluntary—as the honourable member is suggesting this morning—or compulsory; whether they should benefit mainly the servers or the served; and finally, whether such schemes would be designed for the disadvantaged, or would indeed make special efforts and expenditures to engage targeted areas.

There is also disagreement about the age or the ages at which service should be undertaken. Here this morning, we are talking about youth, but I would say to the honourable member for McEwen that what we are suggesting here should not be restricted to youth. In fact, it applies far more widely to other age groups. There is disagreement about the length of service, and about the character of service activities. Of course, there is the traditional difficulty of the relationship between civilian and military service rates of pay. The degree to which national service should be centrally or locally planned and managed is something about which the honourable member for McEwen and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie have had something of an exchange.

Indeed, it seems to me that national service cannot be assessed nor, in fact, really discussed, unless we are very specific about it; and that is where the difficulty arises. I have recently skimmed a very interesting book written in the United States, but nevertheless having Australian application. National Service: What Would it Mean? was written by Richard Danzig and Peter Szanton six or seven years ago. In it, they reviewed the alternative programs of national service, some or most of which have an Australian application, although of course they are written in the United States environment.

The first program, they suggested, might be school based, and would involve projects, et cetera within the schools. The second was draft based, and that is, of course, when we get into the military situation. I know that a year or so ago the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) had something to say on that. I would like to read into the record this morning what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think it would give them—
in other words, the national service people—
an opportunity for character building, teamwork, cohesion, motivation and a range of activities which flow from the military service or indeed peace corps-type or community service . . .

That, of course, is the broader issue that we are discussing this morning. The American study also talked about a third model, an evolutionary and voluntary model which involved the peace corps, environmental considerations, et cetera; and, finally, it referred to a universal model where everybody would have to make a contribution, whether in civilian or in military terms. They finished off by saying, and it is important in the context of this debate that they said this:
We emphasise this point—
and they were referring to the point that there were four programs, but that they were not exhaustive—
not because no other specific programs have ever been proposed; many have. We emphasise it because we think the political temptation is to keep the debate unparticularized.

That is exactly what is happening here this morning, and it is exemplified by the words of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. There are problems, and we need to solve those problems. The motion before the House this morning goes some way, albeit not the full way, to providing that solution. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I think I have some understanding about the motives for what those honourable members opposite are putting forward here today, the fact is that the Government already has in place a range of employment and training programs that give young unemployed people essential skills which they need in order to compete in today's local market. The introduction of a national service would be counterproductive and unnecessary. It is important how matters have been put forward here this morning, with honourable members skirting around the defence aspect, because there does seem to be that underlying factor that, when you start talking about national service, the broad population out there does think about military service in the defence area. Whilst what they have said today is commendable, we need to understand that there is a motive behind it. I think it is very mischievous sometimes for honourable members opposite to speak as they have in this context this morning. This motion consists of two parts: the first directs the Government to investigate the use of voluntary national service, and the second provides that the House:

PARA.TAB: (2) acknowledges the skills that young people would acquire through undertaking voluntary national service.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to briefly address the first part of this motion. National service would be of little benefit to those young people who are, unfortunately, unable to find work at the present time, particularly when we look at it in the military sense. As I said, the Government already provides young Australians with the opportunity to serve their country through participation in the Army Reserve and the Ready Reserve. I would just like to make a few comments about the Ready Reserve, not to mention the Australian Defence Force itself, which is a voluntary force, of course. But the RAAF in my electorate of Oxley, for instance—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have missed the plot.

—This person opposite is rather rude, Mr Deputy Speaker. Can you not keep calling her to order? She has been carrying on like this all morning. She may show a little bit of respect, but she obviously does not have much perspective. We are talking about a very serious matter here, concerning the young people of our nation, and her constant interjections just become a bit of a nightmare.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—I will certainly afford the honourable member for Oxley the protection of the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I would like to just seek clarification, without taking up the honourable member's time.
—No, you are not clarifying anything; you are making a point of order. What is the point of order?

—The point of order is that the honourable member is not addressing what this motion is about. It is not about military service; it is about voluntary national service, and if the honourable member had been listening carefully earlier, he would know that.
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. There is no-one in this country who can talk about national service without talking about it in a military context, and the previous speaker, the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), highlighted that simple fact.

PARA.TAB: I was just mentioning my electorate of Oxley, where we have the Amberley Airforce Base, which the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Price), who is at the table, visited not so long ago, or shortly after he took up that position. It is just one of the Defence Force bases that actually participate in the Ready Reserve scheme, with 30 recruits who were trained as airfield defence guards already passing through Amberley. The Ready Reserve scheme is not only an important part of the Australian defence policy; it also gives people skills and experience that will serve them well in civilian life, as we all well know. The key to the success of the Ready Reserve program is the fact that it is strictly on a volunteer basis. The people who are in the Ready Reserve want to be there.

However, service in the armed forces is not the answer as a youth unemployment program. While it provides very useful experience, this experience is, by its very nature, defence related. So the Opposition really does have a tendency of late to try to latch onto simplistic policy prescriptions for the problems faced by Australia today. These solutions, of course, act as a substitute for rational thought, which some of those honourable members opposite obviously do not have too much of. But what this country needs is action by government, not gimmicks such as the re-introduction of national service. If we were to listen to the Opposition, we would believe that all Australia's problems would be solved if we shoved the unemployed into the Army, made young people work for $3 an hour and taxed milk and bread at 15 per cent, while reducing the price of a Ferrari by $30,000.

The time for such simplistic solutions, if it ever existed, has long passed. Australians want governments to plan for recovery, and to introduce policies that directly address the problem of youth unemployment—and unemployment generally, of course, which we are doing. Rather than investigating the use of voluntary national service for young unemployed Australians, as this motion suggests, the Keating Government is implementing programs that will directly assist young unemployed Australians now, not at some vague time in the future.

I would now like to address the second part of the motion which suggests that young people would acquire skills through undertaking voluntary national service. While it is certainly true that participants in national service would acquire skills that they did not previously possess, the level of skills that they would gain would not be as great as they could gain from more structured and targeted training programs.

To understand why the introduction of voluntary national service is unnecessary and entirely inappropriate, let us look at the record of this Government in the area of providing training and employment opportunities for our young Australians. In July this year, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) released a national employment training plan for young Australians. This plan sets out a series of programs that will offer training and long term career prospects for young Australians.

The release of the plan followed the national meeting on youth unemployment that was held in Canberra on 22 July 1992. In this document, the Prime Minister gave a commitment to all long term unemployed young people that they would have the right to a six-month prevocational training course, with a Jobstart card on completion. The card would give any prospective employer a wage subsidy, if that employer hired a young person. By the end of 1993, 35,000 places will have been funded under this program.

The Prime Minister also announced the creation of career start traineeships. These will be targeted to people who leave school earlier. They are amongst the most disadvantaged people in today's highly competitive labour market. Other important initiatives contained in the program include: an expansion of Skillshare and Jobtrain, with a link to wage subsidy for a job after training is completed; an increase in subsidies for existing traineeships and in support available for apprenticeships; the creation of an extra 12,000 prevocational TAFE places by the end of the next year; $43.6m until 1995 to introduce the Australian vocational certificate, as recommended in the Carmichael report; and the provision of $56.3m over the next three years to fund Carmichael pilot projects, as well as to help in the running of career start traineeships.

One of the most significant measures in the national employment and training plan for young Australians was the announcement of a land care and environment action program. This program will not only give young people employment experience; it will also improve their long term career prospects. The program will also provide an invaluable service to the community in the form of environmental and conservation projects. When the Government was developing its youth employment strategy, it decided that a broad range of measures would be necessary in order to fully address this complex and difficult issue. It is a tragedy that around half the young unemployed are looking for a full time job for the first time. One of the most important factors an employer looks at, when considering a potential employee, is a person's past work experience.

The great advantage of the land care and environment action program is that it not only provides employment experience to young Australians, it also addresses one of this country's most pressing national problems—land and environmental degradation. The land and soil degradation that has occurred over the past 200 years is a national disgrace and needs to be addressed. This problem not only has important environmental consequences, but it is also detrimental to Australia's long term economic interests.

A great deal of previously viable agricultural land is lost every year as a result of soil erosion and soil salinisation. Several of the delegates to the Prime Minister's national meeting in July supported the concept of setting up programs to employ young people on conservation and land care projects. The idea of such a scheme was supported by the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation—an indication of the broad community support that exists for such a scheme.

The National Farmers Federation suggested in its submission that 5,000 places could be created for such a program in the short term, with an increase in this number over the long term. The Prime Minister went further than this in the national employment and training plan, with 6,000 places being created in 1992-93 and 6,500 people to be trained under the program in 1993-94. However, these are only indicative targets. If demand exceeds 6000 places this financial year, the Government will fund additional places.

Under the program, people aged 16 to 17 years will receive an allowance of $125 per week, with 18- to 20-year-olds receiving $150 per week. This is a lot more than what those opposite would offer with their $3 an hour wage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minimum.

—That is right; crook, is it not? On top of this, special allowances will be available to meet special costs in certain circumstances. At least 25 per cent of a participant's time in the program will have to be spent in a structured training program. I might point out that the land care environment action program is similar, in many ways, to the proposal—and this has been mentioned by those opposite—put forward by the Anglican Archbishop of Brisbane, the Very Reverend Peter Hollingworth. His suggestion was for a national community service scheme which he called `Serving Australia'. I recently had the opportunity to share a platform in my electorate with the Archbishop, and we spoke about these things afterwards.

PARA.TAB: The Government is willing to take on board any proposals designed to address the complex issue of youth unemployment. However, the introduction of national service, even in a voluntary capacity, is not the answer. The Government needs to implement a series of structured training programs. (Time expired)
Mr Deputy Speaker (Mr Nehl)—Order! The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.
Debate resumed from 10 September, on motion by Mr Cobb:
That the Parliament:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)welcomes the initial steps taken by the European Community to lower its massive levels of agricultural protection; and
(2)urges that the USA match these reductions in the interests of freeing up world trade in primary products.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker Mr F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to read Paul Kelly's verdict on agricultural protection in his recently published book The End of Certainty. Kelly sees the great era of Australian protectionism, which commenced with the humiliating political defeat of George Reid's free traders by Alfred Deakin's protectionists in 1902, as having been dismantled by the Hawke Government in March 1991. He waxes lyrical when he says:

SPEECH.PARA: The wonderful symmetry: that Australia will enter its second century as a nation in 2001 liberated from the protectionist's shackles which stifled its first century.

Kelly also sees the beginning of the end of the National Party with the schism that developed between the National Farmers Federation and the National Party in 1976. What Kelly is saying is that the NFF led a grassroots farmers revolt against the National Party and joined with the economic rationalists in the Liberal Party to embrace, on behalf of Australia's farmers, a free market philosophy that runs totally counter to the entrenched protectionist traditions of Page, McEwen, Anthony and Sinclair which have been the very essence of National Party ideology since the 1920s.

PARA.TAB: Kelly sees the Nationals as a dinosaur, a relic of an era of agrarian socialism, embarrassed by their own philosophy but with no adequate response to prevent their political extinction. I mention this simplistic assessment not to denigrate the National Party but because Kelly seeks in the same breath to dismiss the Left of the Australian Labor Party which, while going along with the view that Australia has to get internationally competitive, still believes in some degree of protectionism.

I am no apologist for the Nationals and I would hate anyone to think that anything I said would give them solace or support. However, I think Paul Kelly has a lot in common with George Reid when it comes to political judgment. Those who are in touch with our constituency and have access to opinion polling know well that the Australian electorate is a long way from uprooting its protectionist heritage.

Australians do not operate in the arid intellectual environment of elitist right wing think-tanks such as the Institute of Public Affairs or the Centre for Independent Studies but in the real world, which is divided into trade blocs where protectionism is being practised on a bigger and better scale than ever before. We all know that the Uruguay Round of GATT is trying to break down these trade barriers and that it would be very much in the interest of some Australian industry if protection barriers were dropped. On the other hand, the reality that the Keating Government has come to accept is that there are a lot of Australian industries that will go to the wall if some protection is not given to them, at least for the foreseeable future.

More importantly, the electorate appreciates that the overseas trend is toward trade wars, not towards the lifting of barriers. Anyone who can read knows that the Bush Administration, with the tacit support of President-elect Clinton, has just escalated the North American bloc's long-running trade offensive against Europe. Australian voters are concerned with jobs and they know that the fanatical rush of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to zero tariffs will put hundreds of thousands of Australians out of work and force tens of thousands of farmers off the land. Mindless adherence to policies of free market globalisation strikes few chords of sympathy in the psyche of the Australian voter. Whether the Paul Kellys of this world like it or not, the old Labor ideal and the old Country Party ideal still rate highly in the Australian ethos.

Perhaps Australia's future will rest upon free trade and a new enterprise culture. However, a great many things have to change, both in Australia and in the world, before that future can be realised. In the meantime, I would not be writing off the traditionalists in either the National Party or the Labor Party as dinosaurs. The real saurian analogy should be to crocodiles, which are still around after millennia and are likely to be snapping and biting long after the free market economists have been given yet another burial.

Having got that off my chest, I turn to the specific terms of the motion, which international events seem to have somewhat overtaken. In particular, I raise a special problem of agricultural protection within my electorate which is of great importance to all Australians. I refer, of course, to the discussion paper by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service concerning the importation of fresh, frozen and cooked chicken meat and products from the USA, Denmark, Thailand and New Zealand. Those countries have been lobbying the Government to gain access to Australian markets for poultry meat products.

The paper comes out strongly in favour of importation, provided pathogens associated with avian disease can be inactivated. I have received powerful and persuasive representations from the central coast branch of the New South Wales Chicken Growers Association, which strongly argues that AQIS has not given proper consideration to the health risks or the social implications of throwing thousands of chicken meat workers onto the dole.

Australia is currently free of the catastrophic effects of viral diseases which periodically annihilate chicken flocks overseas. I refer to Newcastle disease, avian influenza, Mareks disease, infectious bursal disease and salmonella enteritis. Australian consumers are provided with chicken products, internationally acknowledged as the cleanest available.

Virulent Newcastle disease is endemic in Europe, Asia and America. It is incurable, vaccination is highly expensive and native birds are susceptible to the disease. In 1972 it cost the Californian Government $56m to clean up an outbreak. The AQIS position is that if chicken meat is properly cooked all the diseases will be destroyed. It is true that the virus can be thermally inactivated by very thorough cooking for long periods. However, the virus is very stable in the environment and readily survives outside poultry bodies in dust, feathers, packaging materials, faecal matter, soil, et cetera, and it survives for years.

Improperly prepared poultry products have been confirmed as the means by which the disease has become established in many countries. Our geographic isolation and strict quarantine restrictions have resulted in a vigorous Australian poultry industry. Fired with political zeal to eliminate protectionism, AQIS now wants to put all this at risk.

It is inevitable that a cooking production line, somewhere in the world, will fail to achieve thermal inactivation. Industry standards in Thailand, for example, are not quite as good as those in Australia. Viral material can easily contaminate the cooked product via the packaging, air-conditioners, personnel, transport and the like.

Improperly cooked product may be rejected on arrival in Australia, but its very arrival puts the whole industry at risk. Core temperatures required to inactivate the virus render the food almost inedible. Unscrupulous producers overseas will be tempted to reduce costing and to increase sales by cooking less. The varying size and density of the chicken portion would require different periods to properly inactivate the virus, which would greatly add to the cost and would be likely to encourage short cuts.

Once infected material reaches Australia, unused portions will find their way into refuse bins and unsecured garbage tips frequented by scavenger birds, animals and flies. Our already endangered native bird population will be just as much at risk as our flourishing chicken industry. Veterinary certificates are no guarantee that the product originates from the exporting country, that the cooking system is sufficient or that cross-contamination has not occurred.

If Australia suffered an outbreak, we would lose very lucrative export markets. Other countries are not as ideologically pure when it comes to protecting their industries. Given the huge risks involved, I find it incredible that AQIS has taken the position it has. Those of us who believe in a viable Australian chicken industry and want to protect our native bird populations can only hope that the Government will firmly reject the risks involved in the AQIS paper as unacceptable and maintain the current restrictions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) has moved this motion. Many of the comments that he made in introducing it on 24 June remain very true today, though the situation has changed somewhat in view of the events which have occurred in the last couple of months. I had the privilege and honour of being part of an Australian delegation to the European institutions during September and I can assure honourable members that that matter of the freeing-up of trade and the initial steps taken by the European Community to lower its massive levels of agricultural protection was very much under discussion at both the European Parliament and the Council of Europe. As a member of that delegation, I had the opportunity to participate in discussions with many of the European leaders and many members of the European Parliament and also the Council of Europe on the progress being achieved in the reduction of agricultural protection throughout Europe.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Robertson (Mr Walker) has advanced a number of reasons why Australia must face up to the freeing up of trade, and in his original comments the honourable member for Parkes certainly spelt out the long process that has been undertaken to try to bring the Uruguay Round to completion. The Uruguay Round discussions commenced in 1986 and some six years later that process is still under way. We have seen much trauma during that period as a result of restrictions and opposition by the French farmers particularly, who represent only 6 per cent of the voting population in France but have an inordinate amount of political muscle in that country. The delegation was able to see the public of France participate in the referendum which was held on 20 September and to see just how close that vote to support the Maastricht Treaty on the unity of Europe was. Most of the resistance appeared to come from the farming community of France.

The delegation also had the opportunity of speaking with members of the Council of Europe, which is an intergovernmental organisation comprising 26 member states. Its aims are to protect pluralist democracy and human rights, to seek solutions to society's problems and to promote the emergence of a genuine European cultural identity. The most important thing in our discussions was that we were able to debate amendments to the provisional report in reply to the report on the activities of the OECD in 1991. We discussed a number of issues relating to the common agricultural policy which Australia supported, including finishing the Uruguay Round of GATT talks as quickly as possible.

The Australian delegation was in fact able to discuss those draft recommendations which sought to maintain the subsidies and protection for European primary products. We were able to have those recommendations amended so that they encouraged policy reforms which would contribute to the recognition of quality products and quality food production and ensure that consumers are better informed of the quality of those products. The amendments then became part of the report to the Council of Europe, where they will be debated and adopted by the whole Council and will be reported back to the member nations for consideration and action.

Australia has a very important role to play in the future of the common agricultural policy, particularly as it relates to Australia's exports to the European Community. At the moment European Community consumers pay between 19 per cent and 52 per cent more for their food, which is of a lower quality than and not as contaminant free as Australian food. The right approach could open up markets for superior Australian food at competitive prices, and we do have a very good record in the quality of our agricultural produce in this nation.

What I do advocate is that a three-pronged strategy should be taken to overcome the common agricultural policy. The first step includes continued discussion at a political level with the European Parliament, the Council of Europe. The next stage requires strong representations to the bureaucracy, the European Commission. The third phase would require a vigorous marketing strategy aimed at consumers. The consumers obviously do not recognise that Australia can be a very good provider of high quality food that is free of contaminants. There are some huge environmental problems throughout Europe. Australia, free from those problems, is able to supply top quality food into that market.

I was interested in the comments by the honourable member for Robertson regarding the importation of chicken from, of all places, Thailand. I have had representations on this also. Can anyone imagine chicken coming into this country from Thailand, when our poultry industry is one of the most efficient industries in this nation? It is very streamlined, and it is very efficient and productive. To allow chicken meat in here from Thailand would be an absolute disgrace. Bendigo has regrettably suffered outbreaks of avian influenza on two occasions. As a strong poultry producing area, we recognise the dangers of bringing in that type of product from areas such as Thailand.

I want to continue the comments that I made about the visit to Europe. We had the opportunity to talk to some of the consumer groups in Europe, and we met members of the European Union of Consumers. They were very supportive of removing protection and subsidies under the common agricultural policy. They recognised that Australia had a quality product to offer them. In our agricultural produce, which we could supply to the European Community and other countries throughout the world, we have a product which is free from many of the contaminants that are current in the European Community.

As we were leaving Europe, the newspaper called the European indicated that there had been an outbreak of food poisoning which had claimed at least 51 lives in France during the past six months. Authorities at that time had been unable to trace the contaminated food thought to be responsible. That indicates the seriousness of contamination and the strong position that it places Australia in. The quality of the food which we can supply to the world places Australia in a strong position in negotiations on trading with Europe and with other nations.

There have been many hiccups and highs and lows in the negotiations to bring the Uruguay Round of GATT negotiations to completion. I note the sudden resignation of agricultural commissioner Ray McSharry, his subsequent reinstatement, and the powerful position that Jaques Delors, the President of the European Commission, has been playing in that role. I think that it is getting back on track again. I note with some interest that Mr McSharry has in fact been reinstated as the agricultural commissioner and Jaques Delors is taking a back seat in the negotiations. One would hope that now the negotiations can be continued with the United States on its export enhancement program and other issues, including oil seeds. I trust that these negotiations will be carried out satisfactorily, so that agricultural protection can be reduced. That would enable Australia to participate in a world trading situation with countries throughout the world, particularly Europe.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no doubt that the principles and the thinking behind the motion put forward by the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) are correct. There is no doubt that any steps taken by the European Community to reduce its protection of its agricultural products can only be good for Australia. Also, reduction in protection to agricultural industries in other countries, including the US, can only be good for Australia.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that the European Community and the US, in reducing their level of protection on agriculture, will give great benefits to Australian producers. The latest round of GATT talks has been going on for six years now with the intention of reducing protection in agriculture, but as yet there have been no remarkable successes in those talks.

Whether the proposal by the European Community farm Ministers gets up in the GATT talks is still very much in doubt. It has been strongly opposed, especially by the French, and recent reports indicate that there is potential for a complete breakdown in the talks. Some onlookers to the talks are predicting a world trade war. Such a trade war would, no doubt, have major detrimental effects on Australian producers.

The Australian Government has led a strong and vigorous fight over the six years of those talks. Australia was instrumental in forming the Cairns Group in 1986, a group of nations which has led the fight for more liberal trade in that time. There have been successes, but the threat the European Community poses to our trade is real and must be challenged strongly and effectively by this Government.

In watching the commentary on the latest crisis, I notice a singular lack of goodwill and understanding by European Community commentators for the Australian point of view. That is why I think the approach of this motion is wrong. In my view, the people of Australia would not want this Parliament offering what I see as weak platitudes to the European countries. We should not be welcoming what the European Community has done; we should be continually fighting for a better deal as we have done in the past.

We should be pointing out to the consumers in the countries of Europe that they are paying through the nose for their agricultural products and they are suffering because of the political decisions of their governments. We should be pointing out that our farm products are better and cleaner than those of Europe and that the absolutely stupid protection levels of the Europeans are hurting people all over the world, and that they are detrimental to an efficient and a sustainable world trade economy. The answers are not to be found in kowtowing to the Europeans and thanking them for a few crumbs; that is not the Australian way. We should be continuing to fight as forcefully as we can and as we have done in the past.

The misinterpretation by the honourable member for Parkes of the correct way to go about this, which is the way Australians would like this Parliament to act on this issue, is reflected in many of the policies of the Opposition. How can it come up with policies that will divide Australia and say that these are what Australians want? Do Australians really want the division that the Opposition's policies will bring? They will mean divisions in education provision, inequality in provision of health care, and policies, including industrial ones, that will create division amongst Australians. That division will lead to inefficient industries that cannot compete with overseas countries. That is just as important as anything that overseas countries may do or that the GATT talks may achieve. The achievement in that area will count for little if Australians are not united and working together towards a better future.

Over the last 10 years we have seen reflected in government policy the attributes that Australians have become famous for, such as sticking up for the underdog, helping your mates and unselfishness. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) makes those sorts of comments because this debate then becomes an internal political debate. I commend the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) for moving this motion in the House. I repeat that this motion welcomes the initial steps taken by the European Community to lower its massive levels of agricultural protection and urges that the United States match these reductions in the interests of freeing up world trade in primary products.

PARA.TAB: This sort of motion in the Parliament provides us with an opportunity for both sides of the House to send a message to other nations. It ill becomes honourable members in this Parliament to debate internal politics when speaking to this type of motion. The real purpose of this debate is to argue our case as a nation in a bipartisan manner to the world on some fundamental principles.

The world is now a global community. This has been argued in the environmental sense quite extensively over the last decade. But we are now also a global economic community. It is on this basis that Australia has established its credentials with the Uruguay Round and the GATT talks. The world would be a better place were we to have none of the barriers—the subsidies and other initiatives that governments take—in the European Common Market and the United States. Total world trade in primary products would be better. We are arguing a case that will benefit the world, not just Australia. It is important that we debate that issue and argue that case vigorously and firmly as a parliament—not as the Labor Party, the Liberal Party or the National Party.

We should again congratulate the honourable member for Parkes for moving this motion in the Parliament. It provides a focus for the ambassadors and embassies and for the people who watch this Parliament so that they know our view on this matter. It is very interesting that each year the European Community spends more money on its cows than half the world's population has in disposable income. Quite frankly, that is a disgrace. We want a community in which we can live together. But when we look at the policies put in place by the European Community, we find that it is actually spending more on its cows than half the world's population has in disposable income.

This argument is all about utilising the total human and natural resources in the world in the most efficient and effective way. Yet we find that in this day and age—in the 1990s—we have a large community in the world spending more on its cows than half the world's people have in disposable income.

This is not just a debate about what helps Australia; it is also a debate about the total world. In this respect, starvation and famine are not merely the result of overpopulation; they result from problems related to the distribution of food and the selfish agricultural policies of some of the First World countries. There is a global commitment which we have as an Australian community.

I believe firmly and vigorously that the world would be a better place and there would be a better distribution of goods, particularly in the agricultural area, if we freed up our trade policies around the world. There would be more trade and more people would have higher living standards. We argue the case in this Parliament so that we can pursue a global objective which will benefit everybody in the world. I commend this motion and I trust that changes will occur in the GATT rounds. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be able to join in this debate. Like all members in this chamber, I was extremely disappointed when the most recent negotiations to finally bring an end to the Uruguay Round of GATT foundered, apparently through the intransigence of the French. Some internal, political considerations in France led to an attitude being taken by their negotiators which led to the negotiations not being completed. It was all the more disappointing given that, a few days beforehand, the indications coming out of the negotiations were that this round of negotiations, which seem to have been going on forever, were finally coming to some sort of a successful conclusion. I suppose it is ironic that the motion, as originally couched by the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), welcomes the initiatives taken by the European Community in calling on the United States to join in the talks when it appears, in the final analysis, that it is the Europeans who have caused the Uruguay Round to fail.

PARA.TAB: This Government has a long history of promoting the cause of free trade. We do so not through any great belief in concepts of economic rationalism or free and fair trade on level playing fields but in the belief that a range of Australian industries—particularly our major commodities, our primary industries—have very efficient producers. We also have natural advantages, a highly skilled work force in this area and good products. If we are able to get reasonable access to world markets, we can successfully sell our goods and return very good export earnings for this country. It is in our interests that world trade be free. We are not pursuing that for some mad ideological outcome; we are pursuing it because it is in our interests to achieve these ends. It has been a major thrust of the Government's trade policy to work for free world trade.

However, that does not mean that we have not also been looking at various bilateral relationships. One only has to look through the negotiations and successful agreements that have been reached between Australia and various other countries, particularly in Asia, to see that we have improved our trade on a bilateral basis. It has largely been as a result of corrupt world markets that the prices we have been receiving for our exports have been considerably depressed, even though we are exporting at record levels. That applies to a whole range of industry sectors. I think that is proof that we have been successful in gaining access for Australian products in a range of new markets.

That success would be doubled, tripled or even quadrupled if we were able to break down the insidious trade barriers and subsidy programs which are being practised, principally by the European Community and responded to by the United States. We do not have the capacity to attempt to match the sorts of subsidies that are being given out by much larger countries. It is pointless to think that we can go down that path. An alternative is to try to put in place very high trade barriers to prevent goods from getting access to our markets. But, at the end of the day, that will achieve us nothing in terms of being able to sell our goods overseas and earn export dollars. I think the Government is beholden, given that the chances are that the Uruguay Round will drag on for some considerable time—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member may have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

PARA.TAB: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleary Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about the Kennett Government. During his rather hysterical speech on the Victorian strike the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) accused the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of scaling Himalayan heights of hyperbole, but by the end of his own diatribe the honourable member for Bennelong was head down in a hill of beans. So far removed from the experiences of ordinary people is he that he still thinks John Halfpenny only has to click his fingers and 100,000 people will appear on the streets. Throw in Wally Curran and Jennie George and add Kirner and Cain for flavour and we are left with that tired old conservative recipe of dimwitted workers being led by the nose up Bourke Street.

PARA.TAB: If the honourable member for Bennelong had been at the WorkCare rally last Sunday or joined the march on Tuesday he would have discovered that these were not people being led by the nose. Rather, they are people seriously concerned and angry about a calculated and vicious attack on the things that matter to them: their work and their rights. My office, down there in Wills, where 20 per cent of the work force is unemployed, is being inundated by calls from people worried about their work, their schools, their public transport and all the things they consider important to the quality of their lives. Teachers fear the loss of their jobs, and school communities are worried that schools will be closed without consultation and foresight.

At the WorkCare rally I was surrounded by people talking about taking further action and asking what they could do to force the Kennett Government to rescind its repressive legislation. They were not the kind of red-raggers and militant unionists that members of the coalition would have us believe. Some had even voted Liberal in the recent election. Now they wish they had not. All this, despite the fact that over the past decade the union movement could hardly have been more constrained. All this, despite the fact that it has been the ordinary working person who has borne the brunt of so-called economic restructuring and the recession.

The honourable member for Bennelong simply has no understanding of the real world. I do not think he even cares about what has happened to people in the real world that exists beyond the theatre of Parliament House. If he thinks ordinary people are going to be walked over he has another think coming. It is all very well for the honourable member for Bennelong, on a handsome parliamentary salary, to claim that an attack on holiday loading, penalty rates and the right of workers to organise should be tolerated without a whimper. You can bet that if his working conditions were under attack he would have the Speaker under siege.

On only one score is the honourable member for Bennelong right. The Australian people who live in Victoria, as he puts it, are not that stupid. That is why they were out on strike on Tuesday. Here we have a man, who claims to be concerned about family life and human misery, quite happy to endorse the actions of a government which did not have the courage to outline its policies prior to the election. It is intriguing how some conservatives, in the pursuit of political brownie points, shed tears over human suffering; yet when those very same people being victimised decide to take action the conservatives are quick to change their tune. Not once in his speech did the honourable member for Bennelong name those wanton speculators who took the money of ordinary people and disposed of it in the selfish, individualistic quest for personal gain.

The Labor Party in Victoria made mistakes. Even its supporters would say as much. The honourable member for Bennelong, however, cannot display the same objectivity or even-handedness. He knows which side of the bread his support is buttered on. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) chimes in accusing me of inciting class war, but not once does he acknowledge the commonly held proposition that Jeff Kennett's approach is an example of crude class politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Commonly held by whom? By you.

—Not by your mates, of course! The point has been made again and again. There was no need for the new Victorian Government to behave in this way. As Bankers Trust Australia Joint Managing Director, Rob Ferguson, pointed out in the Age yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: Cutting deficits . . . would force down profitability in the private sector and it's already low, it would force people to shed labour and that's shedding consumers as well, and it would be a self-defeating process in the short term.

The gist of Mr Ferguson's position is that we should implement spending policies. Kenneth Davidson in the Age this morning says much the same. So what does the economic genius, Mr Kennett, do? He proposes cutbacks and, to quote Davidson, `creates a crisis atmosphere which must be damaging to business and household confidence'.
