PARA.TAB: If the Prime Minister is as concerned about families and social justice as he claims to be, he should act to protect the rights of working people. A couple of weeks ago he mounted the stump at Barcaldine and romanticised about the shearers' strike and the birth of the ALP. He would know, of course, that unionists were tried and gaoled during these strikes. Jeff Kennett has the same agenda.

The Federal Government, for its part, has a responsibility to act to thwart these calculated attacks on the rights of working people. Since coming to office in 1983, the Government has twice flirted with the introduction of legislation designed to create a right to strike in Australia. In the Senate last week the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, served a timely warning when he said, `There is no right to strike in Australia'.

We need to ask why it is that after a decade of Federal Labor government there is still no right to strike in Australia. We should ask why it is that, when Australian workers move—almost always reluctantly—to defend their rights, they must expose themselves to an array of punitive laws and penalties. From sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act to actions under common law—as we saw in the 1890s, and most recently in the Dollar Sweets case—those people with the born to rule mentality have a host of laws at their disposal with which to shackle working people.

The penalties, including injunctions and huge fines, can be quite severe. So wide-ranging are the forms of prohibition that the most responsible and defensive industrial action can be challenged in the courts. As the Australian Journal of Labour Law observed in 1988:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the gradual degeneration of British labour law under the Thatcher Government, British trade unions paradoxically still enjoy a greater immunity from common law liability than do their Australian counterparts.

Under the kinds of industrial relations policies proposed by the honourable member for Bennelong, Australian workers would have much to worry about. The destruction of collective bargaining and its replacement with an individual contract system would leave individual workers defenceless and working conditions decimated. This is really what the honourable member for Bennelong means when he talks about deregulating the labour market. He is less interested in productivity gains than in cutting the real wages of the working person.

PARA.TAB: The Federal Government has had clear advice on several occasions that it has the authority and the capacity to enact legislation to rectify, or at least ameliorate, this situation. Again, as the Australian Journal of Labour Law pointed out, following the withdrawal of certain provisions of the Industrial Relations Bill in 1987—due, in the words of the then Minister for Industrial Relations, to the `hostile reception from employer groups':

SPEECH.PARA: unions in the federal jurisdiction remain wide open to. . . attack. . . by failing to address this the Hawke Government has made life very easy for the federal opposition, should they be elected, to carry out their promise to encourage the use of common law in the civil courts in appropriate cases as a means to obtaining redress for unjustified industrial action.

The Prime Minister has spoken passionately about protecting the rights and wages of working people. Rhetoric, however, is not enough. The Federal Government should do what the Left of the Party is recommending. It must pursue Federal legislative protection for workers threatened by changes in State industrial legislation and legislate to institute the right to strike and diminish the capacity of employers to use common law action against unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to deal with matters relating to Victoria, and specifically to my electorate and the level of health care which is going to be available to persons in that area, as a result of the change of government which has just taken place. I think it is fair to say that the Geelong Hospital is one of the most efficient hospitals in Victoria, and it is probably one of the most efficient in Australia. It is a tribute to the management and leadership of the hospital, by several persons over a decade, and in more recent times under the leadership of Mrs Heath, who happens to be a member of the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: Geelong Hospital has delivered health services to a community of close to 200,000 people, at a very high level and at a very low cost. The hospital has a dedicated staff who are committed to their tasks, and who depend on the hospital for their livelihoods. The reward for dedication and for leadership, and the reward Geelong receives for putting two of Mr Kroger's stooges into the State Parliament—stooges who will not do anything to look after the area—is that 80 of the people who work at the Geelong Hospital are to be sacked. The kitchen is to be closed, and a firm in Melbourne is to provide all the food for the hospital.

This is in a town where the Liberal Party spokesmen only two months ago were telling us how they were going to look after Geelong and how Mr Kennett was going to be the Minister for Geelong. Well, 80 people at the hospital know where they stand with Mr Kennett and his mate Mr Gude. Mr Gude used to represent the area until the people woke up to him and threw him out. They know where they stand with their local members and they wish to God they could get rid of them. Certainly they would not vote for them today. Eighty jobs are to go from the kitchen.

But it is worse than that. The pathology section is to be closed at the hospital and the service be available through private pathology clinics only. That means that low income earners will pay between 50 and 100 per cent more for their pathology needs than they have to pay at the moment. That is not of concern to Mr Kennett as his friends do not need that sort of support.

The outpatients clinic will be closed with the same effect on low income earners. That is of no concern to the new Government. Beds are being removed from the hospital. Remember the stories we heard only a few weeks ago about waiting lists? In the major public hospital serving the 200,000 people of Geelong there will be fewer beds available because it is the aim of the new government of Victoria to reduce the amount of nursing hours available. It is taking beds out of the wards. Then, to go as low as possible, the hospital authorities have been ordered to reduce the standard of cleaning. They are to let the wards get a little bit dirtier to save money.

That is the standard we have from the Victorian Government. It has come to office with an attitude to the law which is probably not greatly dissimilar to the attitude held by that well known gentleman who came to office in Germany in 1933. There is very little difference between him and Mr Kennett.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha.

—I notice the honourable member for Higgins laughing. He obviously supports Mr Kennett's statement that people who disagree with him will have their photographs taken. They will be filed in a Gestapo-type file, or a KGB-type file, if you like that particular reference, and when there is someone to be punished or dismissed then that photograph will be brought out and Mr Kennett, the honourable member's friend, that great democrat, will say, `He disagreed with me so therefore he must be sacked'. That is what honourable members opposite call democracy.
—You are excelling yourself in hyperbole.

—I may well be, but I do not get paid $5,000 a day to mislead people. I am here to represent ordinary people, the sorts of people honourable members opposite would not understand and would not represent unless those ordinary people paid them to do so.

PARA.TAB: It may be that Mr Kennett does not know any better but the whole of the Liberal Party in Victoria cannot be that stupid. Here we have 80 jobs in the hospital kitchen at Geelong being taken away and transferred to someone who probably made large donations to the Liberal Party's election campaign, to a person who is probably a friend of Mr Kroger. After all, we have the position of police commissioner being advertised and the person is required to subscribe to the Liberal Party's policies.

Are they the policies we saw at Camperdown? There the police were asked to cooperate with an agent provocateur to stir up problems on picket lines? Are they the sorts of policies that the police commissioner is being asked to support? The previous police commissioner not only would not comply with those policies but ultimately went to court and had to pay the costs of the Liberals' leader in Victoria, not Mr Kennett but Mr Kroger.

It is understood, and I think it is fairly obvious, that the aim of health policy in Victoria and in New South Wales is to transfer the resources of the public sector to the maximum extent possible to American interests—the private sector they call it—the people who will be fleeing America now at a great rate of knots because of the election of Mr Clinton. He has promised that the corrupt health system in the United States will be cleaned up and that a decent public hospital system and a decent public health care system, such as we have in Australia, will replace it. Those free enterprise Americans are fleeing to Australia in droves and they will be welcomed on the steps of Parliament House in Melbourne simply because they say they are private enterprise people.

Even though the Liberal Party in Melbourne is smug in its belief that the people of Geelong will not protest, I can tell honourable members that they will. It is smug in its belief that the editorial staff at the Geelong Advertiser are prisoners of the Liberal Party's public relations firms, prisoners unable to think for themselves. I tell honourable members now that I do not believe that even the Geelong Advertiser will put up with this sort of rubbish—and, coming from me, that is saying something.

I believe that the people of Geelong will protest very vigorously and very long when they find out about the hidden agenda—before the election they were told that agenda did not exist—and they will find out the policies that were not announced because the present Government of Victoria lacked the courage and the integrity to tell people what it really intended to do. They are policies designed to take away from ordinary people entitlements that they have worked for and entitlements that they should expect. These policies will have an effect not only on people in the industrial field but on the majority of people in Geelong. People in Geelong are being told that their hospital is to be a test case, that it is to be destroyed for an ideological bent and to satisfy the greed of a few people in the health care industry. Those people see that industry only as a source of revenue and not as providing care to ordinary people who, one would have thought at this stage of the twentieth century, are entitled to be treated if they are sick.

I repeat that the Geelong Hospital is one of the most efficient and lowest cost per treatment hospitals in Australia. Its efficiency is well known throughout the health care system, and for ideological reasons it is to be destroyed by a corrupt group purely for money. We now have the situation where people will have to join health funds, but they will not get any better care because the money does not go into care. They will pay more for less care, and those who cannot afford it will go back to the charity sectors of the past.

It is no coincidence that certain American firms in the health care field in Australia are proudly boasting that the Liberal Party's aged care and health policies will be written by them, in their interests and in the interests of their profits. I think it is a great thing that Bill Clinton is going to give America a health care system; it is a tragedy that Jeff Kennett is going to destroy a decent system in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 November 1992, an article appeared in the West Australian regarding the death of Penelope Easton, and part of that article quotes a press release from the relatives of Penelope Easton. The article states:

PARA.TAB: Yesterday her family said: `Due to publicity in the past week concerning allegations made under parliamentary privilege—which could not be explained for legal reasons under Family Court rules—and the stresses of a drawn-out Family Court battle, Mrs Penny Easton ended her life.

`Mrs Easton's family wish to point out that the allegations against her were totally unfounded and ignored a letter from the Commissioner of Police clearing Mrs Easton of the accusations made by her former husband, Brian Easton.
`Mrs Easton leaves behind a 13-year-old son. Her family is grieving and will make no further public comment.'

SPEECH.PARA: I think the background of this matter is worthy of my grievance here today. The circumstances and the motives behind this situation need to be exposed. This is a most tragic situation, in which a woman who had rebuilt her life after a very debilitating divorce chose to end that life due solely to her treatment as an expendable piece of flotsam in the survival of a Premier and a political party.

PARA.TAB: On 25 November 1986 the then Liberal member for Nedlands, Richard Court, raised a matter in the Western Australian Parliament relating to a WA Inc. entity called Exim and associated matters relating to its then managing director, Brian Easton, the husband of Penelope Easton. If press reports are correct, Mrs Easton, who was involved in divorce proceedings with Brian Easton, contacted Mr Court seeking information related to his statement which she wished to use in some aspect of that action. Mr Court is quoted as saying that he referred her to the public record, including, I presume, Hansard. Subsequent statements by Mr Easton admit that, notwithstanding the raising of this matter in the divorce proceedings, it eventually had no bearing on the decisions associated with that case. Nevertheless, sometime in 1989 Mr Easton raised the issue of Mr Court's involvement with the official corruption commission, which sought the assistance of the police. During 1989-90 Mr Easton was apparently informed that no case existed against Mr Court or against his wife.

Late in 1989 Carmen Lawrence, just prior to her becoming Premier, received $5,000 of public moneys to finance an overseas trip associated with her then portfolio responsibilities. She claims that, due to her elevation to Premier, she did not take the trip but forgot to return the money. A mere $5,000 floated around in her bank account for a couple of years, during which time I assume she lodged some tax returns but she was never apparently reminded of this substantial amount of money. Of course, this just adds to the record of forgetfulness that seems to be endemic in Western Australia's Premier. During the investigations of WA Inc. she has had no recollection—and this was when she was under oath—of any of her activities as a Cabinet Minister, notwithstanding that there were three very big deals approved by Cabinet, all of which have been disasters for the Western Australia taxpayer, when she was involved as a Cabinet Minister.

That stands in stark contrast with the recollection of Sir Charles Court, who was pulled into that commission, at the Government's insistence, to describe his dealings during the gas pipeline deal. He showed total recall, never forgot a thing and could produce all the documents—funnily enough, not one had got into the shredder. The royal commission found that he had acted properly. Of course, as time has gone by, that massive development has proved to be in the public interest.

The Premier could not remember writing two letters to one Robyn Greenburg, a woman who has been established as a crook. The Premier had signed them and on one occasion made notes on a draft, but she told the Parliament that she never knew the woman, so her forgetfulness is now a matter of some jocularity in Western Australia.

Some months ago the police laid charges against retired Premier Brian Burke for similar matters. This apparently jolted the Premier's attention—whether it was forgetfulness or she suddenly decided she might get caught, I do not know, but I lean towards the second one. The lady is a liar, as far as I am concerned. She apparently became aware also of direct police inquiries and the money was voluntarily returned approximately two years later.

TALK.START.PARA: —With interest?

—No interest was paid. Nevertheless, the Premier was clearly due for considerable embarrassment and a typical Labor Party style diversion was necessary. Literally years after Mr Brian Easton had been told that his complaints had no relevance, up popped Labor Legislative Councillor John Halden on 5 November 1992 with a petition on behalf of Brian Easton resurrecting the issue. This coincided with the disclosure of Premier Lawrence's dereliction of duty and forgetfulness in copping five grand she was not entitled to have and forgetting it was in her bank account—I do not know how many millions she has got in it but I can tell honourable members that $5,000 makes a pretty good bump in mine.

PARA.TAB: It is a coincidence beyond comprehension that all of a sudden an issue which was dead should be resurrected in this situation by a well-known Labor backbencher who gets himself involved in these issues. The petition attacked not only Mr Court, but also both Penelope Easton and her sister, Margaret McCauley. Margaret McCauley is a lawyer who, by coincidence, is acting on behalf of women who were defrauded by Robin Greenburg and who claimed they were directed to Robin Greenburg's services by a government organisation, the Women's Information and Referral Exchange. That is another scandal which the Premier, Carmen Lawrence, says she knows nothing about.

This petition, aimed at Richard Court, was obliged to accuse both Penelope Easton and Margaret McCauley of giving false evidence in court. It claims that Easton is a bankrupt, but I have been given oral advice that even that is not true. I have been told that he has substantial investments which he is benefiting from.

On Friday, 6 November, a few hours after the tabling of this petition on behalf of Mr Halden, a press secretary, Mr Darren Ray, who was attached to the Labor MP, Jackie Watkins, offered media interests direct interviews with Mr Brian Easton on this matter. And the Labor Party says it was just a coincidence!

This is further evidence of the conspiracy involving the Premier, Carmen Lawrence, in a matter that brought about the death of a woman who had had it tough enough as it was. Penelope Easton had been through a debilitating divorce action. During that particular situation she had sought to protect her interests. She had sought evidence that she had read on the public record—statements which had been made in parliament about the concerns that the Liberal Party had at that time for what has become one of the greatest financial and political scandals in Australia.

We are asked to believe that this was not a set-up, that it was not planned and that the Premier of Western Australia did not conspire with John Halden for the purpose of his raising this matter in parliament on the day. It may be of interest to see the result they achieved. Here we have the Premier guilty of having in a bank account the amount of $5,000 that she should have returned two years ago, and here we have Richard Court, who had been previously exonerated and, of course, the charges would never have had substance.

The simple fact is that I charge the Premier with conspiring, and in a way that has caused a woman to commit suicide. I challenge her to go before some appropriate authority, presumably the Chief Justice of Western Australia, and sign a statutory declaration to say that she had no knowledge. She is the type of person who probably could do it, but there is a chance at least that lightning might then strike her dead.

It is a disgraceful situation. It is one for which the whole Labor Party must take the blame. It is clearly a conspiracy to try to protect the Premier, and she is up to her eyebrows in it. Of course, Halden will just have to live with it. Penelope Easton took her own life and, according to her family, she took it because of the massive pressures on her and because of the direct attack on her that was necessary to make the thing have any substance. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to speak about a part of an Australian industry which I think is badly in need of some micro-economic and social reform—that is, the advertising industry. In particular, I want to refer to an advertising campaign launched last week by the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation aimed at encouraging Australians to holiday in Queensland, which is of course a very laudable aim.

PARA.TAB: This campaign is described as the `Yo! Way to Go' campaign, and it has attracted some immediate controversy. The first controversy was over the hijacking of American phraseology and American culture. The second, and probably the harshest criticism levelled at the campaign, was the way in which it portrayed women. There were two controversial scenes in the commercial. The first depicted a close-up of a woman wearing a G-string being sprayed with suntan oil. The second showed a woman being pinched on the behind. Upon being pinched, the woman turns around, smiles and shakes her finger in mock accusation at an unidentified male.

After a day of public debate, criticism from the State Women's Policy Unit and direct intervention by the Premier and the tourism Minister, the advertising agency concerned was told to remove the two controversial scenes.Clearly, the images contravened the Queensland Government's own stop violence against women policy, part of which obliges the Government to ensure that its own media advertisements are free of sex role stereotypes.

It has been interesting to follow the course of this story over the weeks since the ads were launched. Despite being told to clean up their act, the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation and the advertising agency concerned have been completely unrepentant.

The QTTC Chairman, Mr Peter Laurance, accused the State Government of being `hypersensitive' to what he intriguingly described as `women's issues' and `many other minority groups'. It may have passed Mr Laurance's attention that women are not really a minority, since they constitute more than 50 per cent of the Australian population. Asked to comment on the bottom pinching incident, he likened the action to `holding hands' or `kissing in the corner' or `winking at your girlfriend'. He is apparently unaware of the laws in this country dealing with assault, not to mention various sex discrimination legislation across the country. Having dismissed the controversy as being both absurd and ridiculous, Mr Laurance took comfort in the fact that at least the ads had not been criticised for being bland and unnoticed. In his opinion, the controversy ensured that the campaign would be a success before it had even been officially launched.

The General Manager of the QTTC, Mr Ken Rosebury, was similarly unrepentant about the whole thing, stating that the offending scene had been removed in the interests of keeping the peace. Like Mr Laurance, he considered that the main objective was for the ads to stand out, so that they sold Queensland to southern tourists. I do not know whether it is exactly the way in which many people want Queensland to be portrayed, but I certainly will concede that the ads have stood out.

The advertising agency responsible for this campaign is the company known as Mojo, which I think is fairly well known in the advertising business throughout Australia. It said that the ads were quite okay in its view and reflected real life. When one sees the models in the ads, one might wonder how many Australians actually look so glamorous, taut, trim and terrific. Unfortunately, some of us do not quite meet that ideal, and I do not really know how much the ads reflect real life. I know there are some honourable members present who always fit that model, with their splendid dress sense! The QTTC adopted the old show business adage that any publicity is good publicity.

There are some interesting insights to be gained from this whole debate. There have been some fairly significant social changes in Australia which do not seem to have penetrated the minds of many advertising executives or the advertising agencies in this country. Probably the most significant change is that, over the last few decades, the number of women aged 15 or over who are now engaged in the paid work force has grown from 42 per cent to 52 per cent—that is, a majority of Australian women are in paid work. Research has shown that these changes in the participation rate have very much changed the perceptions of how women view themselves and other women.

But whilst these changes have had significant implications for advertising, it seems that many agencies seek to ignore them. Research by Saulwick, Weller and Associates in 1987 found that as many as one in seven television ads showed scantily clad females; one in 10 used sex to promote a product; and one in 20 featured women whose clothing was considered inappropriate for the product advertised.

Of course, there are some exceptions to the rule. One of the best examples, I believe, is the ads run by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation featuring their short cuts product. I think that honourable members may be familiar with the sorts of images portrayed by those ads, which are very much in stark contrast to the sort of 1960s style of ads now being run in Queensland for the Tourist and Travel Corporation in the `Yo! Way to Go' series.

The real test of an ad's effectiveness is the response of the consumer. In this regard, opinion polling suggests that the advertising industry still has a fair way to go. In 1989 a major survey of Australian women showed that half of them thought advertisers should use models who are more like real-life people, 74 per cent objected to ads which show women in skimpy clothing, and almost a quarter said they would boycott a product if they did not like the advertisement for it. The same survey found that the three most common words used to describe the depiction of women in ads were `glamorous' by 76 per cent, `thin' by 75 per cent and `sexually available' by 59 per cent. Similar research was conducted by Julie Bailey of Griffith University last year. She found that 87 per cent of Australian women think that ads show women as valued for sex at least some of the time, and 86 per cent think that it is far too often.

Such polling reflects an increasing consumer irritation with the way in which women are portrayed in advertising. Australia is not alone in this regard. In 1983 a review of opinion polling in the United States on sex stereotyping found that a majority of consumers felt that advertising was insulting to women, and this in turn affected women's purchasing patterns. We should remember that women on the whole are responsible for major purchasing in Australia; yet again this fact does not seem to have seeped in to the minds of many advertising agencies. The United States research concluded that certain ads alienated female viewers, resulting in fewer sales and greater public criticism of the advertising industry.

I do not have much cause in this House to agree with the comments being put forward by National Party figures, particularly the Leader of the Opposition in Queensland, Mr Borbidge, but on this occasion I am in agreement with him. Mr Borbidge has argued that the Queensland Government should have taken much stronger action against the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation over this particular series of ads. Mr Laurance is responsible for the campaign. I object to the ads, and Mr Laurance's response after the criticism was made has led me to have very little confidence in him. I agree with Mr Borbidge that he should be removed from his position.

It is not good enough that we rely on the same old stereotypes of decades ago. There really should be some close thought on the part of the advertising agencies in this country about the sorts of messages that they are portraying. If there is a case for a major shake-up of an industry to get some proper reform into it and bring it up to modern day attitudes in the way in which it is making its products, I think that the Australian advertising industry would be a prime candidate for such scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to participate in the grievance debate, I commend the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) on the speech he has just delivered and the observation he has made. I reassure him that, while he has successfully emptied the gallery during his address, I would not want him to think that it was because it was in any way uninteresting or that he had only titillating material and a poor delivery. In fact, I thought that the content of his speech warranted the attention of us all.

PARA.TAB: The one thing that has distressed me in today's grievance debate has been that no-one from the Government has dealt with what I think should be the one subject causing us all most distress on this day. That is the fact that today the unemployment figures indicate that we have reached a postwar record level of 11.3 per cent or, measured in terms of male unemployed, an astonishing 11.9 per cent of males out of work, with the total figure conservatively estimated at barely short of one million people.

For all that, day in and day out, members of the Government claim to be the people with a monopoly on concern about unemployment and concern about social justice, it does us well to note that today it has not as yet been dealt with by any of the Government speakers opposite—though I concede to the next speaker that it may be. I am not claiming for a moment that the Opposition has a monopoly on concern for the unemployed but I do believe that, with all that the Opposition has done to build a package for an alternative direction for Australia, the criticism that can be levelled at the Government is that that package has met with nothing but scorn and derision.

I rise, as the parent of teenage children, to speak of my concern about the direction that our nation is taking and about the job opportunities that my children are going to face. If I, as someone who is in a relatively secure, well-paid job, am concerned and, if the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), as the parent of non-teenage children is concerned, how much more concerned is every unemployed Australian or every parent who has children about to go from school into the job queues likely to be about this 11.3 per cent? It is not just the unemployment that we are worried about, it is the fact that there is no light on the horizon and little sense of opportunity for any one of those young people.

I think the Government has poured far too much scorn and derision on the alternative plans offered by the Opposition. For almost 10 years, I have been a member of Her Majesty's loyal Opposition; it is too long.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand that.

—I am happy to pick up the comment made by my colleague opposite. I did a quick survey of Government members—the honourable member who was interjecting is one of the exceptions—and I found that only a quarter of the members of the Government were in government when I entered the Parliament in 1983. Therefore, only a quarter of them understand the desperation felt by people in opposition who want to get out of opposition into government.

PARA.TAB: We do not want to be here, we want to be on the other side. If that is the case, every parliamentarian and every Australian should ask themselves why an opposition, desperate to win government, would hand down a package that was as frankly unpopular and lacking in pragmatism as the Fightback package is. Why hand down a package that the Government could, if it wanted to in a cheap and unproductive way, pour scorn and derision on? If we are to be a responsible, alternative government, we have no choice. We cannot continue as a nation while our overseas debt continues to rise—it is sitting at $160 billion or $170 billion dollars, depending on how we calculate it. We cannot continue in the present direction, with unemployment at 11.3 per cent and productivity falling.

For that reason, the Opposition has said that the nation needs a new direction—popular or unpopular. We have handed down specific detailed proposals to change the tax regime, to change the industrial relations regime and to provide real opportunities for transport and waterfront reform. We have not done it by pretending that everything the Government does is wrong. Take the issue of tariff reform, for example: we have agreed with the Government on that. It would have been much easier, much more popular and much more pragmatic to have disagreed with the Government, but we have chosen the unpopular course of agreeing with it.

What has been the response from the Government to this package? Nothing but misrepresentation, scorn, and derision. In the debate that preceded this grievance debate, the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) accused the Opposition of, of all things, being simplistic with its solutions. Simplistic! He then went on to say that under the Opposition's package bread will go up in price by 15 per cent and Ferraris will come down. Such a simplistic misrepresentation of our package as that is without parallel. The reality, of course, is that foodstuffs do not go up 15 per cent. There will certainly be a goods and services tax applied, but its effect will not be to increase the cost of foodstuffs or essentials by 15 per cent. The goods and services tax will be offset by the removal of seven other presently existing taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that that is not right.

—I know that it is absolutely true. Furthermore, let me remind the Parliamentary Secretary that the seven existing taxes currently collected by his Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) tally something like $35 billion and that the taxes collected under a GST will, as conceded by his Prime Minister (Mr Keating), tally something like $27 billion. The Opposition commits itself to collecting $8 billion less in taxation; commits itself to tax cuts of 30 per cent; commits itself to doubling the family allowance; commits itself to raising pensions and government benefits; and tries to put—contrary to the popular image created by those opposite—a real focus on social justice by ensuring, for example, in the health area, that a greater penalty is put on those on higher incomes than those on lower incomes.

PARA.TAB: More than that, concerned about productivity, the Opposition deliberately goes about taking the tax burden off business to pick up the very unemployed people who make up today's 11.3 per cent figure. The Government says, `Let us look at the way we employ people', and this grievance debate has been dominated by people critical of the Victorian experience. We are not planning to parallel the Victorian experience; we are saying that under our industrial relations proposal awards would be retained but we would allow people to negotiate outside the awards.

I am surprised that the House is indignant of this. My own background is in the citrus industry. I can employ people to pick citrus fruits either on an hourly basis or on a contract basis. They come to me and want to work on a contract basis. Why? The job is not easier; it is because, frankly, they can earn more as they produce more, and have a greater sense of fulfilment at the end of the day.

So what do we offer? We offer that sense of choice and with it the opportunity for additional job creation and the opportunity to soak up some of that 11.3 per cent unemployed. What have we had from those opposite for all of our package? Derision, based, they say, on the New Zealand experience. I was in New Zealand, and I sat down and spoke to PDL Industries. PDL has a factory which makes electrical fittings in Christchurch and in Melbourne. In Christchurch, its oncosts are 17c in the dollar; in Melbourne, its oncosts are 53c in the dollar. As the manager of PDL said to us, `Where do you think we are going to put in the additional shift; where do you think the opportunity for job creation is going to exist?'. It is going to exist in Christchurch and not in Melbourne—or not in the Melbourne that existed prior to the election of the Kennett Government, anyway.

We in the Opposition propose a package deliberately designed to give people job opportunities and to soak up that 11.3 per cent. We have not pretended that we have some magic wand that will solve all unemployment, but we have a deliberate sense of direction that gives people hope, gives people opportunity, gives people a sense of purpose and gives the nation a chance to produce more exports and relieve its crippling debt, largely run up in the last 10 years under this Administration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up some of the points made by my colleague the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). I too recently returned from overseas. The Western world is going through a worldwide recession. Those countries which have the equivalent of the coalition's promise of a GST have as many problems as face the present Government in Australia: unemployment rates are high; misery and pain abound. The Opposition says that all that is going to be solved by adopting a tax proposal which has already been adopted and tried in places such as England and other parts of Europe. It does not solve the problems of unemployment and it does not solve the situation which faces so many people.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that, given the agony and the pain that also exist in the United States of America where there are large numbers of unemployed, the first thing that the President-elect, Mr Clinton, proposes to do is to hold a summit in order to involve the American people and American leadership in the kind of hard decisions that have to be made to turn the American economy around.

It is my deep regret that in my home State of Victoria, where a change of government meant that that was an option which should have been available to the Premier, that did not occur. I do not have any doubt at all about the capacity of the average Victorian to tighten his belt and to make some level of sacrifice to get his State moving again. There was an opportunity for the newly elected Premier to show some sense of statesmanship to unite the Victorian community on the basis of understandings and a sharing equally of the burdens that have to be faced in getting the Victorian economy moving again. But what we have seen is an exercise in industrial confrontation from a government that could not wait to give itself its own pay increases, its own additional benefits, while taking away from average workers in Victoria hard won rights, hard won benefits, and at the same time promising to proscribe their defence of those rights, their defence of their working entitlements, by proscribing them in terms of the criminal law. The result, of course, was that we saw some 100,000 people marching on the streets of Melbourne. What is interesting is that the Age poll showed that on that day of the strike people were more concerned about the loss of their democratic rights than the attack on their hip pocket nerve.

When these proposals were first made, there was some sign that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who carries the responsibility for the Opposition in dealing with industrial matters, and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) were distancing themselves from those actions of the Kennett Government, as in my view they should have. But it is sad that we then saw what I regard as a sleazy attack on fellow Australian citizens in this Parliament when speaker after speaker on behalf of the Opposition and the honourable member for Bennelong, with the support of his Leader, simply characterised those 100,000 people out on the streets as being manipulated by some trade union leaders.

I do not know whether they genuinely believe that. It has been my experience over many years in both Victorian and Federal politics that, for every person who marches, there will be another three or four who, for personal reasons, will not participate in the march but will have great sympathy. Let me take the judgment of two independent journalists, who are not Labor Party sympathisers—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they from the Age?

—Every time the honourable member opens his mouth he puts his golden foot in it. I do not expect him to understand this and I do not expect him to have any sympathy at all for those 100,000 people, who were described in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: What struck me about this rally was the restraint, the determination and, yes, the respectability. It is a very peculiar mutiny that brings forward detachments from the zoo, the Public Records Office and the National Gallery.
And another comment:

I do not know how many thousands of Victorian men and women marched the Collins-Elizabeth-Bourke Street protest circuit yesterday. I do know that Mr Kennett risks grave political and economic jeopardy if he tries to ignore it.
That is a salient comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which newspaper?

—It does not matter which newspaper. What the honourable member for Gippsland wants to ignore is that two archbishops—I do not know how he would characterise them—have already indicated that they regard the right to strike as part of the inherent fabric of a democratic community. The only time I have ever heard the honourable member for Gippsland or some of the other gentlemen opposite support the concept of the right to strike was when Lech Walesa jumped the fence at the Gdansk shipyards and Solidarity was born, and the trade union movement fought to establish its right to bring democracy into Poland.

PARA.TAB: Do honourable members opposite seriously believe that legislation can be introduced which criminalises actions which have been part of the inherent birthright of every Australian citizen, and that the living standards of the Australian people can be attacked in this way? I think it has to be conceded that clearly the Premier—and the Victorian Government—did not think his way through this concept. In one fell swoop with his initial legislative package, he sacked an entire jurisdiction of judges, who had been appointed for life to the Workers Compensation Board in Victoria.

Fortunately, saner counsel seems to have prevailed and members of the legal profession, including prominent members of the Liberal Party, pointed out to him that one cannot go around attacking the judiciary and one cannot go around sacking judges who have been appointed for life. So there has been another attitude adopted, and I am pleased that there has been that change. But equally, in the same action, the Victorian Government originally proposed to take away from a worker the right to sue in tort for damages for negligence if he is injured in a serious industrial accident where he has to prove in our courts that the action was due to the negligence of the employer. That has also been reconsidered as a result of representations from the legal profession.

At the same time, the Premier produces legislation that says the same worker, if he exercises his right to industrial action, can be sued in tort for an unlimited and unspecified set of damages. The problems of Australia will not be solved, nor will the problems of Victoria be solved, by dividing the community into those who have and those who have not, by bringing in legislation which does not belong to contemporary Australian society but is a regression back to those days when there was a wealthy class and a class basically without rights—an underclass.

I do not want to see, and I do not believe any honourable member of this House wants to see, the creation of a new underclass in Australia but that is the trap that we are in great danger of falling into. It is not good enough for honourable members opposite for reasons of political prejudice to look at decent honest Australians, the sons of those who were Anzacs, the sons of those who fought for this country—and the daughters—and say that their perceptions of their rights are any less than the rights that their fathers fought for. I would hope that, if this coalition is serious about industrial relations, it will use its influence to persuade the Premier of Victoria that the course that he is embarking upon not only is divisive but also will destroy any potential for the Victorian economy to recover and at the same time will do great damage to the Australian economy. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to bring to the attention of the House a matter which has arisen in my electorate of Gippsland which bears on the application of the Family Law Act and which raises serious questions as to the Act's capacity to ensure the Family Court exercises its powers fairly and justly in all its dealing in disputes between citizens. I fully realise the strictures imposed on me by way of section 112 of the Family Law Act in addressing this matter publicly. For this reason, I will have to beg the House's indulgence if I refrain from identifying the relevant parties by name, although I hasten to add that my constituent would gladly allow his name to be publicly broadcast, to give an even more human dimension to his tragic circumstances. Frustratingly for him, the Family Law Act prevents him telling his story in a media which demands personal identification in stories such as I am about to outline.

PARA.TAB: Naturally, I would concede that there is no more difficult area in which to exercise legislative or legal authority than in regard to the relationships that exist between men and women in the community. Any institutional mechanism for intervening in and overseeing divorce proceedings, the disposal of property between parties in personal conflict and, most important of all, for assigning custodial rights in respect of children as a consequence of marital breakdowns or the dissolution of long standing relationships, is destined for a hard road. Yet the circumstances of one of my own constituents in Gippsland does require that the legislative process give closer regard to the operation of the Family Law Act.

In 1986 my constituent married a woman of South African-Indian descent, a result of a relationship which was born of a chance meeting when both were travelling in India earlier in that year. Together with my constituent's wife's daughter from a previous relationship, the couple lived in East Gippsland over the course of 1985 and late into 1986. During this period, the couple had a son.

Regrettably, the relationship between my constituent and his wife deteriorated over the period to late 1986, and the couple subsequently separated. Almost immediately following separation, there were numerous applications for access and custody lodged with the Court with respect to the children. Restraining orders were also invoked to ensure that the son, who was an Australian citizen, would not be removed from Australia. A subsequent order was made to this end, by consent, in February 1987.

As of April 1988, orders were again made by consent that both parties would share joint guardianship of the children, whilst the mother would hold custody. These orders detailed access arrangements, including access to South Africa, and placed close restrictions on the son's travel to South Africa, the original homeland of my constituent's late wife.

Further disputation followed in December concerning allegations that the orders affecting access had been violated and my constituent's wife was in contempt of court. In that same month, my constituent filed for sole custody of the two children. Three years later, after the separation, in the heat of the custodial battle, allegations were made that my constituent had interfered with his step-daughter. These allegations were never pursued to any extent and were not given any marked weight in the subsequent hearings of the Family Court. Similar allegations were later made that my constituent had molested his young son. These allegations were also never proven and were clearly viewed by the Court as having something far less than primary essential significance.

In a tragic turn of events, my constituent's wife died as a result of a car accident in February 1991. Custody of both children was transferred in the interim to my constituent's wife's mother, who had journeyed from South Africa in the sad event of her daughter's death.

The final Court judgment was handed down in the latter half of 1991, and custody of both children was transferred to their grandmother. Subsequently, my constituent's son who, I would remind the House, is and remains an Australian citizen—along with his half-sister, with whom, as I understand, he has little affinity—returned to South Africa in the company of his grandmother.

The Court's order, it should be noted in this regard, permitted my constituent access to his son, and the grandmother was required to enter a bond to ensure the orders were fulfilled to the Court's satisfaction. Tragically, my constituent has now found that he is unable to enforce the Australian Court orders in respect of access to his son in South Africa, as the South African courts do not respect foreign court orders. In order to gain access to his son, my constituent is now pursuing very expensive legal avenues for redress through the South African court system.

Several important queries arise out of this judgment, to which I would wish to draw the House's attention. Before doing so, I would hasten to point out that the concerns I will shortly raise are not simply applicable to a specific case before the courts. They bear, instead, on very much wider matters and ought to be considered as issues of principle against which the authority of the Family Court should be appropriately reviewed.

Firstly, I question whether the Family Court should be empowered to permit the person who has been awarded custody to remove the child permanently from the country of which the child is a citizen, especially when the judgment included access provisions for the other parent remaining in Australia. This point is of even greater significance when it is understood that the Court allowed the guardian to remove the child, an Australian citizen, from Australia to a country in which its own orders in respect of custody could not be enforced.

What might be the logic of such a determination by the Family Court? Is this a practice to which the Parliament would happily accede, especially if it means the effective forfeiture of a child's citizenship? On what basis of law or other principle can the Family Court, through its determinations, effectively transfer a child's citizenship?

Secondly, is it a legitimate practice that a child should effectively be removed from the custody of his or her only surviving natural parent and placed in the custody of a very much older relative with whom the child has next to no acquaintance? The importance of this point cannot be underestimated. My constituent's son is now required, as a six-year-old and an Australian citizen, to adapt to a lifestyle in a foreign country, in a community and within a broader culture with which he has little familiarity. In addition, he is now living in a so-called family environment which provides few, if any, of the essential interactions we would expect of a normal childhood.

Thirdly, are such decisions as these by the Family Court reached on a thorough assessment of the suitability of the environment into which the child is to be placed? I raise this point because the locality in which my constituent's son is presently required to live is not only emotionally deprived but also politically unstable and potentially violent. It affords a lifestyle and an educational environment which, on the evidence before me, would not be tolerated in Australia. This is the point of concern. The Family Court ostensibly reached its verdict on the basis of the familial and social environment in which the child's welfare would be best served. But what is the working requirement on the Court to investigate the actual environment to which the child is being relocated as opposed to the representations of that environment which are made before the Court?

In the case I refer to, it needs to be investigated whether the Court should undertake a detailed analysis of the conditions to which the child was being transferred prior to making a determination to this end. Honourable members with experience in the law know well that the legal system works well when it is right, but something less so when it is believed to be in error. It is incumbent on the legal process to constantly seek to improve its operation, to scrutinise its weaknesses and improve on its administration. Family law is no different from any other branch of law in this regard.

I, for one, am tired of the prevailing mood of the judiciary, and even of the legislature, that the Family Law Act is so sacrosanct that to dare question its judgments is tantamount to contempt of court. The judgments of every other court are intensely examined and debated, and judges at times are criticised, but not the Family Court. An Australian citizen can be sent out of Australia and away from his father to totally unsuitable surroundings and there is nothing he can do about it. Any application of commonsense in this judgment would conclude that the child should not have been sent to South Africa. He is an Australian citizen, for heaven's sake, with family here.

I am pleased that the Parliament has sought a review of the operation of the Family Law Act through the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Interpretation and Operation of the Family Law Act, but the terms of reference are very narrow. I have brought these and related concerns to the Committee's attention in greater detail than I have outlined in the short time available to me today. I hope the Committee addresses the matters of principle I have raised in this report. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —On a day such as today when the latest unemployment figures have just revealed a substantial jump in the number of people actively looking for work in Australia, it is opportune to remind my constituents and the people living in the Illawarra region of some of the underlying

SPEECH.PARA: reasons why these unemployment concerns continue to arise and of some of the remedies that are being put in place by a community that has always been prepared to get in and fight and to try to assist itself.

PARA.TAB: I remind honourable members that, whenever we talk about micro-economic reform and structural adjustments and so on, what that normally translates into is simply sacking people and in that way reducing costs to business. In the case of the major employer in the Illawarra, BHP, and other employers in the area, the coalmines and so on, since 1983 we have seen a major structural adjustment take place in our area to the extent that, whereas in 1983 there were 23,000 people directly employed in the steel industry, that figure is now 7,500 and it is set to go down even further. In the coal industry some 3,000 coalminers have lost their jobs. But productivity has gone up, new equipment has been put in place and the steel industry and the coal industry on the south coast in fact have been saved from extinction.

At the present moment we have the lowest interest rates in a generation and we have inflation running at less than one per cent. In such an environment as this, why is business not taking advantage and trying to look at ways in which it can reinvest in jobs for the future of those people who are long term unemployed, as well as the younger generation coming through? As I said earlier, in the Illawarra we are prepared to get in and have a go. I am pleased to be able to tell the House that in the last couple of years, and in the last six months in particular, some major announcements have been made by various people in the private sector, as well as in the public sector, that are going to assist in the economic recovery in the Illawarra.

For example, the Illawarra Retirement Trust, a magnificent organisation providing retirement village accommodation for our senior citizens, announced recently that it would construct a major multi-storey retirement village in the centre of Wollongong. It has also announced the intention to construct another one of similar dimensions in Kiama and is putting the finishing touches on another in Tarrawanna. The boost that will give is valued at many millions of dollars in terms of the construction industry, and it also means that ongoing jobs for carers and so on will be created in the region. We have also had McDonalds, a much maligned food chain, I might say, deciding to construct two new McDonalds stores in the Illawarra. That means that many jobs—agreed, part time jobs—will be provided for young people. That provides them with an income which they might not otherwise have had.

We have had the Commonwealth Government, our Government, make a major announcement that a regional tax office is to be constructed in central Wollongong, with 275 permanent jobs to be created, after the construction has injected $20m into the building industry. We have had the decision taken by this Government to construct the hydrographic office in the Illawarra and transfer the staff from North Sydney, creating over 110 jobs and injecting an additional $12.5m into a regional economy that desperately wants it. Yet the decision is opposed by those opposite.

We have had the announcement by Esso that it is proposing to invest quite considerable millions of dollars in a new construction process at Port Kembla, building platforms for oil rigs which will then be towed down to the Bass Strait. We have had over $7.5m injected through the local capital works program, particularly through Wollongong City Council, with jobs being created immediately but, more importantly, long term projects being put in place.

There are many other proposals on the drawing board. There are an indoor sports centre and an additional grandstand at Steelers Stadium, where next year's rugby league premiers will be presiding. A new synthetic athletics track is to be constructed; that work will commence in the next couple of weeks. We have expansion at the University of Wollongong, where again the Commonwealth Government, the Keating Government, has put money into the construction of major buildings to accommodate the needs of students. There is also consideration being given to a major new shipbuilding proposal at the port of Port Kembla when the Esso project and the use of the old casting basin is complete.

The Illawarra knows what it is like in difficult times. We have been in difficult times since the 1983 recession and yet what we are prepared to do is to get in and fight and go out and drag people down to the Illawarra, show them how good a place it is and convince them that they can invest in that area.

I would say to any other potential investors out there, whether it would be in the tourism industry or other industries, that there are opportunities for them in the Illawarra. Yesterday there were a lot of Americans out here with pension funds—many billions of dollars—who are looking for places to invest in. I could point them in no better direction than the Illawarra. It provides an excellent living environment and working environment, and I would commend it to them.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:
That grievances be noted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to congratulate the Buchanan Aircraft Corporation in my electorate for achieving another milestone in its contractual work for the Australian Submarine Corporation in Adelaide. Last Monday saw the shipment from Toowoomba of the first set of composite hull casings for the six Collins class submarines being built in Adelaide. This is a unique achievement in engineering, commercial and transportation terms by the fledgling Buchanan Aircraft Corporation, which is establishing itself as a dependable contractor in the high-tech and untested area of composite plastics. It says much for local ingenuity and precision engineering.

PARA.TAB: Buchanan's work force has trebled over the last two years, to a point where 55 local employees are now involved in this important $12m contract. I congratulate John Buchanan and his work force for a job well done in a difficult economic climate. I wish them continuing success in an enterprise that is very important both in local and national terms. Buchanan Aircraft Corporation and its workers can hold their heads high. They are important contributors to our enhanced national defence industrial infrastructure which is so important to our strategic circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with much pleasure that I bring to the attention of the honourable members of this House today the fact that my electorate of Port Adelaide, and in particular the port of Port Adelaide, will be establishing a submarine cove with the Navy's submarine HMAS Ovens as its centrepiece. The corporation of the City of Port Adelaide first came up with the idea through one of its able officers, John Drennan. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) and I worked long and hard to convince the Government to support the plan.

PARA.TAB: HMAS Ovens was launched in Scotland in 1967. It has had a long and distinguished record of service in the Royal Australian Navy, including assignment to the ANZUK force in Singapore in 1972. It is only fitting that it should spend its final days as a living museum and not be broken up and sold for scrap.

I say with a fair degree of pride that in Port Adelaide we are indeed fortunate to have a submarine cove, and in it the submarine HMAS Ovens, which is due to be paid off in 1994. This submarine cove will supplement the railway, maritime and aviation museums and the historic precinct in Port Adelaide. I applaud the corporation of the City of Port Adelaide for its vision for the future. The development of the submarine cove will no doubt give Port Adelaide, and the State of South Australia as a whole, a world-class tourist facility with the potential to attract up to 100,000 visitors per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent days in this place, the annual report of the Civil Aviation Authority for 1991-92 has been tabled. On page 14, under a report on the Australian advanced air traffic systems, the report says that the Authority was satisfied that it had received all essential information in a fair and unbiased way before arriving at a decision to award a contract. The Authority went on to say that, to satisfy the concerns of some members of parliament and Hughes Aircraft, the board had decided to establish an independent review of the evaluation process. That review is chaired by Ian Macphee.

PARA.TAB: To correct the public record, that particular inquiry was not instigated by the board of the CAA. It was brought about by the pressure of the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works, through extreme pressure exerted on two Ministers. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) did that work. Finally, the two Ministers very reluctantly decided to have that inquiry. The Macphee committee report is due in this place in a very short time, I understand. I hope it is not complete dynamite for the CAA.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome a decision by the Government not to phase out tariffs completely. A petition of nearly 9,000 signatures, which has just been presented to the House, reflects the disadvantage of a broad approach to tariff cuts. In supporting lower tariffs, both sides of parliament have overlooked some important issues about canned food. Food is important enough to be completely under Australian control. That means that inspections should be much more frequent and that importers should have to pay for it.

PARA.TAB: The recent rejection on health grounds of a shipment of tuna after a visit by the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) to the Heinz cannery in Eden confirms the need to do that. Food canning is labour intensive. Tariffs should not be used to protect inefficiency, but they should be used to protect living standards.

The coalition proposal for no tariffs at all is worse than Labor's phase-down to 5 per cent and 2 per cent for developing countries for tuna. The combination of having a GST, effectively a tax on wages, in place of a payroll tax and opting out of wages awards—both Liberal-National Party policies—would hurt the workers far more than the present arrangements.

I am pleased that the canned food industry has lodged an anti-dumping application on tuna imports. I urge the Government to reverse the phase-down of tariffs to 5 per cent and 2 per cent, and I urge the Opposition to abandon its policy of zero tariffs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I quote from Tuesday's Hansard where the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) answered a question on rural research. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: One interesting comment came from the member for Lowan in the Victorian Parliament, Mr Bill McGrath. He slammed what he said was the `Federal Government's preparedness to slash rural research and development'. Who is Bill McGrath today? He is the Minister for Agriculture in the Victorian Government, and he has that headline against him in a Herald and Weekly Times publication last week. That is the Victorian Government's position. It is prepared to criticise us over a speculation of slashing research and development, but it is into the cutting of research and development up to its neck.

The headline in fact says, `Jobs slashed for research', indicating that jobs may go from the 2,000-strong bureaucracy in order to maintain and expand research and extension. The Victorian Minister for Agriculture also recently announced a $13.2m private sector funding boost for the State's research program over the next three years. What a tangled web we weave when we practise to deceive. The Minister for Primary Industry and Energy has either intentionally misled the House, did not read the article, or was very poorly advised.

TALK.START.PARA: —On page 14 of the Civil Aviation Authority's annual report, the Authority claims that, because concern was expressed by members of parliament about the radar scheme, to correct those concerns it set up an inquiry. These are lies. The CAA annual report for 1991-92 gives a completely false account of the setting-up of the independent inquiry into the TAAATS program.

PARA.TAB: Contrary to what the CAA has stated on page 14 of the report, the inquiry was set up by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Cook) following a recommendation by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, of which I am Chairman. I spelt out the need for the inquiry in a speech in the House on 3 June 1992 following the Committee's inquiry into the proposed air traffic services centres in Melbourne and Brisbane.

I find it absolutely incredible that the CAA can give the impression in the annual report that the setting-up of the review of the TAAATS project was its idea. I believe that the CAA has, not for the first time, misled the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —About 230 Australian tourists, including a woman who is seven months pregnant, are stranded in eastern Europe because of problems with a Bulgarian private airline called JES Air. Amongst those 230 Australian tourists is a constituent of mine who was due home on a flight last Saturday morning. The flight was delayed, supposedly because of mechanical problems. The passengers were then told on Tuesday that the reason for the delay was that the airline did not pay handling fees and the plane had been impounded.

PARA.TAB: The passengers were given no reason for the next delay, on Wednesday. The husband rang his wife in Australia and is very concerned about this situation. I have been in contact with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and I have been told that it is monitoring the situation. But I impress on the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin) that he should take up this issue as a matter of urgency. These people are under great duress in Sofia, Bulgaria, and I ask that he take that matter up as a matter of urgency with Senator Evans. Here is an opportunity for Senator Evans to show his mettle as a Minister and bring that matter to a speedy conclusion so that those Australian residents can be returned to their homes in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last weekend I had the opportunity to attend the official opening of the Redbank Day Respite Centre in my electorate.
—You got them the money for sure.

—The centre has been funded by the Federal Government under the HACC program and I had the opportunity to represent my good friend the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples). This particular centre is run by the Blue Nursing Service.
—They are a good crowd.

—Yes, extremely nice people. The particular lady to whom I would like to pay tribute today is Mrs Gallagher, the centre coordinator, who runs the place. This actually operates in conjunction with the Woogaroo Meals on Wheels.

PARA.TAB: It just shows the level of cooperation in the community with the Blue Nurses and the Meals on Wheels organisation working together to assist our elderly people to remain in their own homes, which they often prefer to do rather than move into nursing or hostel accommodation. I think it is to the great credit of this Government that it has been able to provide these sorts of services to elderly people to ensure that they can live the life they wish to in their own homes, provided they have support such as this respite centre. It provides day care from time to time and, in conjunction with the Woogaroo Meals on Wheels, it provides meals as well. I would just like to put on record my congratulations to all those associated with the new Redbank Day Respite Centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —The effects of the disastrous levels of unemployment have been well canvassed, but there is an even worse malaise abroad in the community. There is a lack of faith in the institutions of the country, a lack of trust in the leaders and a lack of hope for the future. The sale of Qantas, approved almost unanimously by this House, reinforces all of these views. Qantas is more than just an airline, it is a symbol of national pride and confidence in the future. It was built up by the efforts of several generations of Australians, but it has now fallen victim to a decade long frenzy of deregulation and national assets liquidation presided over by this Government. It comes at a time when the United Kingdom lies in social and economic ruins as a result of the same policies and when the USA has jettisoned Reaganomics for a more interventionist approach.

PARA.TAB: The glee with which both the Government and coalition support privatisation and increasing foreign ownership of national assets is matched only by the violence of their attack on anyone who opposes these policies. The plundering of the past to solve the problems of the present, leaving nothing for the future, is part of the short term economic irrationalism which has gripped the English-speaking world in the 1980s. It has done dreadful harm to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I showed my fifth school through this great Parliament House this week and in so doing I started to think about the effect the GST would have upon visitors to this place. Our tourist industry is booming and it is of great importance to Australia, but there is no question that the great enemy confronting our tourist industry is the GST.

PARA.TAB: The GST will kill off the Australian tourist industry immediately. I calculated that each child who visits this House pays somewhere in the vicinity of $205. That is their total cost. But I calculated that when GST is added to their bus fare, their accommodation and on their food it is going to increase the cost to every child who visits this place by about $65. I want all of those people who are sitting in the gallery who travelled to this place from country areas throughout the State and from other States to understand that the GST is going to add $65 to the cost of their visit to Parliament House. That is a tragedy for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members would be aware of the disgraceful decision by the Federal Government to close the limestone quarry in southern Tasmania operated by Benders Pty Ltd. But I was particularly appalled to receive a written answer to my question on notice, No. 1855, from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly). I will quote from her written answer. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has issued regulations under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 which curtail operations at Benders Quarry without the written consent of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories.

I will just repeat that. It says that the Government has issued regulations which curtail the operations at Benders Quarry without the written consent of the Minister. I ask the House to consider that this Department is apparently operating without the approval and without the control of this Minister. If she is unable to effectively control the issuing of regulations by her Department then I question whether this Minister has the capacity to administer properly a department of state.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Mr H.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to read a motion passed unanimously by the Dorrigo Branch of the New South Wales Farmers Association. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: This Branch considers that the GST as proposed by the Coalition is not in the best interests of Australia and the rural community in particular. It is also considered that lower level income groups will be disadvantaged to such an extent that severe hardship could occur. This Branch therefore has no option but to publicly oppose any policy by any Government that entails the implementation of a broad based GST on basic foodstuffs—

—I inform the House that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Beazley, will be absent from Question Time today. In his absence, questions should be directed to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin.

—Name him; name him for disruption.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Given the absolutely disastrous unemployment figures released today and the obvious failure of your policies, how can you possibly claim that the recession was over long ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's unemployment remains a serious problem, as we said in today's release, but we must not be discouraged from tackling it.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—What we find in today's bulletin—
—I feel discouraged every time I look at you.
—Order! The honourable member for Casey!

—is a quite strong increase in employment of 26,000 for the month, but an increase in the participation rate.
