TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—There is no doubt that we have had a very high level of participation at this point in the cycle now for quite some time, but again because the number does dance around notoriously—
—Dance around!
—Yes, it does.

PARA.TAB: Mr Ronaldson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Ballarat!

—it does not mean necessarily that we are getting a clear and accurate picture of the trend direction of unemployment or even the level. I might also add that in this month in particular the Statistician has changed the basis of the survey which adds further confusion to the number.
—It has not changed for 18 months.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—What is it if you take that factor out?
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins will cease interjecting as well.
—The Statistician said this at the beginning of the release:

ANSWER.PARA: Care should be taken in the interpretation of month to month movements in estimates during the period September to December 1992—

PARA.TAB: Mr Lloyd interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Deputy Leader of the National Party!
—He continues:

ANSWER.PARA: A new sample for the labour force survey is being introduced which will increase the variability of estimates of month to month movements.
He then refers to explanatory notes. We have had a job growth of 26,000 over the month. The increase in unemployment is totally due to the increase in the participation rate.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Some of the volatility in that participation rate may be explained by the changed basis for the series which the Statistician refers to. But the Government continues to press on with an expansionary fiscal policy to deal with the problem of unemployment. I refer the Opposition to a statement by the OECD yesterday, which said:

ANSWER.PARA: The OECD said it would be sensible for some countries to relax fiscal policy to counter what it called the relatively weak and uncertain prospects for economic growth, but the OECD's economic policy committee said any easing of fiscal policy must be accompanied by concrete commitments to reverse such action once growth accelerates.
Importantly, it goes on to say:

Where there is room for flexibility in fiscal and monetary policies, any changes to support activity and to reduce the downside risk should be in the context of well-defined and credible medium term objectives.
There we have the principal economic organisation in the developed world talking about a need to expand fiscal policy—totally contrary to the policies of the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is dreadful.
—You are hopeless.
—Mr Speaker—
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Lowe!
—You are arguing for a $7 billion contraction in the Budget deficit.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—The Government expanded fiscal policy in the One Nation package, we have expanded it in the youth statement and we have expanded it in the Budget. The Opposition opposes this expansion and says that we should cut back the Budget deficit by nearly two full percentage points of gross domestic product—nearly $7 billion—

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Lavarch interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Fisher!

—which the Treasury calculates would have an unemployment effect of 135,000 persons. So here is the OECD arguing for an expansionary fiscal stance; here is the Opposition of Australia wanting a contractionary fiscal stance and, not only that, but knocking people off unemployment benefits after nine months and putting a 15 per cent goods and services tax—a huge price effect—into the economy while it is at it.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145, relevance. The question asked specifically what this Government is going to do about the problems of unemployment. It did not ask what the Opposition is going to do. It is a problem created by this Government, and I would ask you to get the Prime Minister to get back to that answer.
—Order! There is no point of order, as the honourable member for Isaacs well knows.
—The recovery is under way in Australia—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—but it is not fast enough. If it was not under way there would not be 26,000 job growth.
—Order! The honourable member for Bradfield!

—Unemployment will take longer to fall than any of us hopes, but the key to this is to go on strengthening the recovery and running an expansionary fiscal policy and getting the right mix in fiscal and monetary policy which, of course, the Opposition is opposed to. For the past few weeks the Government has been—

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Ronaldson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Ballarat!
—looking at the One Nation spending and considering measures which will do a number of things—speeding up One Nation spending by reallocating—

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Broadbent interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Corinella.
—He will not be here long anyway, Mr Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Government members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my right! The House will come to order.

—and bringing forward funds which are not being spent quickly enough, and also redesigning some of the labour market packages to encourage employers to take a large number of unemployed people. The Government has been working on both of these measures for a couple of weeks. The Government will be considering these matters at tonight's Cabinet meeting, and the results will be announced by the Treasurer in the morning. In other words, we will be doing all the things to keep the spending rate up in fiscal policy, and we will be making certain that labour market packages can be accepted for large groups of unemployed persons, for the use of unemployed persons by companies and by institutions.
—A new policy, eh?

PARA.TAB: Mr Melham interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting, as will the honourable member for Banks.

—And it is those issues on which the Government has been working now for some weeks. Here we have the Leader of the Opposition, in what can only be called a treacherous statement, saying that Australia is in danger of drifting into a depression. That is a treacherous statement.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—It is true.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—You ought to be ashamed of it. You'll score off any problems you think the Australian—
—Order! The Prime Minister might resume his seat.
—You are not a real Australian, John Hewson!

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the honourable member for Page interjects again I will name him.
—The Leader of the Opposition will traffic off anyone's difficulties to make a lousy political point. But to say that Australia is in danger of drifting into a depression—

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—is the most treacherous statement I think he has ever made.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—Let me remind the Leader of the Opposition, if he wants to talk about depressions, of the American depression. Between 1929 and the stock market crash in 1933 American gross domestic product fell by 30 percentage points. In this recession it has fallen by about four. That is the dimension of a depression. This is a statement calculated to damage and hurt the Australian public and the nation at large.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Accompanying the cowardice of this statement is a policy to cut two percentage points out of spending and cut the Budget deficit, with a contractionary policy, by $7 billion. He is arguing for that against everyone else in the world, including the OECD. He would destroy industries through the abolition of tariffs. He would knock off unemployment benefits after nine months for those affected. He would wreck the relationship—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—between employees and employers, which is building new investment—
—Point of order!
—Order! The Prime Minister will resume his seat. We have a point of order from the honourable member for Isaacs.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I do not like to raise another point of order under standing order 145, but I must say that the question relates to unemployment and to jobs, not to anything to do with the Opposition; it relates to what this Government has failed to do.
—Order! The Prime Minister will answer the question.
—Opposition members want to disrupt me, and they are embarrassed in so doing.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—The fact of the matter is that they will wreck the relationship between employers and employees in building new investment—
—You don't know what to do.
—Order! The honourable member for Bendigo!

—and most of all they will disrupt the economy by putting a massive price effect from a consumption tax, a GST, right throughout the economy. Whatever the Leader of the Opposition and his Party think about Australia's economic problems, your remedies have nought to do with the solution. In fact, they would just exacerbate the problem.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—In terms of remedies to the problem, you have been sidelined by the extreme nature of your own policies; that is, trying to turn into a contractionary policy stance—

PARA.TAB: Mr Bradford interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for McPherson.

—which no-one in the world supports by putting a huge price effect in through a GST, by wrecking industrial cooperation, like we are seeing under the Kennett Government in Victoria, by knocking people off unemployment benefits after nine months. How do you think any of these policies would help the unemployed, particularly when you try to say to the nation that they are on the edge of slipping into a depression with that treacherous statement designed to score off the peace of mind and progress of every sensible Australian?

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Andrews

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing orders 75 and 76. Standing order 75 says:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Member may use offensive words . . .
Standing order 76 reads:
All imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.
I put it to you, Mr Speaker, that the allegation of treachery—

PARA.TAB: Dr Hewson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—against any member of this House is offensive to both standing orders 75 and 76. I accordingly ask you to ask the Prime Minister to withdraw the allegation.
—If an honourable member whom words are used against takes offence, the honourable member can take the point of order and I will then rule on it. If the Leader of the Opposition wants to take—
—It is a standing order.
—Order! The House will come to order. Has the Prime Minister completed his answer?
—The fact of the matter is—

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—that the Opposition wants to market itself as having some answer to Australia's economic problems, where in fact its policies would be disruptive, contractionary and uncompassionate. They have everything about them which is wrong for Australia at this time. So you have marginalised yourself by your extremism but, worse than that, you have branded yourself by your opportunism with the statements you have made.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the Minister inform the House what actions the Government has taken to enhance the position of women in the work force, particularly within its industrial relations framework? What indications are there that these policies have been successful?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's objectives in relation to women in the work force have been twofold. Firstly, to increase their total employment opportunities; and, secondly—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—to provide equal opportunity for women in obtaining access to jobs at any level. In relation to more jobs, this Government has been vastly more successful than the Government that it succeeded. In relation to women, we have increased employment by 930,000 in 9 1/2 years—a 40 per cent increase in employment for women in the period that this Government has been in office. This compares with a total increase in employment for men and women of about 325,000 in the period of the Fraser Government. So it is a vastly greater performance in relation to employment for women under this Government. The female participation rate has increased from 44.6 per cent to 52.1 per cent. Obviously, there is a much greater proportion of women now looking for jobs. Of course, there is a much greater level of employment for women overall.

PARA.TAB: In regard to more opportunity for women, we have taken many steps to improve that opportunity and to give women a better quality of job. Obviously, the Sex Discrimination Act is important in outlawing discrimination against women in the workplace. The Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act is designed to encourage private sector employers and higher education institutions to introduce policies to enhance the position of women in the work force. Those employers have taken many steps to do those things: improving the flexibility of hours; providing employer based child-care; part time work; campaigns against sexual harassment; encouraging women into non-traditional employment areas; career break schemes; actively encouraging women to return to work after maternity leave, and so on. There are many examples of the kinds of things that are happening in the work force today. A similar thing is happening in the public sector under the equal employment opportunity program.

In regard to conditions of employment, women have benefited greatly from the pursuit by this Government of policies such as the minimum rates adjustment process, which was part of the award restructuring initiative of a few years ago. This resulted in substantial pay increases for many low paid women. When we came into office 24 per cent of women had superannuation. The latest figures show that as a result of award superannuation and now, of course, the changes which have been taken further by the superannuation guarantee charge, we have 72 per cent of women with superannuation. Unpaid parental leave has also been introduced as a result of this Government's support and the accord.

Of course, there have been major changes through education, child-care and training. In relation to child-care, we have had over a fourfold increase in the number of child-care places—an increase from 46,000 to 193,000 places. There has been a 77 per cent increase in the number of women in tertiary training. Women now have 70 per cent of traineeships. There are all sorts of indications of women's position in the work force being greatly improved under this Government. The overall figures show that that improvement is, in fact, eventuating.

In relation to wages, we see that in regard to full time, adult, non-managerial work the ratio of female pay to male pay has improved from 87 per cent in 1983 to 92 per cent this year. In regard to managerial and professional work, women represented 31 per cent of the work force in 1986; they represent 35 per cent of the work force now. Clearly, their position is improving substantially as our policies bear on the problem.

In the context of all of this, one should look briefly at what the Opposition would do. Under Fightback we see that the Affirmative Action Act, which has been so important, would be greatly damaged by the fact that the Opposition would abolish the Affirmative Action Agency. The Opposition says that it would still pursue the Act because it would require the Department of Industrial Relations to do so. However, it would halve the variable expenditure of the Department of Industrial Relations. It would chop $79m out of it. The Opposition would then tell the Department to do the things that it did before, plus administer the Affirmative Action Act. What a joke! Obviously, that Act would be gone.

The Office of the Status of Women is listed as an agency which would be reduced or absorbed. Clearly, that would be at least downgraded. Child-care would be subject to a 15 per cent GST. We noted from the Opposition's industrial relations policies that the policies of taking away the safety net of awards would be greatly damaging to women. Most important, and most surprising perhaps, is the fact that the Opposition is pursuing a policy of rewriting history. I refer here particularly to a speech given by the Leader of the Opposition in July this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this on the question?
—It is very much on the question. In talking about women in the work force, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I reckon I can understand women because I have worked out that most of them are just like us.
What an amazing statement! He said:
I had this blinding flash of insight one morning when I was ironing my shirt.

This blinding flash of insight did not extend to his knowledge of history. In the same speech he said that in 1972, the McMahon Government passed the historic equal pay for equal work legislation. There was no such legislation. What we had in 1972 was a major development for women in the work force in Australia. It was the introduction of equal pay for work of equal value. That came about by a case that was taken by the trade union movement in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which the McMahon Government opposed. Now the Leader of the Opposition is trying to stand up and say that it was responsible for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—In fact, that case had been concluded, but not been decided at the time of the 1972 election.
—You are really in trouble when you go back 20 years.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.

—After that election, the Whitlam Government asked for the case to be reopened to make submissions in support of the claim. I can say that I recall these events very well because I was the union advocate in that case.

PARA.TAB: The history of this Government's period in office and going back much further is, quite clearly, that women have progressed in the work force of this country under Labor Governments. That is the way it has been in the past. That is the way it will be in the future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again directed to the Prime Minister. I remind the Prime Minister that during the 1982-83 recession, and even in this Parliament as late as 1985, he and other senior Ministers used the word `depression' to describe the economic downturn in 1982-83. The Treasurer referred to it as the `devastating depression', at a time when the unemployment rate was 9.7 per cent. The Minister for Finance described it as a `vast depression' at the time when the unemployment rate was 9.4 per cent. The Prime Minister himself described it in the following terms:

QUESTION.PARA: In 1982 when the honourable gentleman had interest rates at the level they are now, the economy was in a state of depression. It was at the bottom of the worst depression since the great depression.

I ask the Prime Minister: if depression was an appropriate description of 1982, surely it is an even more appropriate description today, given the circumstances in which you have left this country, with 11.3 per cent unemployment and massive pain and misery and hardship? By the way, I ask you to withdraw the statement that my remarks were treacherous.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Withdraw! Withdraw!
Mr SPEAKER—Order! The House will come to order. A withdrawal is required at the time the matter is raised.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh! Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Members on my left may laugh if they like, but they know that is the rule and they know it well.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, he is retro-indignant.
—The House will come to order. Members on my left will cease interjecting.
—Why don't you spin the bottle for the decision?
—If the honourable member for Kooyong interjects again, I will name him.

—Obviously, the Leader of the Opposition was cavilling at those remarks. If he was cavilling at those remarks, I do not know why he sought to use them today. The fact of the matter is that there is a simple point here. He says in today's statement:

ANSWER.PARA: Labor is trying to spend its way out of the problem. Australia needs a real change of direction.
That means to contract policy.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—That is what you are arguing for—a contraction of policy.
—Answer the question, you hypocrite.
—Order!

—I just leave the simple question hang. If we were to contract policy by 2 per cent of GDP, would this not exacerbate unemployment and push the economy back into recession? Of course it would. If we were to have an industrial confrontation nationwide, would this promote economic recovery in employment or contract it and see unemployment?

PARA.TAB: Dr Hewson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course such a policy would.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.

—Why does the Leader of the Opposition believe that he alone has the right to argue for a contractionary policy when the representatives of the 24 industrial nations are arguing for an expansionary policy? When the OECD is endorsing the stance of this Government, he is out there arguing for a contractionary policy which would make things worse in this country and make life harder for people across the spectrum.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition may be discomfited by this fact, as I said earlier, that the extremism and ideology of their policies sideline them in this.
Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—It may be an uncomfortable political fact for you to know that, at a time when you see political opportunity, your policies prevent you from playing a role. Your policies sideline you from being relevant in the remedies to Australia's economic problems. The policies which the Government has—
—Do not talk about inflation, we have the lowest inflation rate in the world.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. There is far too much noise.

—We have an expansionary fiscal policy in place, which, as the OECD enjoins us to do, will again return to Budget balance at the appropriate point in the cycle. Such a policy is in place in Australia. We have low interest rates, which are playing a role in accelerating the recovery, and we have an industrial relations policy conducive to cooperation, investment and economic growth. You are opposed to all these things.
—You would say anything.
—You would do anything.
—You are a hypocrite!
—Order!

—We do not have a policy of putting a six to seven percentage point net price effect into the economy through a 15 per cent goods and services tax. The fact is that you are on the wrong policy horse at the wrong time. Whatever you think about the problems, you are not only irrelevant to the problems, you would vandalise the problems by your policies. That is the harsh reality of the position.
—Mr 11.3 per cent!
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—That is why everybody out there in business understands that your policy now of lifting interest rates, of contracting fiscal policy, of wrecking industrial cooperation and adding a GST to the system would simply drive the Australian economy back into recession, at a time when the economy is recovering and where we are seeing positive job growth numbers.
—You answer the question.
—Order!
—The Opposition is very discomfited by this. In that case, change your policies; endorse the expansionary policy by the Government, endorse the thrust of the One Nation package—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—endorse the thrust of the youth statement and the Budget, endorse the thrust of the Government's industrial relations policies of cooperation. But do not stand up with these wrecking policies—
—That would be endorsing your policy for unemployment.
—Order! The honourable member for Gilmore!

—and try to claim for a moment that they are in the slightest way useful or relevant to repairing Australia's current problems. They are not; they would exacerbate them. Not only that, they would see the economy reverse into a recession which would do us no good at all.
—Ah, you almost used the D word.
—Order!

—The fact of the matter is that members of the Opposition thought that the economy was going to recover more quickly, that they could run a contractionary policy, that they could fit the economy up with a GST, and they have been wrong. They have been wrong and they have now got the wrong cast of policy for the current conditions in the economy. That is just too bad for you.
—You did not even answer the question.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Rural Sector: Goods and Services Tax

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of concerns being expressed by farmer groups in relation to proposals to change the current business tax regime? Will he inform the House of the benefits to the farm sector of the Government's policy approach to the rural sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Yes, I am aware of widespread opposition from grassroots farmer organisations to the introduction of a goods and services tax.

PARA.TAB: Mr Carlton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mackellar!

—The fact of the matter is that the policy that this Government has introduced in relation to farm inputs has seen a position in which direct farm input costs are virtually negligible now so far as the wholesale sales tax is concerned because of the amendments that this Government has introduced. The latest expression of this concern from farmer organisations has come from Dorrigo. Just before Question Time started, we heard the resolution from the Dorrigo farmers group that 70 people—
—Ten people! Ten people only!
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.
—We heard the resolution that was passed in which the Dorrigo farmers group opposed the introduction of a goods and services tax from any government.
—Six to four.
—Order!

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting.
—That would be a large garage in your electorate.
—If the honourable member for Kooyong interjects again, I will deal with him.

—Those on the other side feign concern for the rights of individuals to have their expression when it comes to trade unionists, but they do not like it when their own members rebel and come forward with statements that question their policy. Mr Block represented this group of farmers from Dorrigo in a radio interview on the ABC yesterday.
—Only six—six!
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland!
—The questioner asked:

ANSWER.PARA: What would you say the basic criticism—
I am sorry, Mr Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh, ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—I will come back to that, because you will get it.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. There is far too much noise.
—The questioner asked:

ANSWER.PARA: What were the inconsistencies you found, Mr Block?
Mr Block answered:
In the papers put out by the Coalition—
which I think they got from the honourable member for Cowper's office—
. . . and we weren't looking for inconsistencies, they just happened to pop up as we examined them . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what they are.
—We will come to that. I thank you for asking. The questioner asked:

ANSWER.PARA: What would you say the basic criticism . . .
He said:
At the moment the rural community does not pay, and I'm talking about farmers, primary producers . . . sales tax on any of its inputs probably other than oils and greases—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Wrong! Wrong!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—You have got it wrong.
—Order! The honourable member for Bass will cease interjecting.
—He continued:

ANSWER.PARA: All inputs, whether they be vet fees or commission to our sales agents or freight or seed or feed or fertiliser, and so on, is free of sales tax as far as the farmer is concerned.
He is now going to have to pay 15% on all those items, irrespective of what they are—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Wrong! Wrong!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting.
—He continued:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . he's then, after a period of time . . . got to claim it back from the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wrong.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell!

—This is no ordinary farmer. This is a person who holds office in the New South Wales farmers organisation. He is an accountant of 40 years experience and a person who has voted eight out of the last 10 times for the National Party.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—He and his group are starting to find out the harsh truth. They have been sold out by the National Party on this occasion in relation to the goods and services tax.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The responsibility of Ministers not to mislead the House is a convention in this place.
—Order! Does the honourable member for O'Connor have a point of order?
—Yes, I do.
—Get to your point of order.
—It is about the misleading of the Parliament. My point of order is: should a Minister refer to something as the truth when it is absolutely not the truth?
—The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. If he makes an intervention like that again, I will name him.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber on both sides.

—The National Party has sold out its so-called constituency and it cannot adequately explain how this goods and services tax will impact. How is it explaining that a 15 per cent additional tax on everything farmers buy will be good for them?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Wrong!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Our approach, on the other hand, is to consult with industry, not dictate to it.

PARA.TAB: Mr Sharp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Gilmore.

—It is to, in consultation with industry, tackle impediments to its future and to develop a growth strategy for those industries. That is what we have done in relation to the dairy industry and the grains industry. We are doing it in relation to the wool industry, the tobacco industry and the sugar industry. Let me come to the sugar industry, because I think it is interesting.
—Talk about anything but jobs.
—Order!

—A couple of weeks ago, on 30 October, the Leader of the Opposition was in Mackay to speak to, of all people, the Regional Development Bureau. You would think that people who knew something about Mackay, as many on this side of the House do, would know that a fundamental plank of regional development in that area depends upon the future of the sugar industry. Yet in a 16-page speech, how many times do you think the Leader of the Opposition referred to the sugar industry? Not once! Not once in 16 pages!

PARA.TAB: This is the person who maintains that he stands for one thing—his absolute determination to call it the way it is, to call for what needs to be done, irrespective of the short term political consequences. Not mentioning sugar once to the Mackay Regional Development Bureau, he sure did not call it the way that the Mackay industry wanted to see it, particularly having told the Nationals in his own party room that the tariff for the sugar industry would be reduced to zero.

In conclusion I say this: the fact of the matter is that there is growing concern among people in the bush about what Fightback and the GST are going to do to them. Farm organisations are increasingly questioning what they have been told. Gone is the day when those on the other side, particularly from the National Party, can go out there with a smile, a hat and a pork barrel and pretend that the issues are not there, that all the complexities will be dealt with when they get into office. They want answers. They want to know how a 15 per cent goods and services tax will help them. They want to know how a zero tariff will help them. I might say that I think they know the answer.
Opposition members interjecting—

—of this questioning about you within your Party; I will give you your shot at history now'. The fact is that in this system the Prime Minister has the prerogative of calling the election date, and that is not something I am going to cede to you.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. What is the Government doing to rectify the drop in income of British pensioners in Australia as a result of the significant fluctuations in the pound sterling over the last two months?

—I note from the honourable member's own cor-respondence to me that he does follow the concerns of his pensioner community closely and recognises the difficulties that pensioners with British pensions have been encountering because of fluctuations in the exchange rate.

PARA.TAB: If you listen to the merchants of doom on the Opposition side, you would think that the only currency affected by the present volatility was the Australian dollar. But if you look at the English pound, you will see that it has fallen dramatically and precipitously against the Australian dollar in recent weeks. There is no doubt that the sudden and dramatic fall has affected some 110,000 British pensioners who have their British pensions topped up by the Australian pension. The free fall of the English pound in recent weeks has outstripped the mechanisms of the social security legislation which are required to deal with these matters.

At the moment we set that exchange rate four times a year and each setting remains in place for three months. There is a trigger mechanism designed to provide for sudden and dramatic changes in exchange rates, but it proved inadequate in the last weeks of October in coping with the volatility of the pound sterling. The present departmental rate is one Australian dollar to 39.14 pence. Yet we have had an average variation away from that of some 11 per cent in recent weeks. Anyhow, it does not reflect the trend movement in the pound sterling.

Given the failure of the trigger mechanism, the Department has now intervened in the process and we have set a new exchange rate of one Australian dollar to 44.85 pence. This has been based on the average of the Commonwealth Bank rate during the last two weeks of October. We will bring that in next week from 19 November. If we had not done that there would have been no change until mid-December and that would have badly and unfairly affected a large number of people living in Australia but with some English pension entitlement.

This new rate will significantly increase the Australian pension which tops up British pensions for some 110,000 people in this country with a British pension entitlement. It reflects again the Government's continuing concern and monitoring of any challenges faced by our pensioner community.
