PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative, with an absolute majority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House censures the Prime Minister for his economic policy negligence which has given Australia record unemployment and left our country to drift towards depression.

SPEECH.PARA: The unemployment numbers that were released today for the month of October are nothing short of a national disaster. They are a tragedy for thousands and thousands of average Australian families. Indeed, something like 52,000 more people were added to the dole queues in that month alone, which brings the total since this recession began in late 1989 to half a million people. Five hundred thousand people, or thereabouts, have been added to the unemployment queues since this recession began—the recession that this man said we had to have.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps most disturbing, when we look at the composition of some of those numbers, is that 375,000 Australians have now spent more than 12 months on the dole. I have seen predictions in recent days to suggest that the number of long term unemployed will rocket towards 500,000 people by the middle of this decade under the sorts of policies we have seen in recent days. This is real pain and real hardship knowingly, willingly and deliberately inflicted on the people of Australia by this man, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in the pursuit of his own short term, politically expedient objectives.

I think what is most disturbing is that when we look at some of the regional characteristics of this unemployment experience we see the magnitude of the problem that is there for large parts of average Australia. For example, if we take the area of Fairfield and Liverpool in New South Wales and look at the average unemployment rate for the three months to September—not including the October deterioration—we see that the unemployment rate is now 18.6 per cent. In Richmond-Tweed on the mid-north coast of New South Wales, for example, it is 15.8 per cent. In north-western Melbourne there is an unemployment rate of 17.4 per cent, and an unemployment rate for young people in that area of 50.5 per cent. One in two young people in north-western Melbourne is unemployed. In fact, in outer western Melbourne the youth unemployment rate is 56 per cent. To take one final example, across in western Adelaide the unemployment rate is 14 1/2 per cent. In south Adelaide the youth unemployment rate is the national record of 56.9 per cent according to the data that has been released.

And this man has the hide to suggest that our country is not drifting towards depression! For three years this country has been in the depths of the worst recession in 60 years, and he has done nothing about it. Since he became Prime Minister the unemployment situation has deteriorated dramatically. He brought in the One Nation statement, promising 800,000 jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —He cheated on the figures.

—He fudged the figures and fudged the growth numbers—the whole thing was a political stunt—only to see the unemployment rate since the One Nation statement go from about 10 1/2 per cent to 11.3 per cent. This man is driven only by politics: he is not driven to deal with the pain and hardship that he has inflicted on the average Australian.

PARA.TAB: This man has been in government now for 10 years—and they are 10 years of so-called progress if you listen to him. All the numbers have been beautiful; things have always been on track and things have always gone the way they were expected to go. In fact, we have generally done better than he expected. Budget after Budget promised the bringing home of the bacon and the new golden age. They are lighting candles in cathedrals all over Europe after 10 years of progress and 10 years of social justice a la Paul Keating and the Labor Party.

But it has been 10 years of hard labour, 10 years of failure, dozens and dozens of statements—industry statements, economic statements, Budget statements—and thousands of political publicity stunts. And we sit here today with an 11.3 per cent postwar record unemployment rate with the prospect of 500,000 long term unemployed Australians by the middle of this decade.

They have been 10 years of excuses, 10 years of promised improvements that never came and 10 years of diversions and distractions. The Prime Minister has kept the gallery occupied for a substantial part of the last 10 years by chasing rabbits up various burrows to divert attention from the basic fact that the problems are getting worse, our economic circumstances are getting worse and he has absolutely no solutions to deal with those problems.

We saw the ultimate in hypocrisy today. When we used the expression that this economy was in danger of drifting towards depression, the Prime Minister got up and said that was a treacherous remark. He should go back and read the Hansards from the early 1980s and some of the remarks that Government members made when they were in opposition in circumstances that were dramatically different from those that exist today. Of course, today the magnitude of the problem is so much worse.

A large part of the recession in the early 1980s was brought about by the drought, not by deliberate government policy, as was the case under the stewardship of this man. We had some of the leading shadow Ministers at the time, now government Ministers, describing those circumstances as a depression. Back in November 1983, the current Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) described the circumstances at the time as the `devastating depression in which we found this economy'. At a time when the unemployment rate was 9.7 per cent, significantly less than 11.3 per cent, he was describing it as a devastating depression.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), who is known on the front bench for a greater degree of honesty than the rest of them, described it as a `vast depression'. He said the current state of the economy was a vast depression in December 1982 when the unemployment rate was 9.4 per cent. But the prize for ultimate hypocrisy is always taken by our Prime Minister. In 1985, he described the circumstances in 1982 in the following terms: `In 1982 the economy was in a state of depression. It was at the bottom of the worst depression since the Great Depression'. Our current Prime Minister, in 1985, looking back at a time when the unemployment rate was 9.4 per cent, said it was the worst depression since the Great Depression. And he had the hide to get up here in this Parliament today and try to suggest that our measured remarks about the danger of this economy drifting towards depression were treacherous. Just imagine what we are to conclude about the magnitude of the remarks you have made in the past and on dozens of occasions since.

Government members are always struggling for a definition of depression. The Treasurer got up and tried to explain how things had changed between 1982 and now. He said he could actually call it a depression then, and when things are dramatically worse now in terms of unemployment and debt or anything else he does not have to use the word. It is probably instructive to quote one of the Government's own definitions of depression. The Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) used to be an economics teacher, and he has written a series of economics books. He is actually the man who is responsible for the One Nation failure, perhaps more directly than anybody else. When you take out R.J. Brown's Student Economics, sixth edition, you find the following definition of a depression:

SPEECH.PARA: In serious depressions, mass unemployment of all factors exists and many firms are bankrupt or operating at a loss. Business firms are using up their capital reserves and consumers are exhausting their savings. Prices and demand are both low and national income is low partly because of unemployment and also because the average income of those people still employed is low.
That is exactly what has happened. He continues:

Business prospects look bleak and even the maintenance and replacement of capital equipment are being delayed until prospects brighten or until they can be delayed no longer. The industries which are most seriously affected are the investment (capital goods) and durable consumer goods industries.

The Government is damned out of the mouth of its own economic guru. He is probably the only bloke in the whole Government who has ever read or understood anything about economics, and there he was in his own textbook on that subject educating the youth of Australia as to the definition of depression.

PARA.TAB: What better description can you get of the circumstances today? In fact, it is probably worse today than even that definition because of the magnitude of the debt problem that was not possibly contemplated 10 or 15 years ago in this country. No-one had any idea that a Government could be so irresponsible and so out of control that it could boost debt from about $25 billion to about $150 billion net and about $180 billion gross in the pursuit of short term, politically expedient objectives. Probably to average Australians the greatest disappointment of all is that they see that the Prime Minister has no understanding of what they have to endure as a result of his policies. How long has it been since the Prime Minister actually went out and spoke to a group of unemployed people and listened to the pain and hardship of these people?

I personally experienced one such case this week—the case of a migrant couple who had worked for 20 years to save for a house. Every time we have seen them over the last few months they have been enthusiastic at the prospect of finally getting their own home. At the end of last week the husband lost his job. They are devastated. They had just taken possession of the house. They had just locked themselves into the mortgage. The pain and hardship of that decision and to watch those people in tears is a staggering experience.

I suggest to the Treasurer that he should go out and try to understand what it is like to be unemployed; try to understand what it is like to have your home taken away from you; try to live as a child would live in poverty—as many thousands do around Australia; sleep in the streets one night just to see how it feels for those homeless youth and others living in poverty in our capitals and other parts; go down to the soup kitchens and talk to some of the people in queues to start to understand the pain and hardship that your recession has inflicted on them. Try living for a while on welfare to just see what it is like to try to get by, to make ends meet, to deal with the mortgage, the pressure of the kids' education and every other pain and hardship inflicted on people as a result of the Government's policies.

Perhaps the greatest tragedy in all this—recognising the magnitude of that pain and hardship—is that the Prime Minister actually knows what should be done, but he has not got the character or the strength of leadership to put in place the policies that have to be put in place to turn these circumstances around. What does he do? He spends every day bagging us. He blames everybody else; he attacks us; he blames the business community—it does not matter who it is. He attacks everybody rather than accept the responsibility for what he has done and show the strength of leadership that is required in order to turn these circumstances around.

Our biggest problem today—right now in the circumstances in which we find Australia—is not only the magnitude of the problem but also the magnitude of the weakness of our Prime Minister. He knows what has to be done. He has argued the case dozens of times in the past about what has to be done. However, he settles back on what is just a blatant attack—a negative attitude; a whingeing and carping attack on a daily basis—on us, the only group of people capable of putting down a viable economic alternative and arguing the case to the people of Australia.

Indeed, we saw the ultimate extent to which that man will go. He really is a clever man. He has tricked us all by running the economy more slowly so that he can tell the people that our policies will not work. Did honourable members hear that argument twice in Question Time today? What a clever man! He has run the economy more slowly so that he can get up and argue that our policies will not work. I went to a doorstop today. There were a whole lot of journalists running around asking me those sorts of questions. The Prime Minister is out selling them that line. What a brilliant political tactician he is! He will be able to justify the fact that he ran the economy so slowly that we will now not be able to explain why our policies will work. Yet he knows, as well as we know, that we started out with the basic assessment. This is the worst recession in 60 years and there is a set of identifiable policies that can be put in place to turn it around. He knows that; he has advocated it. We have gone out and done it when he has not had the strength and the capacity of leadership to do the job. Indeed, what is he doing? He is simply trying to frighten the people of Australia about our alternative—about the fact that we have the answers. We can turn this country around, we can rebuild jobs, rebuild wealth, rebuild hope and give people and their families a future. He is out there trying to scare them.

How far will the Prime Minister go? I do not know. There are a lot of heroes of the New South Wales Right who must be turning in their graves today because he is down there with the Victorians, the Left—people such as Halfpenny, Curran and Kirner. He has got into bed with them, for what purpose? To run a whole series of rolling disputes, ultimately coming to a national industrial dispute, in a desperate attempt to frighten people about what he says will be the consequences of our economic policy. It shows how far he will go. It shows how far that man will go to save his political hide. He will not only say or do anything; he will get into bed with anybody in order to undermine the credibility of the alternative government. He will try to scare people in the hope that he will ensure his own political survival.

The Prime Minister is prepared to declare war on the people of Australia through a series of rolling stoppages for his own short term political ends. He knows better than anybody else that that behaviour will only prolong the problem—

TALK.START.PARA: —You would bring in the troops on the waterfront.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Order! The honourable member for Banks!

TALK.START.PARA: —it will only compound the problem; it will only cost more jobs; it will only destroy more lives. Yet, the Prime Minister goes out and does that. He stands up here every day and says just about anything that occurs to him at the moment in order to distort the facts and to try to frighten people about our policies. He is out there up to his neck aiding and abetting, if not organising, a series of industrial disputes to further destroy the livelihood of average Australians.

PARA.TAB: He is a bully in here, of course. He has a reputation for dominating the Parliament with his bully tactics. It is not real hard. We get about 30 seconds for a question and he gets about 15 minutes for an answer. He is a bully in here, but when it counts, when it really matters, when it matters outside, when it matters to put the right policies in place, he is going to go down in history as one of the weakest leaders this country has ever seen—a weak, weak, weak, weak leader.

It is weak leadership because he knows what has to be done. He knows this country can be turned around by cutting business costs. He knows Fightback will cut $20 billion of taxes from the business community, which will create the opportunity to rejuvenate the business sector and create wealth and jobs. He knows that, but he is too weak to get out and argue the case. He knows that an essential part of that is the goods and services tax. He knows that it will take tax off business. He knows that it will make us internationally competitive in a business sense, but he is too weak to go out and argue the case.

To his credit, he tried once. He got rolled. When we look back over the last 10 years, he has hardly achieved anything in terms of economic policy in this country. Even when the dollar was floated in 1983, who did it? Not that weak guy.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Hawke—Bob Hawke.

—Bob Hawke, his predecessor, got out and took that decision. On each occasion he has either failed to deliver the goods or failed to sustain the argument and to win the case when he knows what has to be done. What does he do now? He just runs a political scare campaign about the GST. He tries to suggest that a 20-point program in Fightback, only one of which is tax reform and only part of which is the GST, can somehow be reduced to a referendum on the GST.

PARA.TAB: The next election is not going to be a referendum on the GST; it is going to be a referendum on the pain and hardship that you have inflicted on the people of Australia. It is going to be a referendum on jobs. It is going to be a referendum on economic mismanagement. It is going to be a referendum on the weakness of your leadership, because you know what has to be done to turn our circumstances around and you cannot or will not do it.

In fact, you have now resorted every day to simply trying to frighten people and misrepresent things in order to ensure your own political survival. People will never understand why a country with the wealth and opportunity and position of Australia is in the mess that it is in. Quite frankly, they will never forgive you for your time as Treasurer and your time as Prime Minister and for the damage that you have done to a country that has so much great potential.

The tragedy is that Australia can be whatever we want it to be. There should be no limit to Australia's potential but perhaps the extent of our dreams. If we think about it, if we look at where we are in the Asia-Pacific region, if we think about the tremendous opportunities that are there for us to boost our economic growth and to start to trade our way out of these difficulties, right across the board, in traditional agriculture, in traditional mining, we can expand our exports, our activity and our jobs. In those areas, in food processing, in smelting, we can add significant value and we can create jobs.

Right through the manufacturing sector there are opportunities that are going begging because the weakness of the Prime Minister's leadership prevents him from putting in place the policies that he knows should be put in place. Of course, throughout the service sector—it does not matter whether it is tourism or education or financial services—Australia can be a most important financial centre. That is also the case in medical services, legal services, construction services and telecommunications services. We can get out there and match and beat the best in the world. We can have a viable economy in Australia. We can actually make substantial contributions to the well-being of the average Australian. They can look forward not only to more jobs and higher incomes but to a better standard of living, better education, better health. Those opportunities are there.

The only thing that is stopping them is your hypocrisy and the weakness of your leadership. It is the incredible weakness of your leadership that stops your putting in place the decisions that you know should be taken. You know the policies are there. You know that Fightback includes every one of them. You have advocated most of them in the past, but you are too weak to take the decisions that are required to turn our circumstances around. So, we are left today with a legacy of nearly $200 billion worth of debt; 11.3 per cent unemployment; and pain, hardship and misery for average Australians. They have no hope. They have no confidence in the future.

That will be your monument. That is what the next election will be fought on. I challenge you again: call it on 19 December and let us go, so that the people of Australia can have a chance. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we just heard was a speech without flair or substance, a speech by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) not even successfully addressing his own people because there was no enthusiasm in the Opposition for this motion—none. Those opposite were sitting up there, po-faced, right through it.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition shows all the signs of a person having peaked and who, in political terms, is in decline on his side of public life. That was the position. The speech, which was essentially an attack on me, was not washing on the other side because when he got down to it what was the substance of it? He was basically hiding from the fact that he has a policy prescription which would reverse the economy's progress. That is his great problem.

It may be sucking on a bitter pill, but honourable members opposite do know that any policy which wants to contract public spending by two percentage points of gross domestic product, that cuts $7 billion out of the Budget, that turns industrial peace into industrial mayhem, that puts a 15 per cent goods and services tax on spending and therefore reduces demand, is going to do nothing whatsoever to engender a continuing recovery and abate unemployment. They know that on that side of the House and the Leader of the Opposition knows it.

Those opposite are sort of beached: in a sense, the tide is going out and they cannot keep up with it because their policy position is one which would basically reverse progress in the economy. I do not know why the Leader of the Opposition feels that he has any policy strength to his position because, at a time when the principal policy organisations of the world are urging an expansionary fiscal stance by governments and an expansionary approach to policy, he is arguing for the reverse.

It may be a sad matter for the Opposition but those opposite are in a position now where they know their policy prescription is irrelevant to Australia's position; worse, they would actually vandalise our position by seeking to push the economy back into the recession whence it came. The Leader of the Opposition talked about 10 years hard Labor but he did not furnish any results. He did not talk about the fact that when he left us he had 700,000 people out of work as the Government's principal adviser. In 1983 there were only six million people in the work force where today there are nearly eight million.

The Leader of the Opposition did not refer to any of the structural changes which he and his Party lazily left behind after 30 years of office which saw the economy closed, shut, without confidence and without options; unable to pay for its imports and with its debt to GDP ratio rising from 12 per cent to over 33 per cent within two or three years of the Hawke Government coming to office because of that structural weakness engendered by those opposite. He did not refer to any other issues such as dealing with the big micro-economic changes in the labour market, or whether it be dealing with the ports and wharves, or the telecommunications system, or the rail system, or the trunk road system or any of the hard rutted-in problems that had been left to the Labor Party. He referred to none of those things.

The Leader of the Opposition believes that simply by relieving the tax on payrolls, cutting the price of petrol and introducing a GST which taxes everything from food and clothing to every service in the economy, he will produce a revolution in the Australian economy. What foolish, simple person would believe that rubbish? He is arguing that a tenth order tax change would make such a difference to the Australian economy that it would burst out of its skin and find itself a productive new place in the world. The Liberal Party is bereft of policy, as it always was, but, to look different, the Leader of the Opposition embraced the consumption tax so he could argue to his front bench that he represented something, even though that something was an inappropriate something for Australia's economic conditions.

He talks about 10 years of excuses, when in fact the Government has taken on every rutted-in problem that governments of 30-years standing have left behind. My colleague the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) this week talked about the changes which have taken place on the ports and wharves. Yesterday the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) was talking about industrial changes taking place in Victoria. In the last couple of days I have been talking about the enterprise agreements bringing flexibility to businesses across the country.

We have low inflation. We are in a productivity surge—a productivity bubble. We have made relationships in Asia that we have never made before. We have a position in the world we could never have hoped to have under the Opposition. We have led the world, through the Cairns Group, in fighting the Europeans on a decent, fair and open multilateral trading system, which the Opposition never had the wit to do. Doug Anthony would come back from discussions with the British and the Europeans saying, `They basically turned me away'. That was not our policy. We were into them to try to get a decent multilateral trading system in place.

Australia is now poised, notwithstanding its current difficulties and the disappointment of high unemployment, to take its place in the Asia-Pacific region as never before, to take its place in the trading world as never before, and to emerge as a competitive society. We have never perhaps been more competitive than we are at the moment via the exchange rate, wages and any other measure of comparativeness. We were last this competitive when the exchange rate fell by 25 percentage points in the middle 1980s. The place is hugely competitive.

We are carving out a place for ourselves, and we are underpinning the strength of sectors of the Australian economy to do well in this economy and to do well abroad. While we have done that, we have threaded together one of the most decent social security systems in the world. We have done it with a tax to GDP ratio which is one of the smallest in the OECD, from one of the smallest public sectors in the world. We have turned a smaller public sector into a better and more compassionate public sector.

We have access and equity for health through Medicare; access and equity for kids through education—and for adults as well—and access and equity for aged people through aged care. We have support for women in the work force through child-care. These are all the things that you never had the wit or the compassion to put into place. I noticed this terribly pungent and offensive remark made by the Leader of the Opposition in his speech this morning:

SPEECH.PARA: Giving people choice is the compassion that liberates—just giving is the compassion that suffocates.

In other words, if you support somebody on a low income, with support for their children through the family allowance supplement, it suffocates them. Yesterday when I said, `Let's bring people up so that we don't have an underclass in Australia', you said, `It drags the rest of us down'.

PARA.TAB: If we try for a decent policy which gives Australians a part of the prosperity of this country, if we bring people up so that we move on as a society and as a group, you say that it drags the people in the front back; it drags the rest of us down. If we give support to families with children through the family allowance supplement, you say, `Just giving is the compassion which suffocates'. If we give support through Medicare to people who do not pay the Medicare levy because their incomes are too low but who have families or who may be unemployed, you say that just giving—that is, giving them health support without levy—is the compassion which suffocates.

If we support people who are unemployed, through no fault of their own, after nine months, you say, `Throw them off that support'. We say we should keep them on and carry them along in society until we can retrain them and get them back to work. You say that just giving is the compassion which suffocates. You say that giving people choice is the compassion that liberates; in other words, `Throw them out after nine months on unemployment benefits; knock off the support for taxpayers with children by the family allowance supplement; and ask the parents of kids from low income families to pay full fees in universities and elsewhere'. That is the sort of choice which you say is the compassion which liberates. We know it is a pernicious choice that will only damage them and limit their opportunities in society. The children of poor or low income people—bright as they may be—will not get the opportunities to excel and take their place in this economy as they are entitled to.

Then the Leader of the Opposition half made the nasty point about unemployment amongst young people in inner Melbourne being 56 per cent when, in fact, the proportion of unemployed young people amongst the age group 15 to 19 is 14 per cent, not 56 per cent. The figure for those looking for work is 56 per cent, but it is 14 per cent for the kids aged 15 to 19. What does the Opposition want to do with kids aged 15 to 19—break their heart and their spirit by telling them that they have no prospect of a job, when only 14 per cent of the group is unemployed? This heartless Opposition not only has no head, it also has no heart. It regards compassion as suffocating. It basically regards the policies of the fittest as the way forward.

We have just had an American election. It was the greatest show of democracy on earth, with 180 million people voting—voting by their own free will. They elected a Democrat President on the basis of a policy of inclusion, of bringing people together, of not letting an underclass develop, of not letting people fall behind, of the American economy and society growing together, of joining together and sharing American prosperity.

The Opposition wants to throw that huge mandate to one side and go back to the dismal policies of Margaret Thatcher in the late 1970s and Ronald Reagan. If it gives a tax cut, the wealthy will do so well. As they power along, the ordinary people will be sucked along in the vortex and they will get something from it. In fact, they got sucked into unemployment and got nothing from it.

You will see in today's Australian Financial Review—or was it the Sydney Morning Herald ?—a critical treatise on the lost years of Thatcher and what has emerged in Britain from the same sorts of policies that you do not have the wit to change and which you offer us today. Then you talk today about Australia being on the brink of a depression and you quote me. When I made that remark in 1985 we were powering along, the labour market was growing hand over fist. The economy was growing again. There was no risk of my remark breaking the back of public confidence and pushing us back into recession, as your remark today about a depression was calculated to do. Basically, you will score off anybody to make your own way.

Now the Leader of the Opposition makes this plaintive plea to a basically unimpressed and uninterested back bench as he stands up and talks about his policies. Then I heard him say that I should go out and understand people. He says I should meet people—like he did at the ball the other night for the Grand Prix in Adelaide; like he does up at Mount Panorama with the millionaires' $200,000 toys; like he does on the $100,000 yachts on Sydney Harbour; like he does being a grease monkey on a $400,000 Ferrari or a $500,000 Lamborghini Muira. Those are his interests. They are not going out and meeting ordinary people who are affected by the ebb and flow of the economy, who live on the economy for its prosperity and need the public sector for its support. Those are not the people he listens to. He listens to the comfortable, the well-off, the smug, the people who have done well enough, he thinks. Those are the people that he identifies with. Those are the people he wants to be part of.

I reject the Leader of the Opposition's censure motion. In his first remark he said that the Government had knowingly and willingly inflicted hardship, but he knows everything the Government is doing is about changing that hardship. I move:

That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `this House censures the Opposition Leader for advocating policies which would contract fiscal policy, remove unemployment benefits after nine months, impose a 15 per goods and services tax and introduce a confrontationist industrial relations policy, all of which would retard economic growth and result in more severe unemployment'.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the appropriate position of the House. The fact is that the Opposition does not have policies that will help a recovery; they will only hinder a recovery. Its policies are not the policies for Australia right now. That may be becoming apparent to it. If that is the case, it explains some of the dismal reception his Party gave the Leader of the Opposition when he made that speech—as I said at the start of my speech—without flair or substance. It was a speech in which he basically rambled through a set of remarks he felt compelled to make and none of which he believed. We reject the censure out of hand. I reject the censure out of hand. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We reject out of hand your minute and give it the treatment it deserves. It lacks policy and it lacks substance, just as did the speech we have just heard from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I say to the Prime Minister: if you think that in response to the 11.3 per cent unemployment rate a series of personal abuses directed at the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and our policy will be seen by the Australian public as responsible, then you have another think coming. The one thing that this figure screams out for is a substantial alternative economic policy to give this country a sense of hope; to give people the chance of a job which this Government's policy has taken from them.

PARA.TAB: It was a classic response from the Prime Minister today. There was no admission of responsibility. We would never know that he was Treasurer for nine years and that for the last year he has been Prime Minister and responsible for economic management in this country. What we get instead is personal abuse: the lies and the misrepresentations which he thinks he can use as a basis for going into the next election. I say: take your hypocrisy to the Australian people and they will reject you out of hand. You ought to take it to them now because this country needs change and the first thing we ought to change is the Government.

If ever there was a Prime Minister who deserved censure, it is the Prime Minister of today, Prime Minister Keating. If ever we had proof positive of the failure of his economic policy, we have it today with the release of today's unemployment figure of 11.3 per cent. Politically, for the Labor Party, today is its death knell—and deservedly so, as it deliberately engineered this recession and caused huge pain and hardship right across this country.

Today Australia is in crisis. There is no question whatsoever that we are in danger of drifting towards a depression. It is no good the Australian people, Australian politicians or community leaders burying their heads in the sand about the extent of our problems. It is no good this Government saying that we are not to have a realistic assessment of Australia's problems because that will impact upon confidence. The reality is that the first thing we need in this country is a fair and honest statement of our circumstances. Until we get that fair and honest assessment, we will not gather up the constituency for change.

I say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and, in a sense, for this country: there is no choice about it; we will have to change. The only question outstanding is whether or not we will finally, as a nation, see our problems and deal with them today or—as the Prime Minister wants us to do—bury our heads in the sand and to let the damage that we do to ourselves be exacerbated in the years ahead, in which case that damage will be much greater. We say: let us get on with the job. Let us make the changes that will give this country the hope that it deserves.

I was delighted that the Leader of the Opposition in his censure motion finished with that spirit of optimism about the future of this country which all Australians deserve to have. This is a great country, with great people. It is one of the great democracies in the Western world, with great resources. We ought to have a country where people have the right to a job. Yet the plain truth of the matter is that in the last 10, 15 or 20 years we have not managed our country as well as we ought to have. We ought to recognise that fact and get on with the change.

Let us look at the factors which see us today drifting towards a depression: first, yesterday Westpac revised down our latest growth estimates for 1993. Secondly, Access Economics said, `When you look at the people who would like to work more, in addition to those who are actually unemployed, we do not have 11.3 per cent unemployed; we have about 20 per cent of our population underemployed'—not 11.3 per cent, but one in five Australians looking for work. Thirdly, yesterday the Department of Employment Education and Training, in commenting on future employment growth and in commenting on its leading indicator series, said, `Employment growth in the future is likely to be very sluggish'. Fourthly, in looking at those factors which lead you to that conclusion that Australia is drifting aimlessly towards a depression, let us look at the latest ANZ job advertisements. Basically, it was a 1.6 per cent figure lower than the previous month. Basically, that series is very flat.

Fifthly, the September retail trade figures actually fell by 0.3 per cent. A month or so after this Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) went out to the Australian people and said, `Spend, spend, spend', the latest retail trade figures came back with a fall. That is a critical factor in assessing where the economy is today, because it has been one of those aspects of the economy which the Government has been relying upon in its claims that we have today a recovery.

September motor vehicle registrations fell by 3.8 per cent. September dwelling approvals fell by 1.2 per cent. Business and personal bankruptcies, on the latest annual figures, are up 16,780, by 28 per cent. Our gross debt is now $185 billion—up massively since Labor first came into office when in net figures it was around $23 billion.

The latest balance of payments figure is up to $1.5 billion. We are racking up extra debt and living beyond our means month after month. In the latest month we saw imports go up a whopping 20 per cent—exports up by only 11 per cent. The latest National Australia Bank survey out on 4 November stated that the `economy remains locked in a pedestrian recovery with little prospect of any marked reduction in unemployment during 1992-93'. Then there is today's crippling unemployment figure of 11.3 per cent, with 979,900 Australians unemployed—the worst figures since the Depression. These figures are thoroughly bad in every possible way. There is no saving grace. There are no excuses. I was very surprised by the Prime Minister today. When the first question was put to him about the gravity of Australia's unemployment figure, as released today, his first response was to find an excuse for it and to say that it was not as bad as it seemed. I will come back to that in a moment.

Full time employment actually fell. Sure, part time employment went up a bit. That is to be expected, because people who cannot get a full time job will take anything; they will take a part time job if they can. Unemployment for males is now the highest ever—11.9 per cent. The trend estimate for adults in full time unemployment—that is, males and females—continues to increase. The trend unemployment rate—that is the figure that the Treasurer has so much trouble with; honourable members may remember that we asked him a question a month ago and he got that wrong—is slowly rising, and today we have the very high figure of 11.1 per cent. The Prime Minister's excuse was, `Oh, well, the participation rate'—which simply goes to the number of people who are actually looking for work—`is volatile and, therefore, that is an explanation for what happened today'.

Some of the Labor Party clones in the press gallery are saying, `Is this not a statistical blip?'. Well, it is not, because the figures show that the participation rate now is the same as it was 12 months ago. In fact, on the trend basis, it has basically been steady for 18 months. That is no excuse—it is just a technical aside to try to give this Government some basis upon which to avoid the gravity of Australia's circumstances.

So for all of those reasons we say that Australia is in danger of drifting towards a depression. We do not use those words lightly. In fact, we gave a lot of consideration to the use of those words. But it is revealing that, back in 1982, this Government, these members—then in opposition—had absolutely no hesitation in describing those circumstances in 1982 clearly as a depression.

As was quoted in Question Time, in November 1985 the Prime Minister described the state of the economy in 1982 as being in a depression. The Treasurer, who will speak next, has no answer to explain why it was a depression then but it is not now. In November 1983, when employment was only 9.7 per cent, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Yet they have the nerve to say that we will not be able to turn round as quickly as we would like the devastating depression in which we found this economy.
I can go on. The then shadow Treasurer said:

PARA.TAB: I need hardly tell the House that we are suffering depression conditions in Australia at present due to the wrong economic strategy being pursued by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: That was in September 1982, when unemployment was 7.4 per cent. In order to academically analyse this, we must look at the definition by the Pocket Economist, which is well regarded around the world. It defines `depression' as `a long lasting recession in economic activity'. There are many other such definitions. I do not say that it is like the 1930s depression; of course, it is not. But it is interesting to look at the unemployment rate in the 1930s. In 1930 it was 9.78 per cent. It then rose during the 1930s, to 10.98 per cent in 1936. In 1937 it was 8.83 per cent, in 1938 it was 7.46 per cent, and in 1939 it was 8.76 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The Government's response to this originally was to deny the recession. When the recession was obvious even to the Government, it said it was a recession that we had to have. Within months of the Government saying that we were in a recession, it was claiming that we were in a recovery. The Government has been saying for about two years that we are now in a recovery. We had the incredible claim again today, effectively repeated by the Prime Minister, that the recession was over long ago. I think that is a sick, arrogant claim to make when we have the highest unemployment since the Great Depression. This man who stands here and says that the recession is over and that we are in a recovery deserves the greatest censure possible by this Parliament.

The Government's first claim is simply a series of lies. Its second claim—that it is addressing and fixing the problem—can be put in the same category. That was the claim made when the Government brought down its alternative statement, One Nation, back in February. That has been a spectacular failure; so spectacular that the Government has had to redirect the money into make work schemes painting white rocks in local government areas and try to desperately spend a few dollars between now and the next election. It is a spectacular failure of policy for which the Government again ought to be condemned—and, of course, it is all funded by borrowings when this country is already up to its neck in debt.

The third set of responses we have from this Government involves attacking us again. The classic attack in the last few days has been on the Kennett Government in Victoria for introducing reforms which the Government says are simply replicas of our proposals. Without going into detail, the reality is that Australia must change its industrial relations. In Victoria, the first major policy that Jeff Kennett announced was a complete reform of industrial relations. Those opposite and the trade union movement attacked him up hill and down dale for the whole of the five or six weeks of that campaign. For that policy he secured a historic mandate.

Since then, those opposite have done everything to undermine the mandate of a duly elected government. They have the gall to come in here and talk about the majesty of democracy when in their very actions they deny the majesty of democracy in one of the key States of this country. We have to change in this country, and it will be an eternal legacy and to the damnation of those opposite if they should oppose the essential reforms that that Government is bringing in.

Lastly, the third set of responses is basically to lie and cheat and to cover up. In recent days, on the second big issue in this country—debt—we have seen an exercise in cover-up by the Treasurer of this country. In the last Budget he failed to disclose a massive breach of the borrowing requirements of Victoria when it blew out its debt by $1.2 billion. He has failed to release that minute of 6 July. He has released the one of 23 July but he has failed to release the minute of 6 July, for which he ought to be damned. It is yet another cover-up. It is no good the Treasurer threatening with legal action those newspapers that simply record the voice of the people which says that he ought to give evidence and he ought to release the documents. This Government ought to be censured. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the recurring puzzlements about the gentleman who has just

SPEECH.PARA: resumed his seat, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable for Flinders (Mr Reith), is that he always starts off his remarks by saying that what the country needs is an accurate assessment of the problems confronting the economy. Then within a matter of minutes we find him incapable of controlling his natural tendency to exaggerate, to engage in hyperbole and, if necessary, to distort and deceive.

PARA.TAB: In the context of his description of Australia's circumstance, he used, first of all, the word `depression', which he knows is wrong. Indeed, half of his speech seemed to be dedicated towards giving an apologia for the fact that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) had made this ridiculous assertion about drifting into depression. But I will come back to that in a moment. Secondly, he moved on to say that the real level of unemployment in Australia was 20 per cent.

This is the man who says we ought to have an accurate analysis and an accurate description of the country's economy and who then drifts immediately into distortion and hyperbole, firstly, by calling it a depression—which I think he said he picked up from the Pocket Economist. I guess that is the only textbook he has ever been able to master. He said he picked up the idea that this was a depression from the Pocket Economist. Secondly, he said that the unemployment rate, if accurately measured, would be 20 per cent.

But I think the most fascinating part of the honourable member's remarks was when he said, `We gave very great thought to whether or not we should use this word "depression"'. Why did those opposite bother thinking about it? I am sure they had the thing written even before the figures came out. In any event, I do not sit around waiting breathlessly for the next press statement from the Leader of the Opposition or his Deputy. But I understand that a matter of minutes after the release of the ABS figures the Leader of the Opposition was out there in front of the microphones and then his statement came out a few minutes later. In his doorstop interview he talked about a depression and in his statement he talked about a depression—all of which had emerged within minutes of the ABS data being made available to the Opposition.

So this is what those opposite call weighty consideration as to whether or not they should use this word `depression'. You can imagine the Deputy Leader of the Opposition flicking through the Pocket Economist to find out the accurate description of the circumstances confronting Australia and then giving very careful consideration as to whether or not the Opposition should actually latch onto this idea of a depression.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition and his Leader made the very great error of comparing the current circumstance with that in 1982 and trying to say that, because some expressions might have been used to refer to that as a depression, that somehow justifies their making these remarks now. As I said before, a depression and a recession are actually technical terms—something which the honourable member for Flinders, even with his Pocket Economist, has not been able to grasp. But what they refer to is the period of time during which the economy is actually contracting.

In the September quarter of 1982 we saw the economy contract by one per cent, and in the December quarter we saw it contract again by 0.6 per cent. Yet what have we seen in the June quarter this year? We have actually seen an expansion of a little over half a per cent and, indeed, we have had something like three-quarters of the economy expanding—although not rapidly and not as rapidly as we would like. But it is a total contradiction of the idea of a depression.

Whereas in 1982 we had successive quarters of negative growth, here we have had successive quarters of positive growth. Yet we see the Leader of the Opposition and his pathetic Deputy saying that somehow this is evidence that Australia is drifting into depression. It just demonstrates either how they have totally lost the plot in terms of what is happening to the economy or, alternatively, how they will do anything and say anything in order to make a fairly cheap point.

But at whose expense are these points being made? Is this description of the economy something which is likely to hurt us, the Government—us as individuals—or is it more likely calculated to hurt the economy, to depress confidence and in fact hold back the recovery which is under way in Australia? The recurring theme in Liberal Party politics and attitudes over the last 10 years has been to wait for the circumstances in which the economy would be in that condition which would justify the election of a Liberal government. We heard it from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) in his wonderful remark: `The times will suit me'. Now we see it recurring. The Leader of the Opposition is simply returning to that theme which suggests that things are so bad that only a change of government can fix the problem.

If the Opposition had just one responsibility today in moving its censure against the Government on this question it was to put forward a policy for dealing with the issue which it had identified—high unemployment. That was the issue those opposite had to confront today if anyone was to take them seriously in this debate. On that point they both failed comprehensively. They failed to substantiate the claim that they had any answer to these questions. I repeat: the fact that they would make the distinction between now and 10 years ago is simply to underscore the fact that 10 years ago they were bereft of policy and it required a Labor government to come in and deal with the simultaneous questions of unemployment and high inflation.

Once again, we find the Liberal Party and its National Party of Australia colleagues totally bereft and at sea in terms of the policy issue. As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said, because of this absence of policy—the absence of an ability to address these questions—those opposite have essentially disqualified themselves from this debate. Only those who are prepared to talk about approaches which will help the problem rather than exacerbate it are qualified to talk in this debate.

I do not want to contend with this issue simply on the basis of some political argy-bargy across the table; this is far too serious an issue to deal with in that way. There are 900,000-plus people out there looking for work and this has been the consuming concern of this Government for as long as that has been the circumstance in Australia. That is why we have spent our every waking moment trying to find ways of dealing with this question in circumstances where the world economy is sluggish and where we know there are limits to the extent to which Australia can act independently in order to spur the economy. But we have taken that action which we thought was responsible, the action which we thought we could take independently and responsibly, in order to deal with Australian circumstances.

That is why we have acted on about a dozen occasions to reduce interest rates in order to provide a monetary policy setting conducive to expansion in Australia. That is why we, ahead of the rest of the world, decided that engaging in some fiscal stimulus was an appropriate policy mechanism to use in Australia's circumstances. Yet what is the curious thing about this? Indeed, the fatuous thing about this is that on every one of those occasions when this Government acted to provide some boost to the Australian economy what was the response of the Opposition?

Its response was to oppose it. It opposed every reduction in interest rates; it opposed our actions on a couple of occasions to expand the economy through the Budget sector. Now we find the conclusive evidence that the action that we took in February, and again in the Budget, is in fact the policy prescription which is now being condoned, ratified and encouraged by the OECD. The OECD has said as a result of a meeting of its economic policy committee that countries of the developed world need to employ some stimulus through their budgets in order to provide some encouragement for the otherwise disappointing level of world economic growth.

This was precisely the assessment that we made when we decided to take those actions in February and again in the Budget. So we now have commentators saying that no country has moved monetary policy as far as Australia has, and no country—with the possible exception of Japan—has moved as we have moved in order to provide a stimulus to get our economy moving along a little faster.

But, again, what has been the response of the Opposition to each and every one of those policy actions on the part of the Government? It has either opposed them or ridiculed them as being inappropriate for Australia's circumstances. Not only do those opposite have us to argue with, but they have the collective wisdom of the economists of the developed world, as represented by the OECD, who are not only condoning what we have done but are actually encouraging other members of the developed world to follow our lead. They say that one or two countries acting in isolation are not enough to encourage the world economy. We need other members of the developed world to engage in that policy prescription as well.

I might say—and this is an important point—that not all countries had the kind of flexibility and the room to move as we did. So many other countries failed to take the opportunity that we took in the late 1980s to repair our Budget position, to return our Budget to surplus during the good times so that on this occasion we had the capacity to expand our fiscal activity in order to provide a stimulus necessary for moving the economy along.

Yet, far from having policies which might help, the Opposition simply trots out again and again these policy prescriptions which it has dredged up from the early 1980s and the late 1970s, pretending that in some way they have some relevance to Australia's contemporary position. Those opposite do not seem to realise that the rest of the world has totally passed them by. Even that small number of countries which actually followed Thatcher—Thatcher and her very few acolytes—have abandoned those policies.

But there is one acolyte left—just one acolyte left in the world—and he sits here as the alternative Prime Minister of Australia, trying to visit upon Australia those policies which Mrs Thatcher manufactured for Britain and which, as a result of their implementation, have left Britain weakened and paralysed as a member of the European community. Even her own party has abandoned those policies. Yet we still have one remaining fan, one remaining antipodean fan all the way down in Australia, wanting to deliver the same wreckage on Australia that Mrs Thatcher delivered to the people of Britain.

Anyone who goes to Britain now sees a country in despair—a country whose industrial structure has basically been shattered, a country whose social security system is frankly a disgrace, and a country which seems to have abandoned concern for those who now make up an increasing part of the underclass of the British community. But, you clots, you cannot see what your Leader is trying to do to you. You cannot see what your Leader is trying to do to Australia. He is trying to recycle these failed policies and implement them in a country which not only does not need them but has demonstrated, in its own way, a better set of policies designed to deal with our particular circumstances.

This Opposition is really about the further disparagement of Australia and the further disparagement of the Australian people, whilst at the same time never being prepared to confront what it would do about this issue of unemployment. I mentioned before that the Leader of the Opposition is on record as saying that he will give no promises on unemployment and that there will be transitional effects leading to higher unemployment. Yet he has the nerve and the cheek to come in here and to dare to condemn and to attempt to censure this Government, which has done so much to repair the circumstances which we inherited and to set Australia up for a prosperous future. He could not even begin to imagine the way in which to achieve it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the following report: 320th—Review of six performance audits.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make some brief comments in relation to the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled Review of six performance audits. Under the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951, the Committee is required to examine all reports of the Auditor-General, including reports of efficiency audits. In report No. 320 the Committee examined six reports of the Auditor-General, covering two efficiency audits and four project performance audits. These were tabled between May 1990 and April 1991.

PARA.TAB: These Auditor-General's reports cover a variety of programs and departments, including the Department of Defence, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Department of Social Security, the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Administrative Services. Responses by departments to the audit reports and recommendations were encouraging, with most of the recommendations being accepted by the auditees.

However the Committee, in its review of projects in all the departments considered in this report, observed common problems with information technology projects. The management, control and coordination of projects were areas in which all departments had encountered difficulties. These included inadequate prior planning, failure to monitor changes in cost-benefit ratios, loss of sight of the original objectives of projects, failure to undertake post implementation review, inadequate training of staff and using new IT systems, and failure to prepare adequate system documentation and user manuals.

The Committee also draws attention to specific failings by the Department of Defence in its implementation of an appropriate information system for monitoring maintenance and utilisation of aircraft and some other equipment. The Committee makes recommendations in the report addressing these issues. The most important focus of report No. 320 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which reviews six of the Auditor-General performance audits, is on increasing the accountability of Government agencies to the Parliament. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill amends the Trade Practices Act in three significant respects: in respect of the merger test; in respect of unconscionable conduct; and in respect of penalties. The three proposals can be variously described as good, bad and ugly. No section of the Trade Practices Act has provided more controversy than section 50, which deals with mergers and acquisitions. At present, the Trade Practices Act prevents a corporation from buying another company, merging or acquiring its assets if that would lead to market dominance. The original test which was inserted in the Trade Practices Act in 1974 prohibited mergers or acquisitions where they would lead to a substantial lessening of competition.

PARA.TAB: In 1977 the section was amended to reflect the philosophy that there should be no legislative or administrative impediment to attainment by Australian industry of efficiency and international competitiveness. That change was introduced by the then coalition Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). The Minister, in his second reading speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: There should be no unnecessary impediment, legislative or administrative, to the attainment of rationalisation of Australian industry. It is in Australia's best interest to achieve economies of sale and improved international competitiveness.

In 1984 the Labor Government produced a Green Paper floating the possibility of returning to the pre-1977 merger test. It found no favour for that proposal in any responsible quarter. When section 50 was amended in 1986 by the then Labor Government under Attorney-General Bowen, the Government did not change the dominance threshold. Lionel Bowen reaffirmed the Government's support for the dominance test and said:

The Government is firmly committed to the encouragement of efficient Australian industry and to increasing our competitiveness on world markets. It has been decided that the existing dominance test in section 50 should remain essentially unchanged. The coverage of section 50 will not be extended beyond those mergers which would result in undue concentration in a market.

But the ink had hardly dried before Senator Tate, the then Acting Attorney-General, requested a House of Representatives legal and constitutional affairs committee to take another look. That inquiry, which was chaired by the current Minister for Tourism and Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), reported in May of 1989. It supported the retention of the current dominance test and noted that there was insufficient justification to recommend any amendments to the dominance test. In relation to returning to a substantial lessening of competition test, it also had this to say:

It is widely accepted that this test would involve a significant lowering of the threshold, thereby subjecting a wider range of mergers to TPC scrutiny. This proposal would, therefore, have significant resource implications for the TPC. It would also reduce the level of harmonisation of Australian and New Zealand merger law. In addition, a return to the pre-1977 test would involve increased uncertainty for business, and may, therefore, impede decision making processes.

That statement, which was made by the current Minister for Tourism and Minister for Resources, is as true today as it was when he made it. In looking at the possible change of the merger test as part of that inquiry, the Trade Practices Commission was among those who argued against changing the test. The Griffiths committee summarised the view of the Trade Practices Commission as follows:

The TPC believes that the test is likely to inhibit desirable industry rationalisation and may create more uncertainty for business. A significant widening of the threshold may, it argued, result in pressure to return to formal clearances, which delay the merger process. The TPC also put forward the view that the test of substantial lessening of competition is not a certain instrument, as there is not a strong body of law associated with it.

The Government supported the findings of the Griffiths committee. In August 1991, in a good statement on the Committee's report by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy)—he was still good on this issue in August of 1991, still thinking clearly about it, before his judgment was clouded by lobbying that he was unable to stand up to and unable to intellectually match—he said:
Like the Committee, it—
that is, the Government—
is not convinced that there is sufficient justification for reverting to the `substantial lessening of competition' test in merger cases.

That was in August 1991. But in the meantime, a Senate committee had been set up to look into the matter. That Senate committee was chaired by Senator Cooney. After it looked at the matter, that Senate committee came to the conclusion that the test ought to be changed and recommended a shopping list of factors to be taken into account to determine when companies could buy the assets or merge with other corporations.

PARA.TAB: What had changed between the holding of the Griffiths committee and the report of the Cooney committee was the view of the Trade Practices Commission or, rather to be more precise, what had changed was the Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission. Professor Fels, as the new Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, proved an indefatigable lobbyist, going around to the Senate committee, going around to the print media inquiry, going around to the Minister, going around to other Ministers, going around to the Opposition, lobbying for a wider test which, incidentally, would increase the jurisdiction of the Trade Practices Commission to have a hand in determining the circumstances in which companies could buy assets or shares of other companies and also, incidentally, in determining the circumstances in which companies could sell and shareholders could sell shares or assets to others.

Apart from the indefatigable work of Professor Fels, who proved a great Sir Humphrey Appleby to the Attorney-General's Jim Hacker and who managed to completely turn his own Minister on this particular question, the other development that seemed to carry some time with the Cooney committee was the work of Harvard Professor Michael Porter on the subject in a book entitled The Competitive Advantage of Nations. Professor Porter's work was important work. It is good work and it needs to be studied carefully. Professor Porter's work did not deal with any Australian conditions. It did not deal with the type of legislation which would be needed to bring about strong domestic competition and it has nowhere been shown that it was apposite or relevant to Australian conditions. Warren Pengilley, a former Trade Practices Commissioner, remarked:

SPEECH.PARA: A merger provision may be based on a dominance test and still deliver the effective competition which Professor Porter advocates—especially if other barriers to entry are small or non-existent.

If we are to adopt the test that is proposed in this particular Bill, which moves away from the current dominance test, we would be moving in the opposite direction to trends in comparable industrialised countries. We would be moving away from the test in the European community, in Germany, in France and in New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: At a time when we are trying to harmonise our business law with that of New Zealand so that competition issues can be applied uniformly across the Tasman, we are disharmonising our merger test with this particular proposal. It is not just people such as former trade practices chairmen Professor Baxt, Bob McComas and others who have argued against taking this particular step. The proposal which is put by this Government in this Bill—a bad proposal—is opposed by the Business Council of Australia, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the MTIA, the Law Council and the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants. It was also opposed by the former Attorney-General, Mr Bowen, the Minister for Resources and Minister for Tourism, and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), who did not want a straight shift from dominance to substantially lessening competition. Up until recently, it was opposed by the present Attorney-General. It is, of course, opposed by the coalition.

More nonsense has been spoken on this subject than on just about any other subject in the Trade Practices Act, and there has been less light shed upon it and clear analysis as to what the outcome of this will be. For example, of the shopping list of nine factors that are supposedly to be taken into account by the Trade Practices Commission, at least five of them are already taken into account under the existing dominance test. At least five of them are taken into account in applying the current test as laid down in cases such as the Ansett-Avis case and the most recent case of Australian Meat Holdings.

The Government is now trying to have a substantial lessening of competition test when we do not have a substantial lessening of competition test. It is saying, `Change the test, but take into account nine factors'—five of which are already taken into account—`and see what comes out of it'. What makes that wrong is that it has taken at least a decade to get some certainty into what this test means in practice so that companies know when they can make offers for the purchase of shares and assets. Then the Government comes along, in its magesterial wisdom, and says, `That can all be thrown away; a new test can be imposed' and it throws into convulsion the accepted law. It will take perhaps another decade before business is in a position where it can ascertain in what circumstances it can, and in what circumstances it cannot, make offers.

Section 50 is the only section of the Trade Practices Act that deals with market structure. The balance deals with market conduct. When we come to market conduct, we should always take a very strong line in favour of competitiveness. But structure and conduct are not the same thing. We can say that a certain kind of structure will inevitably lead to uncompetitive conduct and if we can say that it ought to be banned. But if we cannot say that a particular market structure inevitably leads to that kind of conduct, there is no reason why the Government should intervene in the market, impose this regulation and direct itself to market structure. It is not the structure that is the crime when it comes to competition, it is the conduct.

In due course—and I will come to this matter—this Bill also proposes increased fines for anti-competitive conduct. We support those increased fines. We believe that when anti-competitive conduct is found it ought to be punished severely—whether it be by corporations, whether it be by government business enterprises or, indeed, whether it be by trade unions. It is trade unions that so often inhibit competitiveness in modern Australian society. The proposal to change the merger test is a bad one.

The second proposal in this particular amendment is in relation to unconscionable conduct. Currently, the Trade Practices Act says that, in consumer transactions where unconscionable conduct occurs, proceedings can be taken to prevent it. It lists various matters, such as inequality of bargaining power, that can be taken into account. A report into small business was conducted in the previous Parliament by the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) which recommended extending that provision into all commercial contracts.

I argued strongly and strenuously against that. I did not believe that there was a warrant to extend that new statutory cause of action across the whole gamut of commercial contracts: to allow new causes of action to be developed, to throw into the courts the rewriting of contracts and to allow judges to second guess commercial realities. As part of my argument against it, I noted that recent developments in the High Court and elsewhere were extending all the time the existing avenues by which inequitable dealing could be struck down. In cases such as Amadio and Blomley v. Ryan the doctrine of equity was developing new remedies. We ought to recognise those new remedies and allow the courts to develop them, as they have done.

The good thing about it is that the Attorney-General changed his mind. When it went to Cabinet he issued a press release saying that the Cabinet was going to change section 52A and was going to extend it. He is on record and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is on record. The good thing about this proposal is that the Attorney-General did not do what he said he was going to do. That was the good thing about it. I welcome that.

This proposal does not extend section 52A to commercial contracts. The Attorney-General may not have picked it up yet and maybe his Department has not informed him what is in the legislation. The legislation adopts the common law as it applies from time to time. It recognises that the common law, as it applies from time to time, is developing these remedies; these remedies which can be availed of regardless of whether or not we enact this section. But by enacting this section, they can be investigated by the Trade Practices Commission and one can effectively seek them under the Trade Practices Act. Whilst I vigorously opposed the Government's original proposal, I support this proposal. It is, as I said earlier, the good proposal. The good thing about this proposal is that the Minister reversed his original stand.

We now come to the ugly provision of this particular Bill: the provision that says conduct which breaches part IV of the Trade Practices Act, conduct that is anti-competitive, will incur higher fines. This Bill will increase the fine for corporations to $10m—a fortyfold increase. I think the Parliament should say that we consider anti-competitive conduct seriously and a wide range of fines ought to be imposed against it. But a little piece of this Bill is utterly offensive.

When the Government went through this Bill and increased the fines fortyfold to $10m, two sections were left out: two sections that just happen to be ones which can be applied against the anti-competitive conduct of trade unions. Sections 45D and 45E will be quarantined in this particular part from any increase in penalties. What that means is that for trade unions which offend against those provisions the penalty stays at $250,000, whereas for corporations that offend against the balance of that part the fines go to $10m. In other words, the Government wants a penalty for its friends in the trade union movement which is 40 times less than the penalty that applies to corporations which breach the balance of that part.

When it comes to applying penalties, there is one principle of the law: equal penalties for offences against a statute, regardless of the identity of the offender. That is what equality of the law is all about: equal penalties, equal treatment. But the Attorney-General cannot bring himself to do it. By reason of the fact that the trade union movement has such a hold over his Government, he cannot treat the trade union movement equally by subjecting it to equal penalties. An Attorney-General who cannot treat offenders against the law in an equal way is somebody who does not warrant being an Attorney-General. He has taken an absolutely shameful position. It is Labor's special rates for its special mates.

The justification is even worse: the Attorney-General says, `Nobody has enforced the law, therefore we don't need to increase the penalties'. Where does that argument lead us? Nobody enforced the laws against the corporate high-fliers. Does that mean we should not increase penalties against that kind of conduct? Is that what it means? The Attorney-General has not sought to enforce the law because he has run dead. He has now taken the position that he does not need to increase the penalties. First of all the Attorney-General goes to sleep and then he entrenches a special privilege in the statute in favour of those constituent organisations that nourish and nurture him and then ask of him special treatment and special favours when he comes to exercise the duties of a Minister of the Crown.

The Attorney-General ought to be ashamed of himself. It may be that he was done over by other Ministers in Cabinet, but if he had any substance to him, he would have stood up to them. He would have made sure that he had equal treatment for them and he would have taken the position that he knows is right. But for the guillotine, I would have moved the amendment circulated in my name, which will have the effect of making equal penalties under part IV apply to trade unions as much as to anybody else.
