DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Robert Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments proposed in the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) in respect of nursing homes will give effect to some of the aged care measures announced in the 1992-93 Budget. Other amendments regarding sanctions against hostels failing to comply with standards of care were foreshadowed some time ago and so are not new to the aged care industry.

PARA.TAB: Amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act allow for the introduction of sanctions against hostels which fail to comply with standards of care and quality of life for residents. The amendments also provide for the establishment of hospital standards review panels. These amendments bring procedures for hostels into line with those for nursing homes, whereby the Commonwealth can take action if nursing home owners are not providing residents with the quality of life and care required by gazetted standards.

The amendments allow the Government to suspend payment, in respect of new residents, to a hostel not complying with the standards. The amendments also provide a peer review mechanism, called hostel standards review panels, for hostel operators who want a review of an assessment of the hostel's standards. If these panels recommend to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) that a declaration of failure to comply is appropriate, they may also recommend that the Commonwealth suspend the payment of financial assistance to the hostel for new residents. A similar sanction has been available in parallel circumstances for nursing home operators since 1991. During that time, the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services has taken this course of action against 12 nursing homes. The Opposition, however, on examining the details of these amendments, does not propose to oppose them.

The Bill also seeks to amend the National Health Act in order to implement funding announced in the Budget to upgrade nursing homes. The Opposition is pleased to see this funding, however we note that the funding is limited and not all nursing homes seeking upgrading funding are likely to receive it. Many nursing home proprietors, while aiming to provide good quality care, have difficulty in meeting the Government's outcome standards, or health and fire safety standards, because they are operating in old or unsuitable buildings. This amendment will enable nursing home proprietors to apply for funds for upgrading work which has been identified as necessary for the well-being of their residents but which they might not otherwise be able to afford.

The Bill also makes provision for a nursing home adviser to be appointed to a nursing home that has breached the conditions of approval. The role of the adviser will be to assist the proprietor of the home to comply with the conditions of approval and will usually be someone with experience in the management of aged care facilities. Advisers will be appointed for a specific period, and their services will be paid for by the proprietor. If the owner were unwilling to accept and pay for an adviser, the normal sanctions process would continue, including closing the home if that became necessary.

This Bill has not demonstrated that the Labor Party is in touch with the real needs of the frail aged and the aged care industry overall. On 30 September, Aged Care Australia placed an advertisement in the Sydney Morning Herald which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of discussions at the Aged Care Australia annual meeting in Canberra on September 21 and 22 it was agreed—
1. That Aged Care Australia no longer has confidence in the Commonwealth Government's implementation of the aged care reform strategy flowing from the nursing home and hostels review of 1986.
2. That Aged Care Australia refutes the notion that the Commonwealth Government has effectively consulted with and listened to this association in the past in implementing the stages of the reform.
3. That Aged Care Australia is committed to the production of alternative policies and procedures for aged care delivery in Australia.

The fact that this organisation, the peak body representing aged persons hostels around the country, felt strongly enough to protest in this public way is a gross indictment of the Government's policies over the last 10 years. What confidence can older Australians have in the Government's long term care policies when one of Australia's largest aged care organisations has been forced to say that it has no confidence in this Labor Government?

PARA.TAB: There are very few of these organisations. They may disagree with governments from time to time, but rarely do they go through the process of taking space and advertising in the public dailies and stating to the nation as a whole that they do not have confidence in the policies of a government. Aged Care Australia contacted the Opposition, listing its concerns in a letter which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: These concerns have increased with the introduction of more and more bureaucratic requirements and the continued transfer of funds from the care of older people to Government administration. Time formerly devoted to the delivery of care is increasingly having to be used to meet excessive paperwork requirements and organisations providing care believe that the quality of care being given to residents is now declining.

Unfair practices by the Government in the application of the subjective assessment and validation process accuses staff and organisations of dishonesty and makes good management impossible due to the uncertainty which the process introduces.

It is not possible to manage effectively when tens of thousands of dollars can be withdrawn from an organisation by targeting borderline assessments which are redetermined, not on the care of the resident, but on whether there is sufficient documentation.

The Commonwealth Government is presiding over an aged care system which is now stretched to the limits and being increasingly pressured through funding cuts and is drowning in paperwork. Highly skilled long term workers are leaving because they are interested in providing care not in doing paperwork, they want to be able to spend time with residents and not always be rushed through a series of basic clinical tasks.
The following are extracts taken from a letter from a very experienced Director of Nursing:
`The system is unworkable.
Staff are demoralised.
The questions on behaviour are offensive.
The paperwork is intrusive and insurmountable to get through.
The increased documentation is taking floor hours away from the residents.
Age care accommodation complexes live in fear.

The kind of care we give is labour intensive. To keep the policies and the lifestyle we had in those years preceding the RCI's alive I have to work harder and it is telling on my health. As the paper work mounts up I can no longer face my desk. The system is collapsing around my ears and something that was good in the past is slowly crumbling.
In this facility alone we have 17 feeds for 3 meals a day. How can we do this with dignity? Do we document or feed?
Everyone in the community is different and as a nurse I have accepted those differences without question. Now all those differences are documented, if it is possible to document them.

The paperwork is intrusive and insurmountable to get through. The industry is watching the Department. The Department is watching the industry. Surveys come from everywhere, universities, consultant organisations set up by individuals and the Department. There are residents agreements which they can't and are frightened to sign and relatives who would rather not sign on their parents behalf especially if it is to do with the Government. All staff are working unpaid hours to try to get on top of this workload.

I challenge the nurses working in the Department as validation officers to work one week in a nursing home under the policies of that particular nursing home and get through the workload without extending their hours.
The nurses in the hostel are taking work home as it is impossible for them to complete it due to constant interruptions.'

Aged Care Queensland fully supports appropriate standards of care and the need to be accountable. However, there needs to be a simpler, more efficient system of assessment, funding and standards monitoring, which is designed to help meet the needs of the individual in their own home or a residential care facility of their choice.

These letters are merely indicative of the problems facing the industry at the coalface. It is one thing for a department to be able to establish massive and intrusive organisational requirements determined from the centre in Canberra, but it is quite another—especially in the environment in which many aged care providers are operating—to be able to meet those standards and at the same time provide a necessary and adequate level of support and assistance for their patients.

PARA.TAB: The question I have to ask is this: why does the Government not listen to industry concerns? We have heard nothing from the Minister on this matter. I do not believe there would be a member of this House who has not received representations from nursing homes and hostel managers in their electorates saying more or less the same things that were said in the letters I have read—yet so little happens.

I would also like to point out an anomaly which involves the National Health Amendment Bill passed in this House yesterday. Clause 4 of the National Health Amendment Bill repeals section 42A of the National Health Act. However, clause 16 of today's Bill amends section 42A of the National Health Act. Perhaps the experts can explain to us this rather interesting conundrum.

I turn now to medical fees under a coalition government. The Government has been scaremongering by saying that medical fees will increase under a coalition government. This is completely incorrect and certainly worries people living in accommodation of this nature. Under the coalition the level of fees for a visit to the doctor will remain unchanged. The main difference is that the coalition recognises that some doctors charge in excess of the medical benefits schedule fee and we will allow patients to insure for these fees. The Labor Government forces patients to pay these additional costs out of their own pocket. Thus visits to the doctor or visits by the doctor to the patient—which is more or less the case in these circumstances—and visits by the patient to a specialist will mean that patients may be thousands of dollars out of pocket. Last year Australians paid $660m for medical expenses out of their own pockets. That is well beyond the capacity of the Medicare system to compensate.

The coalition also addressed the enormous problems of waiting lists. We will reduce waiting lists by offering subsidies of up to $800 per couple per annum to those who purchase private health insurance. This will enable patients to use private hospital facilities and therefore better utilise the excess facilities which have been part of the system for far too long. These rebates will be targeted to pensioners and low income groups in particular. With regard to aged care, nursing homes and hostels, we favour more flexible funding and less overt regulation. There is too much regulation at the moment. The coalition is currently reviewing the situation and, unlike the Government, we are listening to all the organisations that wish to formulate a position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to speak to the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). Before I comment on specific issues within the Bill, I will refer to some of the remarks of the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), particularly his comments on the concerns that the nursing home industry has raised regarding the assessment and validation requirements. I take issue with the point that he made about the Government not listening to the industry. I have quite a number of nursing homes and hostels in my electorate and they have raised with me concerns similar to those that the honourable member for Bradfield outlined in his address this afternoon.
—The paperwork?

—Excessive paperwork is an issue. I recognise that this is an issue and it is a legitimate question that the honourable member has raised. What I take issue with is the claim that the Government is not listening. I had the pleasure of having the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) in my electorate a couple of weeks ago. I arranged a meeting between him and the directors and senior supervisory personnel of all the nursing homes and hostels in my electorate. Through that process we canvassed a number of issues. This is not the first time that the Minister has had such meetings. The Minister has been travelling around the country talking to people in the nursing home industry.

PARA.TAB: It is also important to note that this Bill has been developed with great consultation with the industry. This is not a Bill which has been developed in secret by the Department or by the Minister. This Bill is the result of extensive consultation and discussion. On the question of excessive paperwork requirements, we believe that there has been an overreaction by some sectors of the industry in their completion of paperwork and that excessive demands have been placed on nursing personnel in some homes and hostels. The Minister has undertaken to outline new guidelines to the nursing home sector which will explain clearly what paperwork is required. This is an attempt to diminish the current high levels of demand that are being placed on some people working in that industry.

Because I am very familiar with the nursing homes in my own electorate, I recognise that the vast majority of people working in nursing homes have great compassion, provide great quality of care, and are determined to try to provide good aged care for all of their residents. They are concerned that their No. one priority, the provision of quality of care, is maintained and is not overwhelmed with excessive paperwork. The Minister is listening to all the people in the industry, and to the pleas of the nurses and other staff in homes and hostels. He is acting to take note of their concerns and to reduce that demand.

We must understand that there is a level of accountability required. There is a balance that we need to maintain between the provision of high quality care and accountability for government expenditure. The Federal Government expends over $1.6 billion a year in the provision of aged care through nursing homes and hostels in this country, and that is a lot of money. Through the provision of that care we have increased and improved the quality of care in the last five years through the reforms that we have undertaken in the aged care sector. The Government is accountable to the taxpayers, the people of this country, and must ensure that those moneys are being expended properly, fairly and reasonably.

The paperwork that is required of nursing staff in aged care is to ensure that there is equity in the provision of facilities and services to aged people. That is why there is a need for people to fulfil some of the requirements of documentation. All people in the industry recognise that the reforms that this Government has undertaken in the aged care sector have dramatically improved the provision of quality care. Issues such as residents' agreements, the classification of different levels of care required for different frailties, and the fact that we have moved to vastly improve the quality of accommodation in aged care and in nursing homes, are all major improvements that the industry recognises are important and welcome. That is why the Bill that we are discussing today, which involves an extension of those requirements from nursing homes into the hostel sector, is welcomed, and I am sure it is welcomed by all members of the House.

I am pleased to be able to speak in support of the Bill because it does contain initiatives which will continue to maintain the viability and quality of the Australian hostel and nursing home industry. Older Australians who live in nursing homes are entitled to a high quality of life and care while they are in those homes. Commonwealth standards monitoring teams have been given the task of visiting aged care facilities and monitoring their compliance with outcome standards. These outcome standards focus on the outcomes for residents, ensuring that their physical, social and emotional needs are met.

This Bill seeks to amend the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act to bring hostels into line with nursing homes in enabling the Government to take action against those aged care facilities which do not provide residents with the quality of life and care which frail aged members of the Australian community can properly expect. We are talking about a very small sector of the aged care industry. The vast majority of people working in this sector do provide top quality care with compassion and have a regard for the needs of their residents. But there are some in our sector, a small sector, who are not able to do that. We are trying to act positively in this Bill to ensure that they have the capacity to work towards improving the quality of their care.

This legislation proposes to implement for hostels a system that has worked very well for nursing homes. Under the National Health Act, nursing homes that disagree with the findings of a standards monitoring team can seek a review. This review is carried out by a standards review panel which includes members of the industry. If a panel recommends to the Minister that a declaration of failure to comply is appropriate, it may also recommend that the Commonwealth suspend the payment of financial assistance to the home for new residents. The proposed amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act will ensure that there will now also be available a similar peer review mechanism for a hostel operator who seeks review of the assessment of the hostel's compliance with standards.

As with nursing homes, if the panel recommends to the Minister that a declaration of failure to comply is appropriate, it may also recommend that the payment of financial assistance to the hostel for new residents be suspended. To date, it has been necessary to take this action against only 12 nursing homes, which is a very small number of nursing homes when we take into account the total number throughout Australia. These amendments will enable similar action to be taken against those few hostel operators who provide substandard care for their residents. We are acting very positively in that we are also implementing a recent Budget initiative involving funding to upgrade nursing homes.

The religious and charitable sector has, since 1984, been able to apply for funding from the Commonwealth to upgrade its nursing homes. This Budget initiative extends that benefit to the private for profit sector of the nursing home industry. There is a considerable variation in the standard of accommodation across the broad spectrum of the nursing home industry. A clear and undeniable link exists between the quality of care a nursing home is able to provide and the calibre and characteristics of its premises. Despite their best endeavours, many nursing homes outside the religious and charitable sector are unable to provide a quality of care consistent with the high standards the Government has set because they are operating in old or unsuitable buildings. The inequality in the provision of care resulting from these variations in the physical condition of nursing homes conflicts with the Government's commitment to social justice.

The new grants provided for in this Bill will be a spur to nursing home proprietors to embark on substantial upgrading work they might not otherwise be able to afford. As a result, there will not only be an increase in the quality of life of many nursing home residents, but there will also be the added advantage of additional and much needed employment in the building industry.

The Bill also contains one other measure which promotes the viability of the nursing home industry. It provides for the Secretary of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services to direct that a nursing home adviser be appointed to a nursing home where the home has breached conditions of funding. The adviser will be someone from a list of approved by the Secretary and will usually have experience in the management of aged care facilities. This measure is aimed at giving nursing homes which would otherwise be closed the chance to improve their performance with the help of an adviser. This approach has already worked well in some cases on a voluntary basis. If the proprietor is unwilling to accept and pay for an adviser, then the Minister can proceed with sanctions against the home, which may include closing it down if that becomes necessary—but that would only be in the very extreme cases and as a last resort. Responsibility under the National Health Act for the management of the home will remain with the proprietor and no liability is incurred by the adviser.

The Government is also amending the Health Insurance Act to prevent pathology practices from being disadvantaged if they choose to merge. Currently when two or more pathology practices merge the resulting approved pathology authority that emerges loses the right to temporary licence collection centres. Clearly, it is desirable that such a fundamental commercial activity as merging is not discouraged through a simple oversight in the original drafting of the legislation. Furthermore, the merging of approved pathology authorities reduces the industry's excess capacity. Such excess capacity has been known to provide an incentive to overservice. There are a number of important clauses in this Bill, and I recommend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Bilney) read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mrs Kelly:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Endangered Species Protection Bill 1992 and the Endangered Species Protection (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992. On behalf of the coalition, I would like to say two things at the outset about these Bills. Firstly, the coalition is in favour of the protection of endangered species and, secondly, the coalition is appalled at the way in which this matter has been handled.

PARA.TAB: We are appalled on two grounds. The first is that we are required to debate this matter just eight days after the Bill was first published. The main Bill has 175 clauses over 72 pages, with four schedules—a further 30 pages—attached. It is quite complicated legislation. It is very important legislation. It affects the environment so it has very important conservation issues attached to it. But it is also of very direct interest to a wide range of industries because obviously it affects the use of land, the way in which various developments might be carried out and, indeed, the way whole industries are conducted particularly, for example, the forestry industry. So it is a matter of fundamental importance for the country, regardless of which point of view one comes from, and there are very many interested parties in relation to this legislation.

It is quite improper in my view for the Government to allow only eight days for such an important and complicated piece of legislation to be considered by the House of Representatives, and then under its guillotine schedule to allow only one hour for debate. With a bit of luck, we have an extra seven or eight minutes because the previous debate finished early, but only one hour was allotted.

I draw the attention of the House to this appalling timetable of guillotines this week. In the course of this week 51 Bills are to be shoved through this House with scant attention. This is the very worst programming this House has ever seen. The present Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) should be ashamed of himself for being the worst Leader of the House we have ever had.

I repeat what I have said on a number of occasions recently—that the House of Representatives is simply not doing its job. It is not examining legislation. It is an undemocratic chamber in the way it is being run at the moment. It is an absolute nonsense to suggest that people could have considered this matter properly over the last eight days. I had asked the various interest groups to give me their opinions on this, but hardly any of them have been able to do so within the time. I had to produce my recommendation to the shadow Cabinet over the weekend. The shadow Cabinet met on Monday and considered it, and then the joint party room considered it on Tuesday so that it could be debated this week. It is just not acceptable to have legislation of this importance treated in this way. I am sure that my colleagues dealing with the other 50 Bills that have been pushed through this chamber this week have the same view. There is a whole lot of important legislation in other areas which is receiving this scant attention by this House.

We are paid a lot of money, collectively, to be here. It costs an enormous amount to have the staff of the House of Representatives and all the supporting people in other departments here to service what we do. This money, taxpayers' money, is being wasted at the moment in the House of Representatives. People ought to know that under the Hawke Government, and now the Keating Government, the House of Representatives has degenerated into a totally undemocratic chamber. I register my full protest about that, not only on this Bill but also generally.

The second reason why we are appalled is that the Minister in charge of this Bill, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has completely bypassed the very expensive and very extensive ecologically sustainable development process in bringing this Bill forward at this time. As we all know, a large number of people have been engaged in the ESD process—at very considerable expense to business and unions and at very considerable taxpayer expense because the conservation groups, naturally, were unable to fund their side of the equation.

People have sat around tables, looked at things in depth and come up with balanced recommendations. What happened? Out of left field, this Minister produced an initial draft of a Bill a few weeks ago which had nothing to do with the ESD process. That draft Bill was not a matter of consultation. It was produced at a time when the ministerial council, the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council, ANZECC, had already appointed a task force to look at the problems of the protection of endangered species. That task force is still drawing up a draft national strategy within which the governments that are party to that council were to draw up their respective pieces of legislation.

In other words, we were to have a mosaic of legislation which would be effective in protecting endangered species. That mosaic was to be drawn up according to a nationally agreed plan after full consultation with the States. That should not have been a long, drawn out process. That task force was to report in March with its final recommendations. It should have been possible in the first half of next year to have legislation before this House, and complementary legislation through the other parliaments, dealing with this issue in a sensible way.

But what did we get? The present Minister for the environment acted totally politically—presumably under instructions from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), whose every act in this lead-up to the election is a political one. She went right around the side of this, absolutely broke agreements with the States, ignored the commitment that she had made to the other Ministers to wait for the report of this task force on endangered species and came up with legislation which even her own ministerial colleagues found totally unacceptable.

There was a supposed consultation with the States on the draft Bill, but the draft was sent out to the States so that they got it about a day before the proposed consultation. When the consultation with the States was held, three States could not be there simply because they had not had sufficient notice, yet the Minister said that people had been consulted. The conservation groups were, allegedly, consulted at the same notice, and also the industry representatives. To call that a process of satisfactory consultation is a denial of the normal meaning of the word. That is really a totally unacceptable way of bringing these matters before the Parliament.

Fortunately, there were other Ministers in the Government who listened to some of the advice that was coming in from a broader range of people than apparently the Minister for the environment was prepared to listen to, and there were substantial changes made to the legislation. From what we have seen of it so far, we are in favour of the general thrust of the legislation. Let there be no mistake about this: the coalition is very concerned that there should be satisfactory legislation around the whole of Australia to protect endangered species. Let there be absolutely no doubt about that.

I do not want to hear the usual misrepresentation that comes from the Government about these matters when it says that the coalition is in some way not interested or concerned about these matters. We are concerned about these matters, but we are also concerned that the legislation should be the result of due process, proper consultation, that it should be conducted within the framework of ESD, that it should be conducted within the framework of the ministerial council, and that it also should be in accordance with the intergovernmental agreement on the environment, which, I again say, has been breached by the Minister in this case because the State Ministers have not had a satisfactory opportunity to give their views under the intergovernmental agreement. The Minister will say—and she has said, indeed—that she is not breaching the intergovernmental agreement. But I will leave it for objective observers to judge whether that is the case.

This legislation was supposed to be part of a mosaic of legislation around the Commonwealth in accordance with a national strategy which ANZECC was preparing through its appointed task force. As to the reactions of various people to this legislation so far, the point is that they simply cannot form a detailed reaction in such a short time. Once again, it will be up to a grossly overburdened Senate to examine this legislation and give it proper democratic consideration. Our support for the legislation at this stage is conditional on the various submissions that will be made to us from conservation groups, from unions, from industry, from anybody who has an interest in the matter, and between the time that we are looking at it now and the time it is considered in the Senate.

So we reserve our right to move possible amendments in the Senate, or to refer the legislation to a committee, depending on what kind of advice, what kinds of views, we get from those who are interested. I can tell the Minister that at this moment she has offended just about everybody. The conservation groups were promised legislation on endangered species before the 1990 election. They feel cheated because it has taken so long to come along and it is not in line with what they were promised before the election. That has happened with just about every conservation issue. The Government, before the last election, promised the earth and the moon and the stars to the conservation groups. It had no possibility of meeting those commitments; they were undeliverable. Understandably, the conservation groups are very angry and they feel that they have been let down.

Industry and the unions have put a lot of resources into the ESD process, as have the conservation groups, at great expense. A lot of time was put in and a lot of very good work was done in those groups. Then that was bypassed by the Minister, coming in from left field as she has, and that has angered those people a great deal.

As to the States, which enter into discussions in ANZECC and also enter into the intergovernmental agreement on the environment—which, incidentally, in itself was a breach of the undertakings by the Labor Government to the conservation movement as it did not want intergovernmental agree-ments with the States; it wanted overriding Commonwealth legislation in most cases, which the Labor Party promised to the conservation movement before the last election and which it did not deliver and indeed could not deliver; we cannot ignore the States—they are upset that the inter-governmental agreement on the environment has been bypassed. So just about everybody has been offended by this Minister.

As the Bill itself now stands, after the Minister's colleagues have had a go at it—and we can be thankful for their efforts because if one had looked only at the first draft, one would not be able to make the remarks that I am making today—we support the general thrust of it. I made it very clear before the Minister came into the chamber that I do not want any further misrepresentation of our intentions by the Government on conservation issues. I will simply not accept suggestions that we are unconcerned about these matters. We are concerned about them but we are concerned to have them properly dealt with. We are concerned to have a democratic debate and consideration of them. We are certainly not getting that in this farce of a House of Representatives in this guillotined debate on this Thursday afternoon.

The Bill provides lists of endangered species. We would want to have a look at the definition of an endangered species. We need technical advice to see whether the definitions that are offered are acceptable to us. The lists provided for in the Bill include endangered, vulnerable and presumed extinct native species, lists of endangered ecological communities and lists of key threatening processes. It sets up advisory committees. An Endangered Species Advisory Committee is to be established to advise the Minister on his or her obligations under the Act, as is an Endangered Species Scientific Subcommittee to advise the Minister on the lists that are referred to in the Bill.

There are proposals for recovery and threat abatement plans—not only on the part of the Commonwealth itself; there are also cooperative plans with the States. We are pleased to see that the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service is the responsible person named in the Act as the director in charge of this particular piece of legislation. We certainly have confidence that the ANPWS would act sensibly in these matters.

A very important area of the legislation is that of the placing of conservation orders. These are of three kinds: interim, permanent or impact assessment. We note that the previously unfettered right of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories to take various decisions unaided by colleagues has been watered down, obviously, by the intervention of other Ministers. There are restrictions on what the Minister can do in putting an interim conservation order on a particular activity in order to protect a species that might be threatened pending suitable investigation. That seems quite sensible.

Then there are permanent conservation orders which can be made on Commonwealth lands and waters by the environment Minister on the same grounds as the interim conservation orders. Although the Minister says in her second reading speech that these will be made only with the approval of Cabinet, as will extensions of interim conservation orders, the legislation does not prescribe this. So we have only the support of the second reading speech for the requirement for the Minister to consult with the Cabinet and get Cabinet agreement to a permanent conservation order. That is not as strong a basis as we would like. It is a much weaker form of restraint on the Minister. It relies on the Acts Interpretation Act and a court presumably looking at the second reading speech and giving that a certain weight, but it certainly does not have the same weight as a section in the Act which would require the Minister to take a matter to Cabinet and go through the Executive Council. So that is one of the questions we would want to raise between now and the actual debate that will occur on this Bill in the Senate.

The other query one would have at this stage is that the Bill relies very much on the key concept of ecologically sustainable development. That is not described in the Bill itself; it is to be dealt with by regulation. I would think the procedure of allowing this key concept to be dealt with by a regulation contravenes the convention that important questions of policy and principle be dealt with in an Act and not in regulations under it. That is one of the other questions we would be wanting to raise. I now move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not denying the Bill a second reading, the House expresses its grave concern:
(1)that the legislation which is of fundamental importance to the environment and sustainable development should be guillotined through the House in 60 minutes only 8 days after its publication; and

(2)that in presenting the legislation the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories should have bypassed the Ecologically Sustainable Development process and ignored the Inter-Governmental Agreement on the Environment".

SPEECH.PARA: Having moved that second reading amendment, I reiterate that the coalition supports the general thrust of the Bill, that the coalition is concerned to have sensible legislation not only in the Commonwealth but also in State parliaments to protect endangered species, and we are certainly open to any further considerations that might come to us in the relatively short passage of time still between this miserable debate here and its more complete consideration by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I second the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us get a couple of things clear. The shadow Minister for sustainable development and the environment, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), spent all of his time bleating about the process here, and mentioned very little of the detail of the Bill. I suspect that, because of his late arrival into this portfolio area, he does not yet have a complete grasp of the significance of the Endangered Species Protection Bill. This Bill is perfectly consistent with the entire debate about ecologically sustainable development and in fact is couched in terms of the key principles of ESD. Those key principles of ecologically sustainable development are: firstly, that there should be inter-generation equity—that is, that the current generation should not leave an impoverished environment for the next; secondly, that there should be maintenance and protection of biodiversity; and, thirdly, that we should deal cautiously with irreversibility.

PARA.TAB: I do not think there is a Bill that more correctly addresses the ESD process than the Endangered Species Protection Bill. Its very essence is ESD. I might also say to the shadow Minister that I was approached and briefed, along with other members of the Caucus environment committee, two years ago by the World Wide Fund for Nature and subsequently by other groups. So we have certainly known of the existence and the idea of endangered species legislation, and we have been working with members of the Caucus, the Minister, conservation groups and anyone else who wanted to knock on our door for those two or 2 1/2 years. I can certainly say that I feel completely relaxed about the amount of discussion that has gone on and the amount of work that has gone into the legislation.

Ultimately, the legislation reflects the sort of debate that those of us, of whom I am one, who have been intimately involved in these debates have had. We understand, and that is now reflected in the Bill. The extent to which the Bill has had changes over time reflects the amount of consultation that we have had. Members of the Opposition cannot have it both ways: they said that we rushed it into the House and that we did not consult enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not having it both ways.

—It is. The fact is that we consulted endlessly and got a Bill in in a timely fashion. We want it in this Parliament; we certainly do not want it hanging over. We have produced the goods: the Bill is there, and its essence is excellent. Let me now go to the essence of the Bill. I want to give an illustration of a particular species of animal that will be saved due to actions similar to those to be undertaken under the Endangered Species Protection Bill. In fact, we are doing this right now in conjunction with the Queensland Minister for the environment.

PARA.TAB: There are five key elements to the Bill. For the first time there will be a scientifically based listing process. This means that politicians will not be debating and deciding which species are endangered; rather, scientists will decide for us which species should be on the Commonwealth's endangered species list. We must keep in mind, of course, the fact that State governments already have a list themselves. We hope over time that the lists will merge.

We are starting with a list of zero, really, because we have to add to the list after we have appointed a scientific community. But we already know that there is an initial list in existence—a great deal of work has been done in this area—of some 299 endangered species or sub-species and 726 vulnerable species or sub-species. I will mention in a moment what are known as two key threatening processes which could wipe out a number of species and which we want to address in the Bill.

The first step is to have an agreed list of species which are in danger and which need to be saved. The second step, and this is the best part of the legislation, is that we seek to go out and recover—that is, save—the species. The most controversial part of this legislation, and any such legislation dealing with the environment, is always that part where a government, in this case the Commonwealth, says that an activity must be stopped in order to save a threatened species. I reckon that more species will be saved by means of the recovery plans than will ever be saved by the imposition of the permanent conservation orders that are written into this Bill. By that I mean that, whilst from time to time there may be a headline which says that an environment Minister or Commonwealth government stops a particular activity—a mine or a farm or whatever—in order to save a species, that will be a one in 10 year event.

TALK.START.PARA: —Famous last words.

—It might be one in five years—I do not really mind. I want those opposite to understand that the event that will take place day after day through the Commonwealth working with State governments—and I will give an example in a minute—will be the drawing up of plans first of all to discover the existence and population of a particular species and then the identification of the threats to the species. Very detailed plans will then be put into effect to ensure that there is no further danger to a particular species and there is a means by which the population of that species can be built up in a given area. We can go out and try to hit the problem before we get to a crunch issue where a government might have to stop an initial development.

PARA.TAB: The very heart of this legislation is discursive—that is, we will seek to draw up plans on behalf of an endangered species and then talk with those actors in the environment who may be causing some threat to the species. In fact, there will be very little use of the conservation orders, the punitive parts of the legislation, if I can call them that. They need to be there, but the heart of the legislation rests with the recovery plans.

Further to that we have what are called threat abatement plans. These are a broader categorisation of threats to any number of endangered species. To give some of the details of the threat abatement plans, here we might find, for instance, that there will be a particular form of disease such as a dieback, or a feral animal such as the fox or whatever, the activities of which are such that it threatens a whole list of species, wherever they may exist. So we need some thoroughgoing abatement plans to make sure that a dieback fungus is stopped in a region, that foxes are wiped out in a region, or that any other form of feral animal is wiped out. There is a specific focus on recovery plans species by species, but where we can identify more general threats to a number of species, such as feral animals, we will also draw up what we call abatement plans in order to wipe out the threat to a number of endangered species.

The other parts of the legislation include the obligations that are specific to the Commonwealth and lands which it owns or waters which it controls. These require the Commonwealth to draw up conservation agreements to take note of the listed species and to invoke recovery plans and abatement plans in its own territories and waters and so on. Where necessary, where there is a specific threat from a particular economic activity, there are powers which the Government as a whole can invoke through permanent conservation orders.

One of the other important elements, the fifth element, is that the community itself and interest groups can become involved in the process and do have some powers of scrutiny over the operation of the Bill. There is an ability, as in all these environmental matters, to comment on draft plans and on the issue of permits and so on.

I turn to a species in Queensland that has been drawn to our attention. One particular recovery plan which has already been drawn up, which is an example of what I regard as the most important part of the legislation, is the plan for the northern hairy-nosed wombat. As far as we know, going back about 150 years, it roamed across a considerable area throughout Queensland and New South Wales. It is now found in only a very small area of Queensland, Epping Forest National Park, which is an open woodland and semi-arid area. The park is 120 kilometres north-west of Clermont in the Burdekin River drainage area of central Queensland.

I want to impress upon people the amount of detailed work that is required to identify the population of the animal, to identify the number of females in the population that are still able to breed up, to identify the specific threats to that population—whether it be a loss of habitat or competition from other animals for feed. Sometimes those other animals may be introduced; in this case, the kangaroo is the main competitor for feed. I would like to give honourable members a hint of the sort of detail required and some of the costs that will arise because of these recovery plans. We will not be just setting in place a plan and then walking away from it; what we will have to be doing, of course, is constantly monitoring and keeping ourselves up to date in order that we save a particular species.

Details such as these have to be considered: the conservation measures that are being used in this case—the Commonwealth has already given a great deal of money to the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service under our endangered species program which, of course, has been running for some time; the availability of on-site accommodation for staff and researchers; the continued exclusion of cattle and public visitation; the maintenance of firebreaks along the perimeter of the park to reduce the potential for wildfire; six to eight weekly checks by the ranger in charge of fences, firebreaks and the population in general; six monthly monitoring of the animal's abundance using burrowing activity counts; six monthly monitoring of the density of kangaroos, with whom it competes for feed; a three monthly assessment of pasture biomass and grazing pressure; and three yearly trapping of wombats to assess breeding status, body condition and population composition. Are the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Beale) fair dinkum about the Bill or not?

TALK.START.PARA: —We were talking about something else. But hang on, it is a State park. Who is going to pay for it—State or Federal?

—Both. I have just explained that the Commonwealth has already assisted the State Government with these moneys on a species which will end up on our list and is already on Queensland's list. It is an illustration of how we have already done most of the homework of negotiation between the Commonwealth and the States in order that specific species should be saved and taken off the endangered status list—and that is the object of the whole exercise. I wanted to impress upon honourable members the sort of detailed and ongoing work that is required in order to save any species.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I repeat that there is no Act in this entire arena that is not only more consistent with ESD but also is the very essence of ecologically sustainable development. I thank the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) for her great work and commend her for getting the Bill here before us. We support it and, of course, will not be supporting the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Johns) was saying that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has done a good job. I draw it to the attention of the House that the Minister has not even accorded the House the courtesy of attending during this one-hour debate. I wholeheartedly support the shadow Minister for sustainable development and the environment, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), whose amendment talks about there being only 60 minutes of debate, with eight days of notice, on this fairly complicated Bill.

PARA.TAB: The Endangered Species Protection Bill is a result of the activity of the environmentalists and Green movement who supported the Government in the 1990 election and who are now coming home to demand implementation of their views. They were able to allocate some preferences and, as the Parliamentary Secretary at the table says, a lot of work has gone into this particular Bill. Some groups have been consulted, obviously, but a lot of other groups around Australia have not been consulted. Obviously, with the time schedule that Opposition members have had to look at this Bill, we have not been consulted at all.

The State governments have had a dry run on this legislation. Those of us in Victoria and Tasmania are aware of endangered species legislation, so much so that farmers have been prevented from ploughing the silver tussock because that could become endangered. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) would be aware of those suggestions.

There was also a suggestion that the legless lizard might be lost; farmers all over the State of Victoria were greatly upset by the Kirner Government's suggestions for similar legislation. Likewise, in Tasmania, the former Labor Government brought forward legislation of a similar kind. So the Federal Government has plenty to go on in drafting this sort of legislation to, in the final analysis, prevent a project from proceeding and prevent farmers from farming their land in the traditional manner. We see also arrangements in terms of the forest industries, where the endangered species argument has been used to lock up the Tasmanian forests, the forests down here in the south-east of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —East Gippsland as well.

—And in East Gippsland, I am reminded. The tactic there, of course, is to use rare birds and koalas as a medium to attract public attention. By using that mechanism, foresters and environmentalists are persuaded that large tracts of forest land can be locked up. Obviously there is a public sympathy for koalas. By using that public sympathy, we can run the argument that eucalypt forests should be locked up because the koalas or some rare birds might become extinct.

PARA.TAB: None of the rational arguments about the ravages of bushfires are ever taken into account. It is not taken into account that some of the forests might be ageing and should be cut down in the interests of environmental control so that new young trees can grow in their place and improve the environment. The same tactics are being employed in this Bill. So let honourable members be fully aware of what the environmentalists and the Greens have in mind. The two key issues are: what is an endangered species; and how will we enforce the regulations and the legislation? The Parliamentary Secretary admits that the complexity of the legislation is such that it would be fairly difficult to enforce.

The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) is well known in this House for his erudite views on matters affecting Tasmania and the locking up of Tasmanian forests, and he has seen what has happened with a Labor government in that State and the way in which it gradually encroached on public forests by locking them up so that the loggers could not have access on a long term basis. He has pointed out to me, and I point out to honourable members, the remarkable way in which this legislation has been drafted. I draw the attention of the House to the definition on page 4 of the Bill of the word `endangered'. There is quite a lot of supporting material on what we mean by `endangered', and that is fair enough. The word `habitat' is also fairly difficult to define. I will read the definition out for the information of honourable members:

SPEECH.PARA: "habitat" means an area:

PARA.TAB: (a) in which an organism, or a group of organisms, lives; or
(b) in which an organism, or a group of organisms, has lived and into which the organism or group has the potential to be reintroduced.

SPEECH.PARA: Without going into a lot of detail, honourable members of this House and those people close to this problem could understand the impact of that definition and that it could be interpreted by Green groups and anyone with a particular barrow to push to suit their own point of view. The definition of `species' is in fact more dangerous. It says in the Bill:
"species" means a group of biological entities that:

PARA.TAB: (a) interbreed to produce fertile offspring; or
(b) possess common characteristics derived from a common gene pool;

SPEECH.PARA: and includes:

PARA.TAB: (c) a sub-species; and

SPEECH.PARA: let me emphasise this final paragraph—
a distinct population of such biological entities, being a distinct population that the Minister determines in writing to be a species for the purposes of this definition;

This one clause in the Bill can in fact change the political content and the thrust of this legislation. If the Minister is leant upon by any particular group, that group can bring about a change in the attitude and approach of the Government to an endangered species. National projects could be held up because of an argument about the definition of an endangered species. Of course, that is just one aspect of this very voluminous Bill which has a great number of details which are open to interpretation, exploitation and which, obviously, are the subject of difficult interpretation by the statutory authorities and advisory groups bound by the Bill.

PARA.TAB: I will give some of the technical background to the species we have in Australia. Australia plays host to an estimated 18,000 species of vascular and 36,000 non-vascular plants, as well as 108,000 species of invertebrates. Since European settlement, the losses of species have not been large in terms of the total number, with about 780 species of birds and animals being lost. However, although it is true that 99 per cent of species that have existed throughout the world at some stage are no longer with us, I view the loss of any species as a serious matter.

Mr Ian Hore-Lacy, whom I know personally, who has had a long experience in these matters and who is employed by CRA as a biologist, suggests that 87 per cent of reptiles, 81 per cent of land mammals, 90 per cent of non-flowering and 80 per cent of flowering plants, along with 92 per cent of frogs, 81 per cent of land mammals and 70 per cent of birds are unique to Australia. That is the sort of background we have in Australia. That is the sort of flora and fauna which are unique to Australia.

A recent study by the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources found that, contrary to popular belief, most extinctions of species in Australia were not the result of clearing of farmland, disease or over-hunting. Instead, changed ways of fire, introduced species such as foxes and the 18 million feral cats in Australia, along with introduced herbivores such as sheep and cattle, were the major factors contributing to mammalian extinctions. We can see that other factors are involved in keeping these species going. Of course, extinction is sometimes difficult to prove. A case in point is the Adelaide blue-tongue lizard recently found in the belly of a snake, despite the last reported sighting of that species being over 50 years ago.

These Bills can apply to any area of Commonwealth activity. For instance, if foreign investment or export licensing controls apply, the legislation can be particularly relevant. Those of us who have been close to the woodchipping argument know how important Federal legislation on export permits is in allowing such projects to proceed.

We have had the remarkable spectacle of the environment Minister having a pitched battle in Cabinet with the three industry Ministers—Ministers whom the shadow Minister referred to as bringing some sense to the legislation. The environment Minister said in October that industry groups were `bloody minded and obdurate'. That was her view of them and their quite legitimate opposition to what were then fairly draconian powers in the draft Bill. As the shadow Minister has indicated, if the original Bills had come before this House we would have had great difficulty in supporting their passage. The environment Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the real problem is that some sections of industry did not want consultation—they want agreement or they want deferral, deferral, deferral . . .

Obviously, they wanted a deferral because they could not put up with the Bills as they were then drafted. Both the environment and industry Ministers of this Government agree that the legislation is reliant on the principles of ecologically sustainable development. The concept was best defined in the world famous Bruntland report of 1987, otherwise known as Our common future, in the statement:
. . . development that meets the need of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs . . .

None of us on this side of the House would have any argument with that general thrust of sustainable development and the maintenance of our plant and animal species on the planet. However, in the objectives of the Bill set out in clause 3(1) there is no mention of the need for a balanced approach—an approach which I strongly believe is possible, given the right circumstances.

PARA.TAB: As explained in clause 3(2), the Bill proposes the establishment of an endangered species advisory committee and a scientific subcommittee. One of the major functions of these committees is to advise the Minister on the workings of this legislation. Of course, as I said initially in my speech, this is very much open to political pressure and persuasion.

The Minister has referred to these Bills as being based on legislation already in place in the United States and Japan. The United States legislation provided for an endangered species committee, sometimes known as the `God Squad' because of its ability to rule on whether developments could proceed. Obviously, we have precedents in other parts of the world of committees of this kind having extraordinary powers of control over major development projects. I am sure that here in Australia, if this legislation has some unintended consequences, the committee will have similar powers.

I think that the membership of the US committee is much more balanced than will be the membership of the advisory committee set up under this legislation. In the United States case, the secretaries of agriculture, the Army and the interior, along with the Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency and two others, are all members of the committee. Although the US committee is very powerful it has generally exercised its prerogative quite reasonably and is not seen as being too politicised.

This will be impossible to achieve in Australia with an environment Minister—who has not even been prepared to come into the House for this debate—who put out a kit on the environment which insulted the foresters, car makers and farmers, something which I referred to in a previous debate and which, I understand, has not been withdrawn from all school children around Australia. The same Minister has spent $285,000, in conjunction with her colleagues, on sending Australian delegations to the June Earth Summit in Brazil which produced ecological agreements that made no mention of economic considerations. More recently in this House she was not prepared to listen to the concerns of scientists and those people who understand the problems of Antarctica about the forced removal of the huskies from that continent.

The Minister has not got a very good track record in other areas of activity. She is not even here to debate this issue. She cannot stand up to the very powerful and sensible arguments of the shadow Minister and others of us on this side. She left the House. She knew how long the debate would go. We have a very genuine concern on this side of the House that, whilst this legislation purports to protect endangered species, it has a number of hidden agenda and unintended consequences that may have long term problems for particular projects in Australia. This legislation could be used to prevent those projects proceeding, because we have seen the way in which environmentalists operate—we have seen the way in which legislation such as this can be used, by using the fine print, to prevent major projects proceeding. The coalition agrees with the thrust of the legislation but shows great concern about the way in which the legislation has been drafted and presented to the House. We only hope that the fine print does not prevent genuine development here in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to debate the Endangered Species Protection Bill 1992 and the Endangered Species Protection (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992, which are before the House this evening. It is nice to hear the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) indicate that he is in agreement with the general thrust of the legislation. In general, the legislation aims to adopt a proactive and cooperative approach wherever possible. In particular, it will continue the cooperative approach that exists between the Commonwealth Government and the State and Territory governments for the recovery and protection of endangered species and ecological communities through the endangered species program.

PARA.TAB: There has been a long argument—or a long debate—within this House and within the Australian community about the need for the protection of endangered species legislation. I guess that that argument will continue. Certainly, the amendments moved by the Opposition in this House will ensure the continuation of that debate. However, I feel, and honourable members opposite agree, that there needs to be preservation of endangered species; in particular, the preservation of all species.

A word that has been used in this debate is `biodiversity'. There is no doubt that the enactment of this endangered species legislation will go a long way towards ensuring that we maintain biodiversity. As has been indicated, I guess by speakers from both sides of the House, biodiversity is something which we are yet to cash in on. During the rush towards science and technology during the 1950s and 1960s and that great expanse of knowledge into the 1970s, there is no doubt that the embracing of science and technology did leave behind the role of more mundane things like simple species. Lots of those species are unattractive to us. Some of them are the cute and cuddly types, the ones that we can actually sell readily as souvenirs in the shop in Parliament House or anywhere else.

Certainly, the role of science and technology did not embrace the use of species and the way in which they could portray and help society. We tended to overlook a simple thing like the fungus which contributed to the production of penicillin. It played a large role in saving many lives during the Second World War, and has certainly saved many lives since. That is just one of the spin-offs that we can get from a species which, in its original sense, we would not consider to be something which is worth while preserving.

Certainly there are particular exceptions to this endangered species legislation such as pathogens. They will cause death, and it is desirable that we probably do eliminate those from the species list of the planet. But in the case of many of the species, we have yet to learn and appreciate some of the spin-offs that we can get from them, whether it be directly or from the extractions of chemicals. Certainly, that has been done in the past and can be done in the future.

With the further use of science and technology, which I guess I did lambast a little bit there a moment ago, we can also ensure that some of these species contribute substantially to the well-being and economic benefit of any society, whether it be Australia or some other country. We are on the tip of the iceberg, if I can put it that way, in terms of the sort of information and knowledge that we have about a lot of our species, particularly in Australia.

The recovery program that is enacted by this legislation is essential to ensure that we preserve the biodiversity that we have in this country and to set a standard which many other countries would be glad to emulate in the preservation of species in their particular climes. Biodiversity is not just about Australia; it is about other countries and their contribution to the biodiversity of the planet.

Earlier speakers in this debate commented about the form of consultation, or the lack of consultation that was undertaken by the Government in preparing this legislation. I think I need to comment a little bit about that, because it is not true that the Government has not consulted with the community or anyone else—and by that, I mean the Opposition—in terms of getting information for this legislation.

Let me point out to honourable members that there has been consultation over a prolonged period of time on both the concept and the detail of the legislation. That consultation started as far back as 1989. It was aired in a draft national strategy published in that year. Then, in March 1990, just before the last election, the Government made a commitment to consider endangered species legislation. All Commonwealth Government departments have had the drafting instructions for this legislation for over 12 months and in February 1992, over 1,000 copies of the discussion paper on the legislation were widely distributed.

There were briefings of interest groups, both industry and conservation, in February and March 1992 and September and October 1992. These groups had the opportunity to see the draft Bill before the September briefing and a revised draft before the October briefing which, in itself, is an unusual procedure for Commonwealth legislation. As part of that consultation, the concept of endangered species legislation was raised in the draft Australian national strategy for the conservation of species and habitats threatened with extinction, which was released for public comment in October 1989. Over 200 submissions were actually received on the strategy, with the vast majority being supportive.

The draft strategy's objectives for legislation were to encourage the introduction, in States, Territories and the Commonwealth, of legislation that would require parliamentary approval for an action or development that knowingly threatens a species with extinction. Forty-five comments were received on this objective. The Endangered Species Advisory Committee revised the strategy after considering comments and the revised strategy, published in 1992, recommended introduction of Commonwealth endangered species legislation.

Within the Government, in October 1991 a Cabinet submission was circulated and interested departments were briefed. As well, the Caucus committee on ASET was briefed by the Minister's staff on 12 September, and again by the Minister on 10 October. On 28 October 1991, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) agreed that the legislation be drafted without first being given in principle Cabinet support, and that a Cabinet decision be taken in early 1992, when a draft Bill would be available for discussion.

In February 1992, over 1,000 copies of a booklet Commonwealth endangered species legislation: the proposal, were released for public comment. The booklet was sent to all Federal politicians, to ANZECC Ministers, to all Commonwealth departments and to industry, union and conservation groups. Staff from the Minister's office and from the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and DASET briefed conservation, industry and union organisations on the proposal.

As a result, more than 150 representations were received, with the overwhelming majority from conservation organisations and individuals who supported the legislation. Nine were from industry organisations which, in general, expressed some reservations about the legislation and wanted to be consulted on the draft Bill. New South Wales opposed the legislation on the grounds that it followed the flawed Heritage Commission—as it called it—approach, and the Northern Territory objected to the legislation because it could delay some development approvals.

In September-October 1992, Cabinet submissions and the Bill were circulated to Government departments. Copies of the Bill were provided to the main industry and conservation lobby groups on 18 September and to all States on 24 September. Further briefings of industry, conservation and State representatives were carried out on 28 September and 15 October, as well as further consultation with the Caucus committee on the environment, which was briefed on 8 October, and again on 13 October 1992. So, we have had these consultations which honourable members opposite feel we have not had.

The consultations have resulted in considerable changes to the legislation. One change is the listing of ecological communities. Only endangered communities can go on to the list and the criteria for listing is to be spelt out by regulation, on the advice of the scientific sub-committee. There were various other changes, such as the listing of species and the listing of the key threatening processes. As well, Commonwealth actions and decisions affecting endangered species will now be considered under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, rather than the endangered species protection legislation. That is, no additional process will be involved. The ability of the environment Minister to issue conservation orders has been restricted to a period of up to six months for Commonwealth lands and waters and to the period of environmental assessment under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act in the case of Commonwealth approval.

I think I have answered the question and illustrated the amount of consultation, and as well I have pointed out the resulting changes to the legislation. Without doubt, this Bill enjoys support—if a little reluctantly—from both sides of the House. I am pleased that the Opposition will be supporting this legislation this afternoon.

This legislation covers many different types of animals, and I mentioned some of them in my introductory remarks. I realise that time is limited here. I restate my commitment and the Government's commitment to biodiversity in the sense that doing away with biodiversity is like having a library with just one book in it or 10,000 copies of the one book. I commend the legislation to the House.
