DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Martin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be opposing the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill. The Bill is intended to give effect to the announcement in the Budget to extend the export market development grants scheme beyond the eight-grant cut-off in order to assist Australian exporters in their efforts to penetrate new markets. That means that exporters can get eight grants and then the scheme is not available to them. The Government has sought to identify an area in which it can encourage exporters into new markets. The measures in the Bill will extend the current scheme in that respect. The amendment will provide limited access to the scheme after eight grants. Exporters applying for grants beyond eight will need to demonstrate initiatives in pursuing `new markets', as defined by the Bill—that is, a market which is new for the claimant—in relation to a particular export activity.

PARA.TAB: New market access beyond eight years will be limited to exporters who have not achieved export earnings of more than $300,000 in respect of goods, services, industrial property rights or know-how in that new market. The threshold for a limited number of specified larger scale project service activities will be increased to $1m. Expenditure eligible for consideration in respect of a grant will be limited to that incurred developing the new market, rather than that incurred developing all markets. Exporters will have access to grants in regard to a new market for up to three years and there will be no limit on the number of new markets, so defined, in which an exporter may engage in order to give full potential to this facility to develop new export markets for Australia.

The export market development grants scheme was established in 1974. Since then, there have been five reviews of the scheme and numerous amendments to the Export Market Development Grants Act to improve the operation and targeting of the scheme. At this moment, two separate reviews of the scheme are under way. Firstly, Austrade has engaged a consultant to investigate the efficiency of the scheme and answer the fundamental question of whether it has been successful in getting businesses to export. Secondly, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology has established a subcommittee to look at extending the scheme to cover inbound tourism activities, although the scheme had been extended to cover tourism activities in 1978 and the accommodation sector of the tourism industry in 1982. Nevertheless, inbound tourism activities are still ineligible for grant.

These constant reviews and changes to the scheme do not really provide a stable and secure environment for exporters. Nevertheless, we are not intending to oppose this amendment to the scheme, because we see the scheme as important for exporters in the context of, firstly, the worst recession in 60 years, and, secondly, the abject failure of this Government to undertake far-reaching micro-economic reform, which would be of infinitely greater benefit to exporters.

I put it to those people listening to the broadcast of this discussion on this small Bill to amend the export market development grants scheme: if you were to tune into parliamentary Question Time and, in the face of the worst recession in 60 years, listen to the arrogant creature who poses as Prime Minister of this country for the time being, you would hear him, day after day, seeking to exculpate the difficulties facing the Australian nation by blaming the Opposition. Underneath it all, one of the reasons for this is that he caused the difficulties and, consequently, cannot fix them. If those in the marketplace seeking to export have to rely on export market development grants, the reason is obvious: if this Government were to be returned, they would not receive the sort of real assistance that we will give when elected to government.

I will cite three of the taxes that would go. I say to the people listening to this debate: imagine that you are exporting products or services at the moment, for which this could be applicable. Upon the election of the coalition, if you are an exporter facing intense competition to establish markets overseas you will no longer have to pay a wholesale sales tax; you will no longer have to pay payroll tax; and you will no longer have to pay a fuel excise. To use an old colloquialism: you are starting to cook with gas. You are in an infinitely better position than simply being given an export market development grant. Nevertheless, we will allow the scheme to run right through. The program will be completed. That is the contrast: the real removal of significant impediments to business seeking to compete not only with importers but also for markets overseas, with the removal of taxes that are imposed at present, provides a real opportunity to drive forward.

We regard all the necessary reforms that are contained within Fightback as critically important to Australian business—not just so that it can sell more products in Australia; but the trade element, the export element, becomes the outward reflection of all that is in the Fightback package and allows us to compete overseas, redress the crippling balance of payments problems that we have at present, and lift the gross domestic product and the standard of living of Australians.

It was only in the context of the failure of the Government to implement balanced macro-economic policy and undertake fundamental reforms in the micro-economy that the Hughes committee review of the EMDG scheme saw a need to continue the export incentive schemes—not only the EMDG scheme, but others as well. In 1982, during our period in government, the Industries Assistance Commission recommended that the scheme be extended for five years as an interim measure for a domestic economy hostile to exporters. Ten years later the domestic economic environment is still hostile to exporters. The latest change to the EMDG scheme is an indictment, in many ways, of the wasted opportunities and inaction of the Labor Government. It is in this context that the coalition did not oppose the extension of the export market development grants scheme to 1995 when that was done in 1990, and it is in that context that we do not oppose this amendment to the Act this evening.

The coalition's Fightback package, with its abolition of six existing taxes and the introduction of a goods and services tax which zero rates exports, will reduce the cost to exporters by $1.7 billion. That is a $1.7 billion reduction in costs by the mere election of the coalition. Whilst there is a $1.7 billion reduction in costs for exporters by the abolition of those taxes, business overall will benefit from a cost reduction of $20 billion.

The Business Council of Australia and the Industry Commission have said that the implementation of the policies advocated by the coalition could boost the gross domestic product of Australia by at least 15 per cent; in other words, the gross domestic product could permanently be increased by at least $60 billion. These are the reforms that we are putting to the Australian people and saying, `Unless we make this dramatic change we won't get the sort of lift that Australia requires, not only in our gross domestic product but also in a flow through to the living standards of all Australians'. Exporters, to which this measure is aimed, will judge the Government's failure at the next election on its ability to reduce costs by undertaking micro-economic reform. As I said earlier, this failure, together with the Government's crude use of monetary policy, has visited the worst recession in 60 years on the Australian people and there has been a cost to businesses and jobs.

The fact is that this Government's record in the field of international trade is appalling. From time to time, when the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Mr Kerin) is given a guernsey in this country, and given an opportunity to say or do something—he no longer sits in the Cabinet, he has been ditched from the Cabinet, that is the ranking this Government applies to the portfolio of trade—I have heard him refer to percentage increases in exports to Asian countries. It is very interesting that, when we analyse the figures, the story is very different indeed. The tragedy of the lost opportunities under this Government is not confined to the misery that has been inflicted on the great bulk of Australians, it is also revealed by the statistics on international trade, particularly in the Asian region. Looking at our exports in terms of market share, not in volume, because one would expect the volume to be increasing, if one is caught in the slipstream of growth in the Asian area one will lift the number of products and value of services exported. The test of improvement is whether there is a gain in market share. That is the only test. Is the market share going up or is it remaining static?

In the overwhelming majority of countries in South East Asia and north-eastern Asia, Australia's market share, despite the phenomenal growth in Asia, is either static or going backwards. It is a lie and a total misrepresentation to come into this Parliament and say, `We are having significant success in the export field'. The Government is caught simply in the slipstream of growth in Asia. Rather than talk about how proud they are that the exports are going up, those opposite ought to hang their heads collectively in shame when the ANU produces figures that show the market share in the majority of countries is static or going backwards. To put it mildly, it is an appalling record.

This is not entirely the fault of the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development. He is a decent man and is trying to do what he can within the narrow constraints of the opportunities offered to him. He is operating as the junior Minister under the garrulous Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). The Government's policy that is imposed on him is a single track policy. By that I mean a single track policy of investing the overwhelming number of resources and people in the effort in the GATT multilateral round.

I agree with what the Government is doing in the GATT, as does the Opposition, and we will continue it in government. But it is not the sole approach to be taken to trade matters. Beyond pressing for the big breakthrough in the GATT, we also need, in the region in which we reside and operate overwhelmingly, to be tying down bilateral arrangements to ensure that we have an increase in our trade with those countries. In contrast to the single track approach of the Government to trade, ours will be a multi-track approach, quite apart from the enormous lift in burdens on industry—$1.7 billion to exporters alone, and $20 billion to business generally.

When we come into office we will press on through the GATT; we will work to ensure that we put in place bilateral trading arrangements, liberal trading arrangements, with the countries of north east and South East Asia; and we will press for much faster harmonisation of regulations in areas such as customs and clearance procedures, dispute settlement, investment—I would love to say tax, but that would be well down the line—all to ensure that we lift our market share. There will be an enormous reduction in costs off the back of exporters; we will be pressing for the big breakthrough in the GATT, the multilateral round; liberal trading arrangements will be negotiated; and there will be much speedier work in regional organisations on the harmonisation of those sorts of regulations that I just mentioned.

This will start to show what I really mean when I say that under us the heart and core of our foreign policy in government will be trade. That is not a rejection of geopolitical activities, but it is emphasising the need for a far greater emphasis on geo-economic activities in the face of the worst recession in 60 years, in the face of the need to lift our exports, and the opportunities that we will be creating for exporters with the change in policies on which we embark.

It was quietly leaked about the place that the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development was going to make a statement on trade in this Parliament to tell us of all the government initiatives. We have not had a statement. I will not draw the obvious conclusion that there can be no statement of government initiatives because there are no government initiatives, but I will say that, even if in the dying hours in the week or so ahead of the sitting of this House the Minister comes in to talk about trade initiatives, he will be greeted with a collective horse laugh because, tragically, those initiatives will be ones that dreams are made of—simply in the mind—and orally expressed in rhetorical terms but not finding their way in tangible forms in the performance of Australia's trade effort.

The export market development grants, which are amended here and are to be applied also to new markets beyond the eight grants that have been made, are helpful. But how much more helpful if the exporters did not have to pay wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, fuel excise, et cetera, as will be the situation under us. The challenge for Australia is to ensure that the environment is there for exporters to be able to really compete, to lift our market share. Through a lift also in gross domestic product we will obtain a lift in living standards for Australia. When we say that the heart and the core of our foreign and trade policies will be trade, we are saying so not merely because the Cold War is over, but because we have a cold war in a different form, if you like, imposed on the Australian people at present. If people are not in exports or in business, they may well not survive in the years ahead. Where there is an opportunity to export, we will grow and prosper. But for this to go ahead we have to create that environment by the abolition of the six existing taxes, relief to the extent of $1.7 billion to Australians.

I think it is fair to say that a fair number of people have taken advantage of the export market development grants. The figures I have show that Austrade processed 2,002 claims for grants under the export market development scheme, and paid $143m for the 1990-91 grant year. This compared with 3,035 claims, with a value of $179.6m in the 1989-90 grant year. The decline in numbers and values was, as I understand it, attributed to the changes in the scheme which came into effect on 1 July 1990. In 1991-92 a total of 2,401 claims were processed at a total value of $127.4m.

I have no doubt that the export market development grants scheme has been of assistance to exporters. As I say, we do not oppose this amendment. The grants will be paid out under us, as the program rolls on. But what chickenfeed, with great respect, it is compared with the enormous lift in the burden that is on Australian business and, particularly in this context, Australian exporters if we are to lift the taxes to which I have referred.

I will conclude a little earlier tonight because the Government's guillotine means that there is only about 20 minutes left for this debate. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin) has been good enough to attend the Parliament. Whilst he would disagree with what I have been saying, he ought to be given the opportunity to say so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very generous of you.

—It is only fair. The honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) would have liked to have spoken for a lengthy period. I assume that he is going to speak for a short time and that will leave a short period for the Parliamentary Secretary to reply. After all, we are operating in a restricted process at the moment. In summary, we support the Bill, but it is a small measure in comparison with what is needed for the real drive on exports for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the Opposition's support for this important Bill—the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill—qualified though it is by the comments made by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). The honourable member seems to be frozen in the past. He is an honourable gentleman, and I have a great affection for him, but he has that defect in many ways. He told us about opposing six taxes. Let me take just one tax that he wants to abolish—incidentally, it is a State tax—and that is payroll tax. Most people in tourism do not pay payroll tax, which is a tremendous benefit for them. Given the States rights policy of the Opposition, we wonder how it would go about convincing the States that they ought to abolish their payroll tax. Small business would be burdened with the collection of a goods and services tax. In terms of the administration of such a tax, every sale, every transaction, has to have a hard copy record. All invoices, all documents, have to be kept for seven years. Each tourism operator would be hiring a caravan or building some additions just to house the pieces of paper which would be involved, apart from the heavy cost of having staff involved in recording all of the transactions.

PARA.TAB: We need to look at what has happened to small business in Canada under the imposition of a goods and services tax. Many Canadians cross over the border and go to the United States to do their shopping because of the effect of the imposition of a GST. Small business has been hit very hard there in two ways: firstly, by the costs of collection of a goods and services tax; and, secondly, by the loss of trade that small business suffers as a result of people leaving Canada to shop across the border.

The great bulk of people in tourism—the tour operators and those who provide transport services, amenities and attractions—are small business people. People could say, `Maybe those in the tourism industry just do not have any resources; they are unable to analyse what the Opposition is putting; maybe they are just thick and are unable to assess the implications of the Opposition's policy'. Even if they were, they are people of importance and they have come strongly to the conclusion that the GST and the Opposition's policy are not for them. They have strongly rejected the Opposition's policy. They have made representations to the Opposition and those representations have been rejected.

In fairness to the honourable member for Kooyong—and to his colleague the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), the shadow Minister for tourism—he has been humiliated by his colleagues in the Opposition. He does not, or did not, support the proposal and the policy the Opposition has put forward. He has been forced, dragooned, bludgeoned, into accepting its policy, but he does not support it. We all know that.

The honourable member for Kooyong is a good colleague and I have to help him with maths. He always had difficulty, when he was shadow Treasurer, with mathematics. He made the point quite strongly and repeatedly that it is market share that is important, that we have to get back to the basics—market share. That is what the airlines in this country used to do under the two-airline agreement. They chased each other for decades about getting market share when all the time, even from Opposition days, we were saying, `It is not market share that is important; it is market size that is important'. I say to my dear colleague opposite that I would rather have 10 per cent of a billion dollar market—$100m—than 20 per cent of a $250m market, which is $50m. It is simple: 20 per cent of $250m is $50m; 10 per cent of $1 billion is $100m. The honourable member would make an awful bookkeeper. He would not survive at all.

The increase in absolute trade that has occurred out of Australia is telling the story. As that market grows, so our share of it grows. Our share of merchandise trade with Asian nations has quadrupled in real terms since 1986-87. Our trade surplus with Japan has doubled in real terms—from $2.1 billion in 1986-87 to $4.4 billion in 1991-92. Maybe the honourable member for Kooyong is like that pregnant cow that Fred Daly has talked about a lot. It knew that something wonderful was happening but it was not quite sure how it had occurred. Maybe that is what the honourable member for Kooyong was trying to tell us earlier.

I now turn to what the tourism industry in other nations thinks about the Opposition's GST policy. I quote from a letter to the editor in today's Australian Financial Review signed by Geoffrey H. Lipman, President of the World Travel and Tourism Council in Brussels, Belgium:

SPEECH.PARA: Sir, Australia would be shooting itself in the foot if it were to impose GST on tour packages pre-purchased by foreign visitors.

PARA.TAB: Your country has been ahead of the pack in recognising the enormous value of travel and tourism and in vigorously promoting your country abroad. As a result, tourism has become the leading export and foreign exchange earner for Australia, creating thousands of new jobs, investment and tax revenue. This `tourism economy' is expected to account for some 200,000 new jobs by the end of the decade.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter goes on to say:

The fact is, more and more governments are recognising that tourism is an invaluable export. Airline seats, hotel rooms, restaurant meals and merchandise bought by overseas visitors all boost trade balances and stimulate domestic economies. They are `exports' even though the purchaser takes delivery of the product in Australia rather than abroad.

PARA.TAB: Taxing tourism, like taxing any other export, will increase its costs and reduce its competitiveness. Tourism demand is sensitive to costs.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is a very accurate summary. It is the summary that is recognised by the tourism industry in this country. We must compare it with the Opposition's policy of not taxing tourism packages sold to people going abroad. This is a wonderful way of helping the Australian tourism industry: tax its customers, put a 15 per cent penalty on them—a 15 per cent disability in a world market—and make overseas travel by Australians that much more attractive. What is the Opposition really about? The honourable member for Kooyong is a dear colleague. I know he has difficulty with maths and I have helped him, but he should go away and have another look at this.

PARA.TAB: I am trying to limit the length of my speech to assist my colleague, but I want, briefly, to say something about my region—the Hunter region—and what has happened there. People have been benefiting from the export market development grants. They welcome this amendment, as does industry generally, because it opens up new horizons for them. There is one thing that we have to do with our exporters. The culture in this country is changing and we have to help people—we have to help business people—through that process of change. I refer to some companies in the Hunter region. Stebercraft of Taree is a boat building firm, and Bud-Pak is marketing a product for the packaging of sugar on board ships, where the machinery is fitted into the ships. It is a very successful Australian design. The sugar is loaded onto the vessel in bulk. The vessel pulls into the port and the packaging is done automatically on the vessel and then delivered onto the wharf.

Another company in the area is involved in the marketing and export of pure water devices. Pure Water Products is now exporting to 40 countries. There are other companies involved in light engineering and software, such as Forsythe Software and Industrial Automation Services, which also makes steel rolling mills. Assistance has been given in the manufacture of models such as the space shuttle model. That firm has had some difficulties and liquidity problems, but the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Mr Kerin), in earlier statements in this place and elsewhere, has pointed to the fact that we have to take some risks in this exercise. It is not just about giving assistance and support to those firms that can prove continuing success. In the life of a business there will be ups and downs. Those firms benefit very much from the assistance provided under this principal Act, and will benefit more from the amendments in this Bill.

Under this scheme taxable grants of 50 per cent of eligible expenditure are available for overseas promotional activity, market research and development, representation, advertising, costs of participating in overseas exhibitions, and the fares and costs of bringing agents or buyers to Australia where promotion of export sales is the objective.

Under the principal Act, the tourism industry has restrictive access to the benefits in the legislation. I will not go into detail because the time is short and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin) wishes to participate.

I conclude on this note: in all of these things there needs to be a change in culture in this country towards export—we need to become much more export oriented—but there is one area that yet needs to be overhauled, and that is the journey from the warehouse to the wharf. The Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure of this Parliament reported on that in April this year. Last Monday week in Sydney, we held a very successful forum involving exporters, importers and all the providers of services involved. It was the widest cross-section that I have ever seen collected in one auditorium of people involved in those areas. It was an excellent exercise. But what came out of it, as we on the Committee know very well, is that there is a widespread ignorance amongst exporters of how to go about exporting, how to go about minimising their costs of getting their products from their warehouse or their factory to on board a ship.

We have heard a great deal about the waterfront, but only about inside the dock gate. It is unfortunate that the mainstream media in this country are still locked inside the waterfront gate; they have not got outside the dock. There are problems on the dock. They have been addressed, and the industry readily acknowledges that. But the bigger problem identified as far back as 1984 and 1986 is the cost of getting the product from the warehouse, the factory, the farm or the mine to the wharf.

I end with these words: we have to do a great deal more as a nation in alerting exporters and importers to the need for them to look at their methods and practices and at how they can coordinate with the waterfront. They are commercial problems. They are not regulatory problems. They are not government problems. These are commercial problems and they demand a commercial solution. I hope that the mainstream media can find the key to the dock gate, open it up, go outside, start along the journey from the warehouse to the wharf, and help to further the exports of this nation.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank both the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) for their contributions in the course of this debate on the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill. I would like just to touch on one or two points raised in those contributions.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the point must be made that the extension of this scheme is a recognition of the high external costs of exporting and, in a global sense, the extremely competitive environment that Australian exporters face in trying to break into new markets. The point that was made about Australian exporters getting into Asia particularly is one that I do not think is lost on the Government nor, from the honourable member for Kooyong's comments, on the Opposition.

I pick up also the concluding remarks of the honourable member for Shortland. In the last several months I have had the opportunity of participating in some trade discussions in a number of Asian economies. I have talked to people involved in business councils between, say, Thailand and Australia, Japan and Australia and so on. The thing that strikes me very clearly is the notion that the hard yakka, the hard work that has to be put into breaking into those markets, must come from the exporters themselves. Governments can do so much. They can give assistance through these sorts of grant schemes. Austrade, certainly, can provide opportunities through introductions through our posts overseas and so on. It can open up the gates. But at the end of the day it is the exporters themselves and the Australian business community that must put in the hard work.

It was suggested to me that there are a number of ways in which this might be achieved, which might increase the opportunities of getting into Asian markets. The first is by entering into joint ventures. The second is to have people located on the ground in these economies. Too often we find that Australian, American or whatever exporters think, `There is a lucrative market in Asia now. It is an expanding economy and is growing rapidly. The growth rates are enormous. It will be easy to get into the market. We will fly in one day, talk to a couple of people, wrap up a contract and then disappear again'. But that just does not happen. We have to change the export culture in Australia. We have to get into the psyche of those countries and realise that it is hard work. Equally, once having identified the markets that we as Australians are targeting, we have to learn something about not only the economics of the market but also the social conditions and the social mores of the market in which we are trying to establish a foothold.

I have said time and time again that, if Australian companies and leaders in Australian industry have a point to put to anybody in government in this country, it is a matter of their picking up the telephone and phoning either an Opposition spokesman on trade or the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Mr Kerin), making an appointment and coming in to see those people. That does not happen in many economies around the world. So we have to expose our Australian exporters to this new culture.

The other point that I make is in relation to the comments by the honourable member for Kooyong about there perhaps being an overemphasis within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on achieving a successful outcome in GATT and the Uruguay Round. I think those comments underplay an enormous amount of work which the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development has done in the area of bilateral trade. Last month he was in Germany and in former eastern European countries leading a trade mission—in the company, I might say, of Hugh Morgan and others—to establish opportunities for Australia in that expanding market. At the moment he is in Korea, on behalf of Australia, spreading the word about Australia at a major trade expo.

About 100 of these bilateral trade agreements have been established between Australia and other countries. So I do not think it is fair and realistic to say that we have simply put all of our eggs into one basket on the question of trade. Yes, multilateral trade through the GATT and Uruguay Round negotiations is extremely important. I think both sides of the Parliament agree with that.

As I have said, we have developed strong bilateral trade relationships as well and we have also become very enmeshed in regional and subregional trade arrangements. I refer, in particular, to the APEC process. I know that there has been some discussion from both sides of this Parliament and in a wider context about what our future should hold as far as our regional approach to trade is concerned. When one considers that the Australian economy is as big as that of the ASEAN countries all put together and yet the ASEAN countries are expanding remarkably, as is north-east Asia and other market opportunities, it is clear to everyone that a regional or subregional approach to some of our trade and our trade negotiations is just as critical as are the GATT negotiations or many of these bilateral relationships which have been established through joint ministerial commissions and so on.

I will conclude, because there is a guillotine motion in place on this legislation, by saying that we would hope that the successful conclusion of the GATT Uruguay Round negotiations will give a fillip of $US170 billion to $US250 billion to global trade. This is a massive injection which will impact on Australia.

I also conclude by referring honourable members again to a document which the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development circulated to all honourable members on 15 October entitled A success story: Australia's trading performance, because I do think it goes to the question about market share versus volume, which was the point made by the honourable member for Shortland, and clearly indicates that schemes such as the EMDG are important components of our trade relationship and our trade development.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

QWN.TITLE: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES TO QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to correct an answer that I gave to the House earlier today. I informed the House that my Department will establish a new exchange rate for the purpose of calculating the entitlements of Australian pensioners receiving pensions from Britain. I wish to correct an incorrect figure which I provided inadvertently.

PARA.TAB: In the answer I gave the House, I referred to 110,000 British pensioners benefiting from this move. It should be noted that, of the 110,000 Australian pensioners receiving British pension payments, about 50,000 already receive the maximum Australian pension because of the operation of the free area, and therefore they will not receive the additional pension. PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
MIGRATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Hand:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to speak on the Migration Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Immigration (Education) Charge Bill of 1992. Lest there be any ambiguity about this matter at a later point, I want to make it clear that we will not be opposing the Bills. I want to make it very clear on behalf of the Opposition that we regard the teaching of English to new arrivals where they do not have English language capacity as one of the most important aspects of their successful settlement in Australia. They cannot achieve integration over time unless they have the ability to communicate within the society. For that reason, the teaching of English is of fundamental concern. That concern is one that is outlined very clearly in our policy. It is a commitment that our parties have had over a long period.

PARA.TAB: Having confirmed the importance of English language teaching, let me also make the point very forcefully that that commitment was re-endorsed in our Fightback! document. One of the important points that I make when I speak to ethnic communities and comment on immigration issues is that we will quarantine any expenditure reductions in the area of settlement programs because of their fundamental nature. Even though we had to make difficult decisions in that Fightback! document in relation to achieving cuts in expenditure in a whole host of areas of government endeavour, this was one of those areas in which we made it very clear that we did not expect any expenditure reductions because of the importance that we attach to these matters.

The Government has been involved internally in a whole lot of matters of contest about the education issue and the provision of English language courses. It may not always involve Ministers, but there is often a good deal of internecine warfare in relation to the way in which funding for government programs proceeds. In the recent Budget and in the joint statement by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) and his colleague, we see a working out of those difficult relationships. The Government over time has given certain commitments to English language tuition and to the development of language policies, but in no way does that bring us to a point, when we look at the culmination of all these reports and the Government's efforts to develop an Australian language and literacy policy, where these matters have been worked through.

It is important to understand in the field of adult teaching of English to speakers of another language that there are seven or so alternative programs under which the provision of English language teaching can proceed. We have the adult migrant education program, administered by this Minister's Department, for recently arrived immigrants; the English as a second language courses which are components of the labour market training programs administered through the Department of Employment, Education and Training, and they also occur within industry restructuring programs administered through the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce; the workplace reform programs which are administered through the Department of Industrial Relations; the English as a second language provision within universities, from recurrent or access or equity funding; the State funded programs within TAFE, where the Commonwealth has a very heavy involvement; the English as a foreign language program for overseas students at private and public institutions, involving the ELICOS courses in particular; and the English language intensive courses for overseas students which are conducted overseas or in Australia as part of Australia's aid expenditure program through AIDAB.

So we can see that there is an enormous complexity in the numbers of programs and the numbers of people and various government bodies—statutory authorities and departments—that are involved in the teaching of English. There are quite variable standards in relation to the outcomes; there are quite variable outcomes in value for money and the way in which the Commonwealth is able to measure results.

The AMEP was developed first in the early 1950s and then, with the development of courses for migrant professionals in 1969, universities were involved in offering assistance. We had the commencement in 1974 of English in the workplace and the home tutor schemes. We had the rapid growth and the provision from 1978, as a result of the Galbally report, of a whole range of services for refugees at migrant hostels, establishing dedicated teaching accommodation for adult migrant education. In 1985 we had the Campbell review, initiated by this Government, which enhanced the professional infrastructure of AMEP, and particularly the establishment of the National Centre for English Language Teaching and Research at Macquarie University. From 1990 to 1992 we had the national plan which defined the limits of AMEP, consistent with the report of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies.

It is in that context that it is important to note that there is a Commonwealth involvement and there are also State involvements. We have seen in the AMEP area particularly, I gather, quite independent evaluation of the benefits of that program. One of the outcomes of an evaluation by the Department of Finance is that it is estimated that the AMEP program operates, at a unit cost, 38 per cent more cheaply than the funded programs in the ESL area by DEET. That is a very important factor. I am told that this is despite the fact that the largest component of costs, the teachers' salaries, was the same at least within the State systems and, of course, that the large differential that does occur is because of the management systems that DEET in particular adopts.

The fact of the matter is that the AMEP program has brought about a very important national standard in relation to delivery of services. We have seen a standard approach to the assessment of learner proficiency, at entry to and exit from programs, and we have seen a high level of teacher qualifications, and this is very important. We have seen an improvement in productivity in recent years, particularly in relation to the way in which the program itself is operating. We have seen a shared cost-efficient approach to the development of curricula. Instead of each State developing all curriculum materials, the work has been distributed so that there are certain advantages achieved from that.

We have seen the development of the concept of learner pathways by which students can move from one course to another without repetition of content. I am sure the benefits that have been derived from all this work could be very readily shared were there more effective relationships between the providers of the various programs, and if the internecine warfare that has been going on departmentally was a matter that Ministers had the capacity to resolve. I do not believe that that resolution has occurred, and I very much doubt the Minister's ability in that contest when I look at the outcome that is announced in the statement to which the Minister referred in his second reading speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —What contest?

—The contest between the adult migrant education programs and their particular area of expertise, and the area of programs—the English as a second language training—that is administered particularly through DEET.

PARA.TAB: The Minister in his statement announced that some of the funding that has been provided by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs through the adult migrant education programs is to be moved off that board into the hands of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. So in the Minister's announcement—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a contest.
—It is clear. Last year—
—Ministers' contests are more vigorous.
—Minister, contests are far more vigorous on your side in this area—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hand interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —although I notice that there have been some very interesting rapprochements of late, and you might care to give the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who is sitting beside you, another hug.
—Don't tempt me, not after dinner.
—But we know where the contests lie.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Perhaps the honourable member could address his remarks through the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not encourage you into this, Mr Deputy Speaker. There is certainly no filling in; this is a very serious matter.

PARA.TAB: Mr Hand interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The conversation across the table will cease. The Bill is under guillotine.

—It is cutting into my time, and it may even be cutting into the time of other members. I just make the point that the Minister in his statement said that the Commonwealth spent $114.5m in 1991-92 on English as a second language training, and that came from DILGEA, his Department, at $101m, and the Department of Employment, Education and Training at $13.5m. In the year we are now addressing, 1992-93, the Commonwealth will spend $142m, comprising $138.2m from the Budget and $3.65m from user charging, of which his Department will spend $99.65m—that is, $96m from the Budget plus $3.65m raised through user charging. In absolute terms we have seen a reduction of $1.5m. DEET is to spend $42.2m, a much larger sum, and we are told that those measures follow on from the Australian language and literacy policy of 1991.

PARA.TAB: I think it will be far more important for the Government to spend time developing an overall policy to achieve better outcomes in relation to these matters, building upon the advantages that have been achieved through the AMEP program and ensuring that there is a rational framework in which all of the programs that I have mentioned operate. I want to make it very clear that, regardless of whether the Government is working in this area, the Opposition is, and it is certainly our intention that there be an overall framework of policy bringing together all of the programs in which these benefits can be clearly seen and which are available for the teaching of English.

This legislation addresses the very significant outstanding problems relating to the provision of resources for teaching English to new arrivals. It is very clear from the inquiries that the Government has taken out that the resources that it presently provides, applied on the basis that they are applied, cannot provide sufficient teaching of English to all of the people entering Australia under the immigration program as it has recently been structured. Therefore, the whole question of resources and the way in which people are admitted for migration need to be addressed.

Because of the ability to address these questions in relation to the way in which the services are provided, and to achieve economies by using the most efficient system overall, other changes had to occur. We have seen the introduction of the requirement that people entering Australia through the concessional category for migration, and those entering under the independent migration category, will now be subjected in their points testing to an assessment as to their English language capacity. English language competency will be a determining factor in many cases as to whether people are successful in migration.

I am not complaining about that because, as has been revealed in certain research tabled this week at the Bureau of Immigration Research Conference in Sydney, the costs of immigration to the Australian taxpayer in the short to medium term, at both a Commonwealth and a State level, are quite significant. It is only when it is extended over a period of 10 years that one starts to see benefits from immigration in terms of Commonwealth outlays. That is a factor.

If we have a Commonwealth Budget that is severely stressed, as the Commonwealth Budget is at this time, of course we have to look at ways of rationalising those outlays. This is the very reason for a smaller immigration program and for testing for English language competency. The Minister was encouraged by the Opposition to move in this area. The honourable member for Calwell might like to say that not only was the Minister encouraged, but he followed policy suggestions made by the Opposition.

In relation to the implementation of user charges in the area of teaching English to new arrivals—which is what this legislation is all about—this is one area in which I had not suggested this approach to the Government, and an area in which the Minister has developed some initiatives of his own volition. The honourable member for Calwell might tell us that the Minister did that with his assistance. It will be interesting to hear his comments to see whether he wants to take credit for that initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—Is it the Minister's initiative or the initiative of the honourable member for Calwell? The point is that what we have now is legislation to introduce a scheme in respect of new migrants entering Australia who do not have functional English. It is a scheme of charging for education. In it there are exemptions to cover refugees; special assistance and humanitarian categories; spouse, child and aged parent classes in the preferential family category; and other classes as yet to be prescribed. In effect, only those entering through the concessional family and independent categories, I suppose, will be required to pay tuition fees. These will operate on a sliding scale with the maximum fee being $4,080. That scheme is outlined in the Immigration (Education) Charge Bill.

PARA.TAB: The Migration Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) deals with the provision of English language tuition. Under its provisions, if a new migrant has in fact paid the charge or is exempt from its application and becomes a permanent resident, the Commonwealth will be obliged to provide that person with English language tuition for 510 hours—and 510 hours is estimated to be the average amount of tuition needed for a non-English speaker to acquire functional English. The program ceases if the person does not register within certain time limits that are specified. The Bill provides for user charging for existing migrants who enrol in the AMEP program after 1 January 1993, and the maximum fee that can be set will be $250 per student.

Because of the time limitations, I will simply say that there are certain other amendments proposed in this legislation. Those amendments deal with an anomaly that is to be removed in relation to the duty to consider a refugee status application so as to make it clear that there is no duty to consider applications by certain classes of persons. It also inserts a power to require passengers travelling on domestic routes to international flights to produce evidence of authority to be in Australia. It also inserts a new power to make regulations concerning the use of the decision-making process and certain opinions, findings and assessments or decisions by third parties or agencies. To remove uncertainty, the Bill ensures that regulations which have already been made in that area will be made validly. There is a provision to correct a recently discovered anomaly in amendments to the Act which removed the previous arrangements for people to be granted permanency by absorption.

We certainly have no objections to each of those other amendments. In that respect, the Bill will not be opposed. But I wish to take up some of the points that have been made to me over the last few days in relation to the operation of this legislation. I want to put on the record the reasons why we support this legislation and why I believe that the matters that have been raised with me—particularly by the New South Wales Teachers Federation and the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils, amongst others—if the Government wishes to press them, can be pressed on another day.

The major issue upon which a contest has been raised with the Government relates to the maximum entitlement to English tuition for newly arrived migrants to be 510 hours. My reading of the Bill—and I am not sure that those who comment on these matters have in fact read the Bill—suggests that what is undertaken in clause 6 is an obligation. It is not a maximum entitlement; it is an obligation that the Commonwealth will assume. Proposed new section 4C states:
Subject to section 4D, the Commonwealth is obliged to provide, or arrange the provision of, 510 hours of tuition in an approved English course to a person if the person:
(a) has made an application—

SPEECH.PARA: and so on. I think it is very important that that is understood.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the first time ever that obligation has been met.

—Yes, because it is an obligation. It is something that people will be able to enforce. It is not prescribing a minimum or a maximum; it is prescribing an obligation on the part of the Commonwealth, because the charges are to be made. It does not, as I understand it, mean that the Minister could not provide additional tuition under this legislation if that were his desire. I do not know what his desire is. The framework in which these matters operate often requires regulations. It may well be that when we read the detailed statement, and when regulations are brought in at a later point, what is prescribed as the obligation will be all that the Commonwealth will do. That may well be the case, but it certainly does not seem to me that the provision is one which ought to be reviewed for that reason.

PARA.TAB: There are claims that there have been restrictions placed upon access to the adult migrant education scheme. That might well be the case. This is a Budget Bill, and our view is that it is therefore not reasonable to oppose it. But the reason for the format in which these matters are being addressed, the transfer of funds to DEET and the implementation of the programs in other ways, is the difficulty that the Government has had in resolving this contest. That is clear.

The restrictions that we have in this area will lead to people having to apply for support in other areas if they do not meet them. One of those is the area of courses which are provided for permanent residents, and that comes under section 4A, where lesser fees are charged and under which the holders of health cards and registered job seekers are exempted. Obviously, for those who do not fall within those categories, other fees may be payable, and people who are in otherwise necessitous circumstances may not be able to meet them. They are matters that, as I read the proposed section, the Minister will presumably otherwise regulate, although that is a matter upon which I would need to read the section more closely.

I want to make some comments in relation to some other matters of concern that have been put before me. I want to make it clear that, while this legislation does not deal with anything other than user charging arrangements, it provides that these matters are to be dealt with within approved English courses. In other words, it is the Minister's obligation to provide English language tuition within approved courses of English study which are prescribed in proposed new sections 4A and 4B. There is some latitude, I suspect, in relation to the way in which those provisions might operate and as to where those approved courses may be provided.

There has been some discussion about issues relating to tendering. I am told that there is a report—it is not a report I have seen—in relation to the value of tendering in the adult migrant education program. I hope that the Minister will make available to me a copy of the report of the interdepartmental government committee on the review of tendering in the adult migrant education program. It might be a useful document to review.

I make it clear that the Opposition has no objection in principle to tendering. We see it as being very beneficial to ensure that programs are provided on the most cost-effective basis. I also make it very clear that the terms on which tenders are put out are important matters that need to be addressed.

Earlier in my comments this evening I mentioned the way in which the AMEP program had achieved certain goals. The benefits that have been derived from those might well provide a basis on which a tender document could be developed. My own approach to these matters is that we do not have to lower standards by putting matters out to tender. If the correct standards are outlined in the tender documents, then those concerns are obviated.

I make it plain, in case people who are interested in this subject are listening to me tonight, that I understand there will be some meetings in Sydney later on this month at which the Government will have an opportunity to put its view. I will take the opportunity of attending those meetings and of ensuring that the Opposition's approach to these matters is well understood. Our concern to develop a coherent framework of policy in this area—something the Government has failed to do—is something that we will achieve in office.

I will also ensure that the Minister's legislative framework, such as it is, will not in any way be misrepresented and that, if he is not represented at those meetings, his position is properly put. I say that only because I noticed with some pique that the Minister indicated he was not prepared to meet with certain people who had foreshadowed meetings in advance. It may well be that he takes the same view in relation to the meetings that are to be held in Sydney. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Immigration (Education) Charge Bill and the Migration Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2). The first Bill and part of the second Bill are concerned with migrant education and teaching English to migrants. There are matters in the second Bill which the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) did not refer to. In the short time available, I am going to try to divide my comments into two parts.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I want to talk about part IV of the Migration Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and PRC temporary entry permit holders; that is to say, the pre-Tiananmen Square Chinese students. This is a relevant matter because when I was overseas a number of comments were made about this issue, not the least by the honourable member for Dundas who keeps issuing press statements about what he takes to be the overwhelming majority position of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations on this matter.

Yesterday, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), in a speech to the BIR conference, referred to this issue and tried to make much of the claim that an overwhelming parliamentary majority is in favour of the position adopted by the honourable member for Dundas and himself. However, the reality is that there are nine members of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. Of those nine members, two dissented from the position that we should not fulfil the commitment given by two Prime Ministers to the Chinese students. The two members who dissented were Senator Cooney and I. In addition, when the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) returned from overseas, even though he was included in the majority, he dissented. I have also spoken to the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Catley) who is more inclined to support fulfilling the commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

Four out of the five Labor members on the Joint Standing Committee agreed with the commitments made by the two Prime Ministers and disagreed with the so-called majority position. The fact is that the honourable member for Dundas, who has been going around pretending that there is a massive majority on the Committee in favour of the position, has found that that position has been somewhat whittled away since he started making public statements. The final result is that, effectively, we have a 5 : 4 position on the Committee in relation to this matter. That is very different from the claims made by the honourable member for Dundas.

Senator McKiernan, the one member from the Labor Party who supported the majority position, had entirely honourable motives in the position he had taken. He wanted to emphasise the reasons why he took that position. As Chairman of the Committee, I agree that I should emphasise his reasons, which were that `non-discriminatory criteria are an important principle in Australia's refugee determination system'. He felt that was the reason that he should go with the majority position. The reality is that we have a public debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not going to argue with that, are you?

—I am not arguing with that. I accept that point. There is another counter argument: the commitment by this nation and two Prime Ministers to an important principle. The honourable member for Dundas knows that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) made a statement the day the report came out saying that he would consider both the majority and the minority positions and that he would be making a detailed assessment. That is the position which the Minister has followed. Instead of the honourable member for Dundas accepting that there ought to be a reasoned public debate on this matter, he goes off trying to pretend that only his position has any validity and that no-one else's position has any validity. This is a complex matter and the honourable member for Dundas ought to allow for genuine disagreement on this matter. That is all I have to say about that. Unfortunately, I do not have half an hour in which to speak, as did the honourable member for Dundas; I only have a few minutes. The honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) is laughing. It is interesting that both the honourable member for Dundas and the honourable member for Moore attacked me in this House while I was overseas performing my duties as a member of a parliamentary delegation. When I tried to give an explanation to this House—
—You dissented from your own Committee.

—What is the honourable member talking about? The Migration Regulations Committee considered the matter and deferred it until my return. It considered the matter again only yesterday. What is the honourable member saying? The reality is that I was attacked on this issue unfairly while I was overseas. When the Committee considered it as part of its agenda it decided, properly, to defer the matter until I came back, which is the honourable course and which, unfortunately, neither the honourable member for Moore nor the honourable member for Dundas pursued.

PARA.TAB: I refer now to the very important changes to migration education. The honourable member for Dundas has pointed out that there is to be a public meeting to consider these matters. No doubt this public meeting will be organised in such a way as to attack the Government. However, if we look at the proposals in the legislation, we see that they are being put in place to guarantee 510 hours tuition for every person.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't worry, Andrew.
—Would the honourable member for Dundas keep quiet. The question is that the Bill be now read a second time.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to. Would honourable members cease talking while the Chair is talking. That goes for both sides of the House.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.
Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Hand:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), which is the wider of the two Bills under consideration—the charge Bill having already been dealt with—contains provisions relating particularly to an anomaly which needs to be dealt with to consider refugee status applications and to make it clear that there is no duty to consider applications by certain classes of persons.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the amendment moved by the Opposition, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) took the opportunity in the earlier debate to address some comments in relation to nationals of the People's Republic of China in Australia. This is a very important issue and one about which there has been a report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, of which both the honourable member for Calwell, as its Chair, and I are members.

The report itself is quite clear. There were attached to it two dissenting reports. All honourable members would know the procedures that are followed in relation to parliamentary committee reports. Deliberation in relation to their content goes on over a long time. In relation to those deliberations, all members are furnished with documentation and attend meetings as they are free.

TALK.START.PARA: —Holding was overseas.

—It is certainly the case in relation to the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) that after consideration of drafts of the report over a long period of time, in which the content was quite clear—and he had been involved in discussions—when the final report was prepared, he was overseas. At that point in time, he would have had sent to his office and dispatch would have been arranged of the final report for his consideration.

PARA.TAB: On previous occasions, when reports have been made available and I have not been at a final meeting, I have made my dissent known, if I have felt sufficiently concerned about it. I suspect that what is happening is that there is an effort on the part of the honourable member for Calwell to seek revision of views and elaboration, because—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am being misrepresented. I was overseas when the honourable member for Melbourne Ports made his clarification and I made no attempt to influence him whatever.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is incorrect and a misrepresentation.
—There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.

—The point is that in relation to these matters, normally most of us take it on the chin when we lose in relation to votes in committees and when reports are brought forward. But I am now experiencing a situation in which some people take a different view of those matters.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that at any time in which the undertaking which we are told is so important that it warranted the commitment of this nation such that any successor government ought to be bound by it, the Government could have put in place regulations to honour that undertaking. It failed to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired. The question is that the Bill be now read a second time.
