DEBATE.TITLE: SEX DISCRIMINATION AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! Before I call on the honourable member for Higgins, I remind honourable members that it is the usual courtesy for members in the House not to be speaking while the Chair is speaking. I remind honourable members that that courtesy should be observed by all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are discussing the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). My approach and the approach of the coalition to questions of sex, race, disability or other discrimination starts from the proposition that each person is entitled as an individual to fundamental respect and dignity. We believe that people should be treated with respect as individuals and that they should in Australia of today have the freedom to dream their own dreams and to fulfil their own potential; that they should have the opportunity by talent and diligence to be rewarded for their efforts; and that if they should experience prejudice in some way, be it because of their religion, race, sex or anything else, that is offensive to the notion of the individual dignity of each person.

PARA.TAB: As far as I and the coalition are concerned, we find it offensive that people might be dismissed from employment because of the colour of their skin or refused service in clubs or hotels or be treated in some way as less than full human beings because of their sex or marriage or potential pregnancy. Because we feel that way, and feel that way strongly, we believe that there is a very important place for anti-discrimination law—anti-discrimination law that says that people should be treated equally on the basis of their talent and their ability and what they have to offer; anti-discrimination law that says that it is offensive to treat somebody as less than a full citizen with full rights because of his race; anti-discrimination law that provides a remedy against injustice.

I believe that there is a deep sense of injustice in many circumstances where discrimination occurs—for women in the work force who see men of lesser ability promoted over them, or for people unable to get jobs because they are women and therefore deemed to be likely to fall pregnant at some time or another and not rewarded on the basis of their ability. There is a place for anti-discrimination law that gives a remedy for injustice. There is also a place for anti-discrimination law that performs an educative role, that says to the community at large: we, as a tolerant society, believe in these ideals and these values; we, as a tolerant society, find offensive conduct that falls short of those desires and those ideals.

One of the advantages of anti-discrimination law is that over the years it has performed that educational role and changed community perceptions and attitudes. One might say it was changing community perceptions and attitudes which led to the law, or one might say that the law has led to the change in attitudes. But if they are mutually reinforcing, so much the better. In the area of anti-discrimination law there is always the risk that the Parliament, the State, the opinion formers or the opinion leaders can go too far. If there is one thing that could really hamper equality of opportunity in this country, it is that there might be an over-reaction in one form or another. As I said before, discrimination law is there to prevent injustice, but if it should ever become the tool of injustice by overreaching then it would be destructive and, indeed, destroy laudable objectives that it is otherwise directed towards.

We have seen developments in the United States where there has been over-reaction. We have seen policies of bussing where black children were bussed into white neighbourhoods and white children were bussed into black neighbourhoods. This was all done in the name of anti-discrimination, but I believe the policy was fundamentally flawed and, if anything, would lead to a hostile reaction. We have also seen it in the United States in relation to quotas which say that in universities or in jobs it is important to have such and such a per cent of a particular race or a particular sex, and, regardless of ability or merit, affirmative action steps in and makes those places available.

As far as I am concerned, affirmative action which goes to bussing and quotas or says that people ought to be promoted or rewarded not on the basis of ability but on the basis of sex or race or some other distinguishing characteristic is really no better than straight discrimination. It is inverse discrimination. It looks at a person's race, sex or colour and deals with that person on that basis rather than looking at his or her underlying qualities such as diligence: those things which ought to be taken account of on an equal basis.

The proposals that are made in these Bills are a bit like the curate's egg—some good, some bad. There are some very good proposals which I will describe in due course and there are some bad ones which I will also delineate in due course. It makes it difficult to vote one way or t'other on a Bill like this, but I wish to outline on behalf of the Opposition where we stand in relation to the individual proposals.

I come first to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. Essentially, this Bill does two things. First, it provides for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner within the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The Commissioner is to report yearly on the exercise of human rights by Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. He is to monitor what is done by Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities in the field and to report to Parliament on the progress that has been made in respect of Aboriginal human rights. That is something we welcome.

The coalition believes that the position of Aborigines in our society is still not what it ought to be and that they still suffer from ingrained disadvantage. We welcome proposals to remedy that. That is not to say that we are happy about turning this into an industry, because I do not believe creating an industry around disadvantage in the end helps the disadvantaged. But where there are sensible proposals that can advance the position of Aboriginal people, we welcome them. We would like to see the position of Aboriginal people in our society enhanced.

Secondly, this Bill proposes that the Sex Discrimination Act, which currently renders it unlawful to discriminate on the basis of sex, should also render it unlawful to discriminate in employment on the basis of family obligation. We see this as an important recognition of the institution of the family in our society. Just as we would find it offensive for somebody to be dismissed from employment by reason of his or her marriage or sex, so too we would find it offensive for somebody to be dismissed by reason of having family obligations.

The legislation is to be welcomed for introducing prohibitions on dismissal in employment on the grounds of family status. It elevates the importance of the family to the same elevation that the Act gives in relation to sex, pregnancy and marriage. This is not to say that somebody in employment could say, `I have young children to mind and, therefore, if I leave at 3 o'clock every afternoon I can't be dismissed, even though my job might be from 9 to 5', or, `Because I can't get to work on time, I can't be affected in any other way because that would amount to family discrimination'.

The Bill does not say that, because discrimination occurs where somebody is treated less favourably than another person in the same circumstances. If, for example, a person with family responsibilities were doing a 9 to 5 job the same as a person without family responsibilities and the person with family responsibilities was dismissed, one would be treating that person less favourably than the other person in like circumstances. If the two people are not in like circumstances—if one person is working a 9 to 5 day and the other one is leaving early—one cannot say it is discrimination by reason of family responsibilities. Nor would we say the legislation should ever apply in a situation such as that.

As I said before, in employment—as in all of these areas—the important thing is to focus on talent, ability and diligence. That is what ought to be done. We would hope that employers would be neutral as to the private circumstances of a person's life. But in the circumstance where a person is not performing to the requirements of the position and where a fair day's work is expected for a fair day's pay, that would not take away the rights of the employer. We think this Bill has merit. We think it has some very good features and we support it.

I come now to the sex discrimination amendments. In part, the amendments that come forward in this Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 come from an inquiry conducted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs chaired by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch). It was a long inquiry and the report contained some good and some bad recommendations. To his credit, the honourable member for Fisher worked at it diligently for a long time and took a lot of evidence. I commend him for his efforts. However, the recent interest of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in this particular topic is wholly different. It is wholly new found and wholly politically driven. I would not for a moment put the honourable member for Fisher on the same low level as the Prime Minister in respect of the honourable member's interest in this particular subject.

As I said before, there are some bad recommendations in that report which I would disagree with. I would not support the recommendation to extend the Sex Discrimination Act in its application to religious organisations. If somebody holds a bona fide religious belief which means that, in accordance with the tenets of that religion, he does not believe there should be interchangeable roles for men and women, I think he ought to have the freedom to exercise that belief. For example, I would oppose the thought of applying the Sex Discrimination Act to the Catholic Church by saying, `You are discriminating because you don't have women priests'. I think that there should be full freedom in that area to abide by religious belief. The honourable member for Fisher says that this would be the situation only in relation to religious organisations where the requirement was reasonable. We have that rider on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —And in education.

—But I would maintain that argument even in relation to educational institutions. There could be a Catholic institution, such as an all boys school, which is staffed by all brothers. I do not think we should apply the Sex Discrimination Act to that situation if, in accordance with religious beliefs, it requires that particular staffing arrangement. The Government is getting into the very difficult area of conflict of human rights, which I certainly would not resolve against religious freedom.

PARA.TAB: There is added protection in this legislation for people who lodge complaints, and that is a good thing. If the Government wants people to take up the conciliation mechanism, they must know that if they lodge a complaint they will be protected. We support the parts of the Bill that deal with that. The Bill contains an added mechanism for enforcement. Under this proposal, if the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission makes a determination, it can be registered in the Federal Court and there are 28 days in which to apply for a review. Unless a review is applied for, it becomes enforceable. If a review is applied for, all issues of fact and law can be reconsidered, but no new evidence can be entered.

I hope that, by the same token, if the matter is reviewed, any evidence that has been taken by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission that is not admissible for the purposes of the Court or is unreliable would be also taken out. I would not like to see a situation in which a commission that does not operate in accordance with the rules of evidence effectively binds the Court in relation to admissible evidence. The sensible part of that proposal is that it is a more straightforward mechanism for determination. The obligation will be upon the people who are taking the action to bring out all the evidence in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission rather than to hold back evidence and take their chances on a de novo rehearing in the Federal Court.

It is an interesting mechanism also because we have no enforceable orders in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission because of the separation of the judicial and non-judicial power. Whether this proposal gets around it is an open question. I foreshadow that there will be an open argument at one point on the constitutionality of that provision. If it is unconstitutional, the Opposition will not support it but, until it is declared to be unconstitutional, we will assume it is valid and we will support it. It will also be possible to complain of sexual harassment in a wider class of cases, such as the provision of goods and services or accommodation, or where sexual harassment goes on in unions. I think that most women find it offensive to have lewd suggestions made to them, and as far as possible we should discourage such conduct.

I am concerned about the definition of sexual harassment. I think it is altogether very wide and rather vague. I think it would be possible to push it to extremities. It needs a very thorough review as to the kind of conduct that does and does not come into it. Given that that is the definition that stands, we believe that sexual harassment should no more take place in the granting of accommodation than it should in the granting of employment.

There are some things in this Act that are plain silly; for example, the provisions in this Act to introduce group complaints—not only in the Sex Discrimination Act but also in the Racial Discrimination Act and the Disability Discrimination Bill. Under the proposal put forward in this Bill, to make a group complaint of sex discrimination or race discrimination, a person just describes the class and all people in that class are joined into that complaint unless they go down and take themselves out of it. That is offensive to the notions of justice. How can my rights be determined by somebody who takes an action and describes a class that includes me? How can my rights be determined just because I did not get down there, maybe did not even know about it—probably did not know about it—and did not pull myself out of it? The provisions go on to say that people whose rights are determined as part of a class cannot take their own complaint later on. Their rights have been subsumed into the class. This is the idea that the Labor Party loves of class justice, class litigation and class determination of rights—all in the context of legislation that is supposed to be looking after the dignity of the individual.

What will happen when somebody takes a class complaint on behalf of all Aborigines in the country? Will the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission inquire into whether all Aborigines in the country so described in a group complaint have suffered discrimination in one way or another? What about if somebody takes a class action for sex discrimination? The whole notion is fraught with difficulty. The whole notion is wrong in principle. It is just plain silly. We will reverse it. We do not believe in subsuming individual rights in classes, whether it be in relation to product liability, sex discrimination or race discrimination.

The fundamental point about justice is that, if people have complaints they make them, and they have their cases determined on the merits and facts of their cases. People do not have their rights distinguished by somebody else who says, `You're a member of a class that has a cause of action', who leads all the evidence and has the determination before they have even heard of it, so that when people want to take their own complaints, they are told, `Sorry, your rights have gone. Mr X was down here. He's already had your case for you. Your rights have been extinguished. They were taken in as part of the class'. How ridiculous! It is offensive to the ordinary notions of justice and it will be unworkable. I had hoped to move during this debate amendments to take out those provisions. This debate is being guillotined and I probably will not have the opportunity to move them formally. Because the debate has been brought on very quickly, we have not had as much time as we would like to have had to draw up the amendments carefully. The object of the amendments to be moved in my name is to take out that provision for group complaints.

There are other plain silly things in this Act, such as the proposal to have the Sex Discrimination Commissioner complaining to the Industrial Relations Commission that awards are sexist. How ridiculous! If the Government cannot trust its industrial relations commissioners to avoid sexism, it ought to sack them, rather than to have one government employee argue before another group of government employees that they got it wrong. How many government employees do we need to talk to each other in this country? There is one easy answer to avoiding the sexist award, and that is to make good appointments, or maybe even to have an educational workshop for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. I would not wish an educational workshop on anybody, but that seemed to me to be a much better idea than opening up cases so that the Sex Discrimination Commissioner can lecture the Australian Industrial Relations Commission on sexism in its awards.

I take the interest of the honourable member for Fisher in this matter seriously. The Prime Minister introduced this Bill. He has a newfound interest in women's issues. It is a newfound interest which is born wholly out of the desire to secure women's votes at the next election. He is no recently born-again lion of women's rights. We have only to read what he said in the Parliament when he first came here to see what his views are. Great lions of women's rights who have effectively been running the Government since 1983 do not move amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act on the eve of an election.
Where the Prime Minister's interest in this matter came from has appeared in the press. In April 1992, Tim Dodd of the Australian Financial Review reported that the Prime Minister was to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . appoint feminist author and journalist Dr Anne Summers to his staff on a three-month contract to review the selling of the Government's women's policies.

That is what she was put there for: the selling of the Government's women's policies. She was not put there to inquire into what could be done to advance women's rights; she was put there to inquire into what could be done to sell the Labor Party to women. She is an $86,000-a-year consultant whose task is to try to help the Labor Party get elected. The Australian Financial Review reported in August 1992:

PARA.TAB: Delivering one of her first speeches since returning to Australia to advise the Prime Minister, author and journalist Dr Anne Summers told an audience in Sydney last Friday that some "very positive" changes to the Sex Discrimination Act were on the cards.
But she was careful to avoid giving away more concrete information about her unusual role on Paul Keating's staff.

SPEECH.PARA: She was right. That was in August 1992, and the Australian reported in October 1992 that the Prime Minister was extending the three-month contract until the next election in what sources described as `a broadened political role'. What we have here is an $87,000 a year consultant to get the Labor Party re-elected, paid out of taxpayers' money. She came onto the Prime Minister's staff. Then all of a sudden we have a flurry of activity on the Sex Discrimination Act because he has a problem selling the Government's policy to women voters.

PARA.TAB: Any poll will tell us that the Prime Minister fares badly with the women vote. His problem is not that he does not move enough amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act but that, in his every appearance, with his gutter language and vicious personal attacks, with his braggery and bravado, he offends women. The Prime Minister is now talking about taking violence off television, or putting it back to 9.30 at night. I think he ought to put the replay of Question Time—that is why it has to be replayed so late at night—on at 9.30 at night, because people will see as much violence and bad example from the Prime Minister in Question Time as they are ever going to see from a public figure. The bravado, the braggery and the personal attacks—all of the things that give this Prime Minister a problem with women—derive from the way in which he carries on the political affairs of this country. It is not from the fact that he does not move enough amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act. His problems will not be remedied by paying full time consultants to help him sell his policies to women.

What women voters see—in fact, what all Australian voters see—is a confrontationist, divisive and aggressive Prime Minister. That is his problem. His other problem with women voters is that he has put so many women out of work, and so many of their husbands and children out of work, that they do not feel too benign towards him. They know that he cannot fix the problem in Australia because he caused it. They, as much as anybody else, want to see an economy where they have a chance of a job or, if they choose to look after their children and family, where their husbands have a chance of a job, where there is some security in the home, some future for the children, and some future for them.

Ensuring that women are treated with dignity and respect in our society involves much more than mere legislation. I am sure those opposite would agree with me on that. It is an attitudinal matter; it is a matter of socialisation; it is a question of the attitudes that children pick up in the family; it is the attitudes they see being passed on to them from their parents; it is the attitudes they see in their leaders; it is the attitudes they see in family life; it is the attitudes they see from the moral leaders of the nation and the churches; and it is the quality of national life. It is much bigger than legislation. It is directing to all of those facets an attitude that is passed on from generation to generation that says people should be treated on the basis of ability and merit, without discrimination for their colour, or their sex, or their marriage, or their family. That is the best hope for ensuring that we do away with offensive discrimination in this country; that is the best hope—it is not a legislative answer alone. As I said before, the role of the legislation is to remedy obvious injustice and to engage in an educational role, but it is much bigger than that, and something that we must direct ourselves and our attention towards in that multifaceted way.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) was quite kind in his comments to me, so I am somewhat reluctant to take a great deal of issue with his contribution. But I am afraid I cannot leave unanswered some of his claims about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in particular the sorts of glowing statements which he started his speech with. He started off with the grand, philosophical framework into which these things should be placed, and in particular where the Opposition sits on this matter. I hope I am not quoting him incorrectly, but he said that the Opposition Liberal and National parties strongly support anti-discrimination legislation, and they see a role for it. I am very pleased to hear that because that is in very stark contrast to the initial enactment of this legislation back in only 1984—we are not talking that many years ago—when the legislation was opposed most vigorously by the Liberal and National parties, and it was kept in the Senate for some incredible length of time.

PARA.TAB: It should have been a piece of legislation that had a long time for the public to become familiar with and for public consultation and debate because it is important social legislation. I do not decry its having a long gestation period, but I do find it a little bit of a road to Damascus type of conversion now to have this very strong support, this place in the sun for anti-discrimination legislation, because that certainly was not the case in 1984 when the Act was passed.

I remember going to the election in 1987, when I was elected, and fighting the election campaign. The policy which the Liberal and National parties took into that election was to repeal the Sex Discrimination Act and the Affirmative Action Act. Today, even though they no longer hold that view, it is still their attitude and their stated policy to abolish the Affirmative Action Agency and have the functions of that Agency taken on by the Department of Industrial Relations, while at the same time cutting in half the resources given to that department. I find that a little hollow—although I am pleased to see the broad, philosophical framework—in terms of past actions. But if we are getting some way down the path in terms of a bipartisan position on these issues, I certainly welcome that.

Then we had the honourable member say that the Prime Minister is very much a latter-day convert to these issues, and it is all terribly cynical that he has taken any interest in the position of women at all in terms of this legislation. Can I say, in terms of taking some interest in these matters, that the honourable member for Higgins was a member of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee throughout the life of this inquiry. His involvement in the inquiry was absolutely zero. We had no comments and no feedback from him. He was sent the material and he had access to it, but he gave us, unfortunately, none of the philosophical wisdom that we heard tonight. Maybe we would have been able to produce a much better report if we had had the wisdom of the honourable member for Higgins, but unfortunately we were denied it.

I find it a little hypocritical and hollow for him to come into the House and point the finger at the Prime Minister and to say that the Prime Minister is a recent convert to these things. We had an inquiry that went for 2 1/2 years, the honourable member was a member of the Committee, and he took no role in it at all except to turn up to the final meeting when the Committee had its full committee meeting to endorse the report. I do not know whether his role during that final meeting, from memory, was terribly helpful. Nonetheless, I welcome some of the support which he has indicated tonight.

He went on to talk about the Bills and where he saw good points in them. In relation to the amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act, he said he was agreeing with three of them. The first one dealt with the changes to the victimisation provisions, to allow complaints of victimisation to be proceeded with by way of conciliation rather than simply being a matter that had to go straight to the court. I welcome that support. He also indicated support for the change in the enforcement procedures relating to determinations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I very much welcome that because I think it is an improvement; it will make it a lot more straightforward and it will give people some sort of extra encouragement to pursue their rights knowing that, at the end of the day, if the determination is made in their favour, the thing is not utterly worthless because the whole process has to go to the Federal Court and be argued completely again. That is not to say that the Court does not play an important role in these matters, and that it should not be a full court review; that is not changed by these amendments.

The third element of change where the honourable member indicated the support of the Opposition concerned the sexual harassment provisions. I very much welcome that support of the Opposition. It is an important issue in terms of the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act. The honourable member said he thought the definition of `harassment' was a bit wide and vague and could conceivably bring in all manner of behaviour. The point I would make is that this is an objective test to be determined at first instance by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission if a complaint is made. It is not purely a subjective test of someone saying, `Look, I felt humiliated or hard-done by by the conduct'. It has to have been actions which a reasonable person would regard as humiliating or degrading. Hence in that way I do not believe it is nearly as vague as the honourable member makes out. It is quite a workable definition. It is a definition which has largely existed in Federal legislation since 1984. Similar definitions have existed in State legislation for even longer periods. There is no evidence whatsoever of these definitions being vague, unworkable or anything of the sort.

There were two areas where the Opposition said it does not support the amendments in this legislation. The first deals with group complaints. What we had from the honourable member for Higgins was simply his arguments against representative actions, which we have heard a few times now, most principally in terms of changes to the Federal Court of Australia Act. I can understand that he has a different point of view about the process of how representative action should work, but that debate is in relation to the broader question of representative actions. What this Act does is merely bring in line different provisions concerning group actions in the Sex Discrimination Act, repeal them and apply the same law as now applies in the rules of the Federal Court. What it is doing is simply standardising the provisions concerning group complaints so that it applies across the board.

We can have our argument about whether these group complaint provisions are sensible or fair, but that is a broader argument. To pick on this particular legislation and say, `This is wrong in terms of the Sex Discrimination Act or the Racial Discrimination Act' really misses the point. All we are doing is standardising the provisions. In my mind, like provisions in like legislation should be the same. I think the honourable member misses the point somewhat in his argument there. He is really arguing a case against another point.

The honourable member for Higgins went on to say that the Opposition opposes the idea that the Sex Discrimination Act should apply to the industrial system, that it should apply to awards. This is a joke. Apparently it is laughable, in the eyes of the Opposition, that the Sex Discrimination Commissioner should have any role in making an application to the Industrial Relations Commission and arguing that a provision in an award is discriminatory. What I would say to the honourable member is that if he did at some stage have the opportunity to go through the evidence that was put to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on this point—we did receive very good evidence in relation to the application of the Act in this area—he would see that it was pointed out that there were numerous awards that still contain discriminatory provisions and that it was quite ridiculous that this area of Australian society should be exempt from the general rules which are outlined in the Sex Discrimination Act.

A similar provision to this has operated for some years in the Western Australian legislation. That particular Act applies to State awards in Western Australia and to the industrial system over there. It has not caused great ridicule or problem. People have not seen it as terribly ridiculous that the State commissioner over there has a role in these matters. Given the industrial relations approach of the Opposition, which is basically saying that there is no role for a central umpire in this, to have as a starting point the application of the Sex Discrimination Act in the industrial system, I think, will be a very important safeguard to the position of women workers.

Finally, the honourable member went on to attack the Prime Minister. He said that women have a problem with the Prime Minister because he is confrontationist and divisive and they do not like his behaviour in the Parliament. He may well have a point there, but I suggest to him that the same public opinion polling is showing the very poor standing of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson)—also amongst Australian women—and I would suggest that the same criticism can be laid very much at his door.

DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is somewhat unusual for a Minister to participate in a debate in this manner and I thank the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) for allowing me to do so and relinquishing his speaking rights. I pay tribute to the Opposition for its support for the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) but, most important of all, I pay tribute to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) who has been unstinting in his support for giving effect to what I think the whole Parliament recognises as a very important reform. I seek to speak briefly on the Bill because I have a very strong commitment to this proposal and some significant degree of involvement in making it happen.

PARA.TAB: The establishment of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner is a direct result of the first recommendation of the final report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. The Commonwealth Government gave support to 338 of 339 of the Royal Commission recommendations and, on the occasion of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the 1967 referendum, the whole Parliament gave support to the Commonwealth response. Importantly, the Commonwealth has backed its commitment with $400m over five years, with targeted reforms addressed to areas of Aboriginal disadvantage. I have been very concerned to ensure that the commitments of governments, those promises of governments given in response to the Royal Commission at the State, Territory and Commonwealth levels, are monitored by a rigorous regime of accountability designed to keep the nation honest in its commitments to Aboriginal people over the coming decade.

The Bill before the House seeks to establish an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner within the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the functions of that Commissioner will include the production of an annual state-of-the-nation report on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issues. A commitment to give effect to this initiative was made by the Commonwealth in response to the very first recommendation of the Royal Commission.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is, I believe, a highly appropriate body to administer the function of the Social Justice Commissioner. The Commission has had an active involvement in a number of inquiries, including the Toomelah inquiry which raised public awareness of the extent of Aboriginal disadvantage and issues to be addressed by governments. However, I regret to say that there are hundreds of communities, such as Toomelah and Mornington Island, around this country and that is why I believe that a national and independent perspective on the extent of the disadvantage and the action that needs to be taken is so critical. In producing the state-of-the-nation report, the Commissioner will consult with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community and, of course, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

The work of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner will be greatly supplemented by the extensive information already available to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. This initiative is significant because it will also lead to independent scrutiny of the performance of the nation in giving effect to the commitment to social justice, which is an essential part of the reconciliation process.

DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose this Bill. It is the intention of the Opposition to move a second reading amendment in the form that has been circulated. The form of that second reading amendment recapitulates the views of the Opposition regarding affirmative action. We have from time immemorial supported the principle of equal opportunity for all employees. But we have likewise had some reservations about bureaucratic solutions to problems of discrimination in the workplace and have never embraced the notion that equal opportunity for women and men is commensurate with the number of bureaucrats and the size of bureaucracies which are created in order to enhance their position.

PARA.TAB: The text of the second reading amendment is to reaffirm the commitment of the House to the principle of equal opportunity for all employees, and I would not imagine that the members of the Government would have any difficulty with that. The second limb of the amendment, which is something that the coalition feels very strongly about, calls upon the Government to support the recruitment, training and promotion of all employees solely on the basis of merit. I would not imagine that any members of the Government would have any difficulty in embracing that part of the amendment. I look forward to the action of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan), who is at the table and who has carriage of this Bill, in indicating the support of the Government for the second reading amendment.

There are one or two specific things in the legislation that I would like to comment about. It does remain the view of the coalition that the existence of a separate agency or group in order to enforce this legislation is unnecessary, although we do not intend to vote against this Bill because we would not want in any way to allow it to be suggested that the coalition was opposed to the concept of the equality of opportunity in the workplace. I am a sufficient cynic of the behaviour and the attitude of the Government and of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to imagine that any action of the coalition which was the least bit negative regarding this Bill would be totally misrepresented as some kind of assault upon the status of women in our community.

The Prime Minister has embarked on a thinly disguised campaign, which the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) a few moments ago acknowledged was absolutely necessary in order to repair his electoral stocks with women. As the honourable member for Fisher said, there was a point in the charge that the Prime Minister had a problem with women. I think he is dead right. Anybody who has put as many women out of work as has the Prime Minister has a problem with women. That man has got to go. Anybody who has caused the problem he has caused has no hope at all of fixing it. Anybody who has put as many women and their husbands out of work as this man has done has a real problem with women. He has a real problem with men and with Australians generally.

I make it very clear that we will not be voting against this Bill, but we will proceed with the second reading amendment and we invite the Government to support it. I hope the Government will have absolutely no problem with the impeccable principle of non-discrimination—an impeccable liberal principle in its broadest sense—that people ought to be recruited on the basis of merit and merit alone. Nothing else should determine the entitlement of somebody to a job.

The true state of non-discrimination is a state where people are chosen entirely on merit, without any semblance of suggestion of quotas, coercion, pressure or anything of that kind. It ought to be entirely on a basis of merit. I am sure the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who I have long respected in this Parliament, would have no difficulty at all in accepting that principle. I will be very interested to see how he votes on the second reading amendment. I therefore move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "while not denying the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1)reaffirms its commitment to the principle of equal opportunity for all employees; and
(2)calls on the Government to support the recruitment, training and promotion of all employees solely on the basis of merit".

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sad day when the generals of the Labor Party get their troops to vote against a resolution reaffirming the commitment of the House to the principle of equal opportunity for all employees. They have just voted against a commitment of the House to equal opportunity for all employees.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: is it in order for the honourable member for Higgins to be debating the Bill that has just been debated? We are now on the Mutual Recognition Bill.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—No, it is very much out of order. The honourable member for Higgins will address the Bill before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great many things have to be mutually recognised under the Mutual Recognition Bill 1992, including the recognition that the generals of the Labor Party have just made a major error, and they took with them the Independent member for North Sydney (Mr Mack) and the so-called Independent member for Wills (Mr Cleary), voting against the equality of opportunity—

—I rise on a point of order. Mr Deputy Speaker the honourable member for Higgins's Leader cannot sing the national anthem because he does not know the words, and the honourable member is on the wrong Bill. He does not know the right words for that, either.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I hope for the sake of the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) that he never has to sing for his supper. He will die of famine. The Mutual Recognition Bill, of course, is something that the honourable member for Barton would be well aware of. It forms part of a legislative scheme that involves the enactment of complementary legislation by each of the States and the Commonwealth. The purpose of the scheme is to establish the legal framework for the mutual recognition by the States and Territories of each other's differing regulatory standards regarding goods and occupations.

PARA.TAB: The scheme proposes to implement two models of mutual recognition, one applicable to goods and the other to occupations. The objectives of the models are to remove unnecessary impediments to interstate trade in goods arising from differing State and Territory standards and regulations, and artificial barriers to the mobility of labour amongst States and Territories arising from local registration or licensing laws. When implemented, the models will contribute to the creation of a more efficient national market. They will also enhance Australia's international competitiveness.

Mutual recognition arose out of a series of meetings of Commonwealth, State and Territory heads of government which have been conducted over the past two years with the objective of achieving better intergovernmental relations to improve the operation of the national economy. Agreement was reached by heads of government at the October 1990 Special Premiers Conference to work towards implementing a scheme of mutual recognition throughout Australia, with the aim of removing inefficiencies brought about by varying standards and regulatory regimes, movement of goods and labour in the national markets. The agreement was reached in the context of enhancing the flexibility and competitiveness of the Australian economy.

The scheme was finalised on 11 May 1992 when heads of government signed the final agreement endorsing a revised version of the legislation substantially in the form now proposed for enactment. The agreement requires the States and Territories to use their best endeavours to pass the necessary legislation by 31 October 1992 and for the Commonwealth to use its best endeavours to pass legislation by 1 January.

The clear support which the scheme has had from governments of all persuasions is an indication of the importance of mutual recognition to the Australian economy. The whole purpose of Federation was to remove customs and tariff barriers between the States when the six colonies had their own controls over tariffs. There was not free movement of goods throughout the whole of Australia. Federation partially achieved that. The great section 92 of the Constitution was brought in to allow free trade between the States. This is, if you like, another example of cooperative federalism taking the step one stage further.

The long term benefits of mutual recognition for the Australian economy will be significant. It will facilitate a national market for goods and the free movement of capital and labour. The unnecessary costs to producers in accommodating minor differences in regulatory requirements of States and Territories in relation to goods will be removed. Labour mobility will be enhanced with the removal of artificial barriers linked to registration and licensing laws. This will result in the more efficient use of the skills of the labour force.

The scheme will also provide some incentive for jurisdictions to review and to rationalise their regulations for various products. In the long term, jurisdictions whose regulations are less costly to meet may attract a greater number of producers. Similarly, producers might be attracted to a jurisdiction because consumers may prefer goods produced in that jurisdiction when it is perceived to impose higher standards. There will also be improved competitiveness due to economies of scale made possible by the rationalisation of manufacturing activities since the output of one plant will be able to be sold throughout Australia without modification or additional specification.

The mechanism for implementing this scheme is under section 51(xxxvii) of the Commonwealth Constitution. The Territories will request the enactment of a Bill and, once enacted, the Bill will override any State or Territory Act or regulation that is inconsistent with the principles of mutual recognition set out in the Bill. This is achieved through section 109 of the Constitution which provides that a Commonwealth Act prevails over State Acts to the extent of the inconsistency.

The Bill provides for two models of recognition: one for goods and another for occupations. In the spirit of cooperative federalism and mutual recognition, I believe that there is scope to extend mutual recognition to other parts of the Australian economy. This is a start, and it is one that we welcome. By no means should we think that mutual recognition finishes with goods and occupations. I believe that, in many other areas where there are differing regulations, the principle of mutual recognition can be extended.

Indeed, the concept of mutual recognition may be one of the great new concepts of federalism—the idea that under referrals of powers the Commonwealth can act in the area or, indeed, without referrals of powers where the States can enact for themselves mutual recognition and thereby assume compatibility and harmonisation between the different requirements. I think as we move into the next century the idea and the object of renewing federalism could be greatly advantaged by the idea of mutual recognition.

Of course, the idea of cooperative federalism, new federalism, was very much a pioneering work of the Greiner Government. I pay tribute to the former Premier of New South Wales, to Gary Sturgess and to others who were part of it. Indeed, the last Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, was very much part of the move towards cooperative federalism before his untimely demise at the hands of the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who is not nearly as committed to the process of federalism through the venue of the Special Premiers Conference.

Part 2 of the Bill implements the goods model. Essentially, it provides that Australian producers who comply with the laws in their place of production will be free to distribute and sell their products throughout Australia without the need to comply with the regulatory standards in other States or Territories. Similarly, goods imported from overseas which meet the standards of the importing State or Territory may be sold without restriction throughout Australia. Interstate goods which do not comply with the standards of the State in which they are being sold will be required to identify their State of origin. This is a minimum requirement to give consumers an opportunity to seek further information as a basis for making more informed trade-offs between quality and price.

Mutual recognition will operate as a defence for anyone prosecuted in one jurisdiction for breaching a law which has the effect of prohibiting the sale of a product which was produced in accordance with the standards and regulations of the jurisdiction in which it was produced or into which it was imported. State and Territory governments will be permitted to enact temporary laws exempting a good from the scheme where there is a genuine risk to the health or safety of their citizens, or a real threat of pollution. During the life of that legislation, up to 12 months, the States and Territories will have the time to negotiate an agreed standard to deal with the problem, if considered necessary. But if agreement is not reached, mutual recognition will apply when the relevant law expires, and the sale of the goods will be permitted.

In addition, mutual recognition will not apply to certain products for which a national market is not considered to be appropriate. These include firearms, gaming machines and pornographic material. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be aware that, much to its shame, Canberra has become the porn and X-rated video capital of Australia. The Federal coalition will take the decision, which this Government will not take: to ban the export of X-rated videos and the production of X-rated videos in the Australian Capital Territory. We would not want to see a Bill like this allow something that can be done in the Australian Capital Territory to be mutually recognised by other States. Indeed, the Bill will not allow that because it specifically excludes pornographic material.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Minister starts piping up, if the Government really were serious about violence and protecting children, and if there were great concern about standards on this particular issue, there is one very easy thing it can do: address itself to the X-rated video industry in the ACT. The Federal coalition has always made it clear that this is its policy in respect of the ACT.

PARA.TAB: As I said before, certain areas where a national market is not considered to be appropriate will be excluded from the operation of this Act. Those areas include firearms, gaming machines and pornographic material. Such goods, including any imported from interstate or overseas, will continue to be regulated in each jurisdiction by the laws of that jurisdiction.

There will, undoubtedly, be cases where the application of the mutual recognition principle will have undesirable results. I suppose the worst case scenario is mutual recognition resulting in lowest common denominator standards. One could think of innumerable examples where this could actually happen. But if it should be the case that a particular State has a standard that is lower than the national average, and advantage is taken of that, I believe it is proper that the matter should be addressed in discussions between the States. I am sure that the States concerned would be able to make that point felt, and I am sure that they would be able to bring suasion to bear on the particular government concerned.

At the end of the day we have to ask ourselves the fundamental question: in a Federation like Australia, can we say that, if something is good enough for Victoria, it is not good enough for Queensland, or that, if something is good enough for Western Australia, it is not good enough for South Australia? The fact is that, when it comes to occupations and when it comes to goods, we are Australians.

I think we can fairly say to ourselves that State governments, elected as they are, and bringing to bear standards in a particular State, can be trusted sufficiently for their standards to be mutually recognised. If that were not the case, we would effectively go back to the situation that we were at with Federation, with Customs and tariffs on the borders to ensure that the States had free and sovereign reign to run independent policies as against each other's.

Now I come to the question of occupations. Part 3 of the Bill implements the occupation model. It essentially provides that, if a person is registered to carry out an occupation in one State or Territory, then he or she will be able to be registered and carry on the equivalent occupation in another State or Territory. The rationale is that, if someone is good enough to practise a profession or occupation in one State or Territory, then he or she should be able to do so anywhere in Australia. Essentially, all jurisdictions will rely on the place of first registration to properly assess that person.

A person who wishes to commence work in another State will be required to lodge written notice with the local registration authority seeking registration in an equivalent occupation. Once such notice has been lodged, the person will be entitled to commence work. Registration must be granted within one month of lodgment of the notification unless the local registration authority is of the view that a statement or information in the notice or documentary evidence or information provided as to existing registration is materially false or misleading or that the registration sought is not for an equivalent occupation and equivalence cannot be achieved by imposing conditions. The Commonwealth Administrative Appeals Tribunal will hear appeals against decisions of local registration authorities and will have the power to declare an occupation to be non-equivalent. The States and Territories have agreed to vesting the AAT with this additional jurisdiction.

Mutual registration is an outstanding example of what can be achieved when all governments in Australia cooperate and work together in the national interest. The Opposition firmly believes that it is essential to the efficient functioning of the national economy and of the Federal system that governments at all levels in Australia continue to foster and promote important developments such as mutual recognition. An important feature of this scheme is that it highlights the constructive use which can be made of section 51, placitum (xxxvii) of the Commonwealth Constitution. That provision allows the States to refer to the Commonwealth power to legislate in respect of matters normally outside its control.

The provision could be put to great use in many other areas. It may, for example, be possible for a cooperative federalism to extend the reach of the Trade Practices Act, something that I have always been very interested in. The Trade Practices Act at the moment regulates competition in respect of corporations. State government business enterprises fall outside its ordinary scope. There is no reason why they should. If a business is conducted through a partnership, it can fall outside the scope. If it is conducted by an individual or sole trader, it can fall outside the scope. I believe that the rules on competition should apply uniformly as far as possible and, with cooperation from the States, it would be a major advance if that could be done across the national economy—just as the competition rules of the Trade Practices Act ought to apply, and apply even-handedly, to trade unions.

I am sure that State governments are becoming increasingly conscious of how interdependent they are and of how much the national economy demands the ability to have mutual recognition in respect of standards. I am sure that this will be a great step forward and something to be commended. I hope that it continues in other areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise to speak in this debate because I believe that the Mutual Recognition Bill is a very important Bill and is yet another example of a growing healthy cooperation between the States, Territories and the Commonwealth, which demonstrates a maturity of government that bodes well for the future of Australia. We do not talk about depression on this side of the House; we talk about growth. The only depression we are aware of is that which emanates from beneath the closed doors of those opposite as they lie on couches late at night trying to figure out what strange quirk of fate has led them to yet again snatch defeat from the jaws of victory.

PARA.TAB: The object of this Bill is to enable the enactment of legislation applying uniformly throughout Australia for the mutual recognition by the States and Territories of each other's differing regulatory standards regarding goods and occupations. Until recently, we had the ridiculous situation where throughout Australia we had three different definitions of bread. We had one instance in Western Australia where margarine had to be sold in cube tubs so as to force manufacturers to provide a special run of tubs for that State alone.

In occupations, State registration requirements prevent professionals, even those graduating from Australian universities, and skilled tradesmen with extensive on-the-job experience, practising their skills in another State. These are situations that have to be remedied, but care also has to be taken that mutual recognition does not lead to a lowering of standards. This was referred to by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) in his contribution.

There is no doubt that the different, often contradictory, regulatory systems of the different governments of Australia cause major inefficiencies and restrictions on interstate trade, restrictions on the mobility of labour and restrictions on Australia's ability to compete internationally. In October 1990, heads of government agreed in principle to work towards implementing a scheme of mutual recognition, and further agreement was reached on 30 July 1991. Following a period of public consultation, Premiers and Chief Ministers at their meeting in Adelaide in November 1991 agreed on draft legislation to implement this scheme and at their meeting on 11 May 1992, heads of government signed a final agreement. It was agreed that the legislation would be enacted in each State and Territory by 31 October 1992 and by the Commonwealth by 1 January 1993, with the proclamation of the Commonwealth Act by no later than 1 March 1993.

Mutual recognition is a pragmatic but workable response to the difficulties inherent in forging an agreement between all States and Territories. While mutual recognition ensures that goods legally produced for sale in one State of Australia can be sold in all States, temporary restrictions can be imposed for health and safety reasons or to preserve the environment. There will be two classes of permanent exemptions under mutual recognition relating to inherently dangerous and offensive goods and to certain laws protecting public health, the environment and laws on pornography.

Mutual recognition also ensures that persons who are registered to practise their occupation in one State of Australia can, on notification of that registration, practise immediately in all other States. A local registration body will be set up which has one month to confirm or refuse registration. The refusal to register invokes a right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which, depending on the number of appeals, may have to be further resourced.

This Bill obviously has my full support, but I do have one concern. I know that the Government is aware that several professional groups have expressed concerns about mutual recognition. They argue that if the purpose of the legislation is to provide long term benefits to the public, then care must be taken to ensure that these benefits are not lost in the implementation process in so much as overall standards may be reduced to those of the State with the existing lowest standards.

In my own area of expertise—namely, the law—I am aware that the Queensland and New South Wales law societies, which pride themselves on high standards of practical training, are forever concerned that the standards are still not high enough. If the floodgates are opened, there is a genuine fear in Queensland and New South Wales that the level of service provided to the client might be lowered via the influx of lawyers from other States and Territories who have been subjected to less rigorous training.

There is an enormous oversupply of lawyers in Australia. We currently have some 25,000 solicitors and somewhere between 19,000 and 27,000 students who are studying law. We now have some 23 law schools—too many in my view—some of which promise jobs to potential students which they know full well are not there. I know the Government is aware of this concern, but I urge the ministerial councils that will be involved in this process to monitor the operation carefully.

Only this morning in the Brisbane Courier-Mail the President of the Law Society, Mr George Fox, came out with a press statement in which he talked about this oversupply of lawyers in Queensland. As you would appreciate, Mr Deputy Speaker, Queensland is the go-ahead State. It is the State with the lowest unemployment and the State to which everybody wants to move. That being the case, every sort of profession wants to come there. What concerns us a little in Queensland is that if some of the other States do not have the same standards as ours, we might get them all there. This morning's Courier-Mail said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland Law Society yesterday criticised universities for being part of a "huge con job" on the State's law students.

PARA.TAB: The society president, Mr George Fox, said the rush by universities to all have their own law school had created a huge glut of graduates, many of whom had little hope of finding a job.

SPEECH.PARA: The article then goes on to say:
He said there were as many law students in Queensland (about 3500) as there were practising lawyers.
The article continues:

PARA.TAB: He said many law students had complained to the law society.
"They are saying `I was told I'd get a job, I got a good pass, I can't get articles, I think I have been conned—who is responsible?'

SPEECH.PARA: For that reason we need to be careful that we do not lower standards to the point where we have too many of one profession perhaps in one State. The Law Society in New South Wales, for example, has made it plain that it is concerned that aspects of this Bill will prevent the Law Society imposing any of its current post-admission requirements on any interstate applicant who holds an unregistered practising certificate in his or her first State of registration. These issues will have to be, and I am sure will be, resolved. There will obviously be hiccups in the bedding down of this legislation; even the best of marriages have rocky periods of adjustment. But there is no doubt that the legislation overall is a very good and long overdue idea.

PARA.TAB: Under part IV of the agreement on mutual recognition there are provisions for national uniform standards, including national competency standards, to be determined by the appropriate ministerial council. This process will be vitally important. Upon the making of a determination the ministerial council, or ministerial councils jointly, as the case may be, will recommend to the heads of government of the participating parties that the standard or standards as determined shall be adopted. Unless this recommendation is disapproved by one-third or more of the heads of government or the participating parties within three months of its submission to those heads of government, the participating parties will take action, as soon as practicable, to implement the recommendation.

Even though there are concerns from some quarters in regard to standards, mechanisms have been set in place for these concerns to be aired. I hope that these mechanisms are sufficient. I will be watching their progress with a great deal of interest. Importantly, the method of achieving mutual recognition has been achieved through a reference of power by the States to the Commonwealth. This has the advantage of demonstrating the commitment of all parties to the establishment of a national market. As the honourable member for Higgins said, the fact is that we are all Australians. It is pretty ridiculous to think that one needs to be registered. For instance, as a solicitor one has to be registered in a State to practise in it. I know that there are solicitors in Tweed Heads who can handle Queensland matters only if they are admitted in both States. It is just a way of getting a bit of extra dough for some of the State governments.

This is yet another example of the way that this Government is bringing Australia together, as distinct from the divisiveness practised by those opposite—something which is best illustrated by what is currently happening in Victoria. We want to talk the economy up; they want to talk it down. We want to support those people without jobs; they want to turf them onto the scrap heap after nine months. This is just another thing that we are doing in this Government to see whether we can get things organised to help the situation.

During the consultation process of the mutual recognition agreement there was a significant number of submissions which did not support mutual recognition but which considered that the objective should be national uniformity. Time does not permit me to continue my remarks much longer. Suffice to say that there is broad agreement by the Federal Government and the State governments on this Bill. Possibly, it is something which should have been done a long time ago. I am glad it is happening. As I said previously, I am a little concerned, as are the legal bodies in New South Wales and Queensland, that it could lead to a lowering of standards. I hope it will not. I am sure that the ministerial council will be watching that with great interest. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the couple of minutes before we run out of time on the Mutual Recognition Bill 1992, I would like to make a couple of comments. I thank the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) and the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) for their contributions. The honourable member for Higgins suggested that this principle could be extended beyond the goods and occupations covered in the Bill to other matters. Obviously, these are matters for consideration by future Premiers Conferences. They may well decide, in light of their experience of mutual recognition in this Bill, to proceed. But, given the difficulties that the States have in agreeing on common public holidays or daylight saving, for example, I am not terribly hopeful.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Higgins suggested that the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is not committed to cooperative federalism. This is one of a couple of regrettable furphies that crept into his speech. This is, of course, the Prime Minister's Bill. The final agreement was negotiated largely during his period in office. It was signed on 11 May this year.

The discussion on X-rated videos was also a nonsense. X-rated material is excluded under the terms of the Bill. It is therefore properly the subject of another argument and one in which the coalition speaker should recall the behaviour of this industry in the ACT under a Liberal government and in the Northern Territory under a Country-Liberal Party government.

I understand that some concern has been expressed by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills that a proclamation date has not been included in the explanatory memorandum. I will ensure that the Committee is written to. In fact, the date is in the explanatory memorandum; perhaps not in the place it was looking. It is in paragraph 6 on page 2.

Finally, I report that New South Wales has already passed this legislation referring power to the Commonwealth. I am informed that it has been introduced into the legislatures of Victoria and the two Territories and it was due to be introduced into the Queensland Parliament tonight. It should be introduced shortly in the other States. The aim is to have all legislation in place by 1 January next year, with the proclamation of this Act by 1 March. The mutual recognition scheme will then apply to all jurisdictions that had the necessary legislation in place at that time or enact the legislation at a later time.
