DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (FOREIGN INVESTMENT) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr Baldwin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Foreign Investment) Bill 1992 is the last Bill under guillotine this week. I think it is about the seventieth Bill which has been dealt with by this House this week. It implements the Government's 1991-92 Budget announcement to complete the third element of its tax reform agenda to develop a comprehensive system for taxing foreign source income.

PARA.TAB: The first element of this agenda was the foreign tax credit system which, from the 1987-88 income year, replaced the general exemption in Australia of income earned offshore and subjected to foreign tax. The second element was the introduction of the foreign source income measures which took effect from the 1990-91 income year. The foreign source income measures apply where Australian residents have substantial interests in controlled foreign companies or had transferred property to certain foreign trusts for less than full value. They address the tax referral problem where these entities are used to shelter income from Australian tax by accumulating it in low tax or tax free jurisdictions. Such income is now taxed as it accrues.

The foreign investment fund measures will apply to income and gains accumulating in foreign countries that are not Australian controlled or foreign trusts that fall outside the scope of the FSI measures. The measures will also apply to certain foreign life assurance policies that have an investment component such as life bonds. In addition, the Bill will amend the existing trust provisions in divisions 6 and 6AAA of the principal Act in their application to non-resident trust income. The principal change is to the way in which a person's share of the net income from such non-resident trusts is ascertained. This will be aligned in a way in which a person's share of foreign investment fund income is determined under the foreign investment fund measures.

The Bill, therefore, is the Government's third major piece of legislation in its program to reform the taxation of foreign source income. This revised Bill contains the necessary new provisions for inclusion in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to give effect to the Government's approach in relation to the taxation of foreign investment funds. The foreign investment fund measures contained in this Bill will take effect on and from 1 January 1993.

By way of background, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Baldwin) said in his second reading speech that the need for these measures, as well as the foreign tax credit system introduced in 1987 and the foreign source income measures introduced in 1991, arose from a tax system that was heavily biased in favour of investments in low tax countries. The system also encouraged Australians to source artificially profits in offshore tax havens and, in cases where Australians could control the distribution policy of a foreign entity, to defer remittance of profits.

The foreign tax credit system which has operated since the 1987-88 income year replaced the system that gave a general exemption from Australian tax to income that was earned offshore that had been subject to foreign tax, regardless of the amount of tax paid. The foreign tax credit system provides generally for foreign income to be subject to Australian tax, with a credit being allowed for any foreign tax paid. The foreign source income measures which took effect in the 1990-91 income year introduced an accruals system of taxing foreign source income. The accruals taxation element of this legislation is directed at passive income and other forms of tainted income that is derived in low tax countries by Australian controlled foreign companies and accumulated offshore, avoiding Australian tax. It also applies to certain non-resident trusts to which Australians have transferred property or services for less than full value.

The Bill therefore introduces legislation which seeks to counter avoidance opportunities remaining after the introduction of the foreign source income measures. These are the cases where a foreign company or trust, although not generally controlled by Australians, is nevertheless an attractive investment vehicle because it allows for the accumulation of income offshore, especially in low-taxed countries, allowing the investor to minimise and defer Australian tax.

This Bill in its first form was introduced earlier this year and, following general concerns that were raised by the industry, it was then referred off for a matter of consultancy to a Professor Brian Arnold of the University of Western Ontario in Canada. Professor Arnold is a well-known and respected expert in the field of international tax law. Subsequent to that referral, a series of recommendations and submissions were made to Professor Arnold's review by various interests and various persons interested in the subject of this particular legislation. Following Professor Arnold's review, the Bill was reintroduced by the Government on 3 November this year as an amended version of a Bill of the same name that was introduced on 25 June of this year. The passage of the 25 June Bill was delayed to provide interested parties with the opportunity to examine the proposed legislation and for further consultation.

Subsequent to the review conducted by Professor Arnold, the Government, by adopting 37 of the 52 recommendations made by Professor Arnold, feels that it has solved the majority of the problems that were raised by the industry and by those with a concern about this legislation. However, there are still several problems associated with this legislation, some of which were the subject of recommendations by Professor Arnold in his review and not adopted by the Government, and some others which were beyond the purview of the recommendations and the review conducted by Professor Arnold.

It should be noted, though, that Professor Arnold's report dealt only with the technical and practical aspects of the implementation of foreign investment funds legislation and not with the policy basis of the FIF legislation. For example, a number of those concerned about this legislation note that some of the major problems have been alleviated by this amended Bill, but generally these problems are of the Government's own making. The new Bill does not examine the fundamental concerns. The Taxation Institute of Australia, for example, has expressed the view that the proposed legislation has been introduced on the basis of an anti-avoidance and anti-tax deferral measure, but notes that the proposed legislation sets out an entire new regime for taxing investments in foreign entities generally and the anti-avoidance objective does not seem to justify the scope of these provisions. This is evident from the fact that the major burden of the proposed legislation will fall on Australian taxpayers with bona fide investments in offshore entities.

The present Bill has made concessions in this area, though not far enough. The Taxation Institute, for example, notes that the proposed changes to the foreign life policies is only an alternative method of valuing income by referring to the sum value of the policy. All this alternative does is effectively tax the contribution at the top marginal rate.

Many of the original concerns which have been expressed about this Bill have been addressed by the redrafted version. Importantly, the schedule 4 so-called `white list' has been replaced by a new `black list'. Conceptually, this is far easier since it now means that a taxpayer merely has to establish that a foreign investment fund is not principally engaged in the activities listed therein. This is a far simpler exercise than having to establish, as was required under the previous version of this Bill, that the FIF has principally engaged in listed acceptable activities.

The exemption for an interest held in a foreign bank has been amended so that the test is now more practically feasible. Now, instead of the taxpayer having to establish the existence of a fixed number of non-associated shareholders, the interest will be exempt so long as the shares in the foreign bank are widely held and actively traded. The treatment of foreign investment fund losses has also been addressed—and this is welcomed by those who are involved in this particular area of activity—as recommended by Professor Arnold, to allow the foreign investment fund losses to be offset against a taxpayer's assessable income generally. However, there still remain serious concerns regarding the rationale behind the proposed legislation. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer, when dealing with the purpose of the Bill in his second reading speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . tackle the hard issue of tax minimisation and deferral opportunities available to Australians through some types of offshore investment, while recognising some taxpayers' legitimate need to invest offshore to achieve portfolio diversification.

With the large number of exemptions now contained within this new Bill, its purpose is even more obviously aimed at avoidance and deferral of taxation. It is submitted that this stated objective could well have been achieved by a greater reliance on the present general anti-avoidance provision contained in part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act of 1936. The need to enact 113 pages of legislation in an attempt to bring into the tax net a very small proportion of the tax paying community already covered would appear to be legislative overkill at its very worst. The enactment of such a complex piece of legislation which taxpayers will theoretically have to acquaint themselves with simply to determine whether their investments are excluded from the operation of the foreign investment funds measures does not sit comfortably with the concept of simplification of the tax law.

PARA.TAB: One of the principal objectives of taxation laws should be that they are certain in the first place and that they are easily ascertainable by ordinary taxpayers in Australia. If honourable members believe that this measure, these 113 pages are easily ascertainable by ordinary taxpayers in Australia, let me quote from just one clause of this Bill which is before the house tonight. Clause 15, which I will quote from—and there are other clauses which I could have easily quoted from—deals with proposed new section 160AFCF.(2)—not 160A, nor 160AF, not even 160AFC, but 160AFCF.(2). I will read this subsection and if anybody listening tonight can understand this and they do not have a PhD in income tax assessment legislation in Australia well, then, their intelligence level is probably much higher than yours and mine, Mr Deputy Speaker and, I suspect, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin) opposite. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) an amount is included in the notional income of the first tier foreign company of the relevant period under section 576; and
(b) an amount ('the section 529 amount') is included in the assessable income of the taxpayer of a year of income under section 529;

(c) the section 529 amount was determined by the application of the calculation method set out in Subdivision D of Division 18 of Part XI in respect of the notional accounting period of the first tier foreign company; and
(d) at the end of the notional accounting period of the second tier foreign company, the first tier foreign company and the second tier foreign company were related to the taxpayer; and

(e) the amount ('the gross deductible amount)' is a notional deduction under that Subdivision from the second tier foreign company's notional income of that notional accounting period because the second tier foreign company paid an amount in respect of foreign tax;
subsection (3) has effect.

I will not go to the trouble of reading subsection (3). I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, were well on top of what was contained in subsection (2) of section 160AFCF, but I wonder how many other ordinary Australians, even Australians who might have some small investment overseas, had any understanding of what that provision of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Foreign Investment) Bill will means if it becomes law and forms part of the Income Tax Assessment Act of 1936.

PARA.TAB: We wonder why ordinary Australians complain about the complexity of taxation law in Australia. If those who are listening to this debate tonight actually follow what I am speaking about, what the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade will speak about, and what any other honourable member has been speaking about tonight, then they deserve a PhD straight off for simply understanding the provisions in the Income Tax Assessment Act. Yet this is the complexity of the legislation with which we are dealing in such an important area. Ordinary Australians who want to invest and ordinary Australian business people have to try to understand it.

It may be great legislation for accountants and lawyers. As a lawyer in the past, I can attribute to having earned some income from giving advice about this sort of legislation. Surely we ought to have a system of taxation legislation in Australia that most ordinary people can understand the provisions of. This legislation tonight does absolutely nothing to add to the simplification of Australian income tax.

I now turn to some of the intricacies of this legislation which demand some dealing with tonight. The Government has not supported Professor Arnold's recommendations with regard to foreign life assurance policies. It has been submitted by a number of people to Professor Arnold, and to the Treasury, that the legislation will have a devastating consequence for longstanding retirement plans of migrants to Australia and expatriates returning to this country. The Bill has not adopted Professor Arnold's recommendations to transfer offshore policies onshore. Industry suggested that, when foreign life policies are transferred onshore, they should not need to restart a 10-year period for the purposes of section 26A(H) of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

The foreign investment funds regime does not apply to non-residents. But when immigrants and returning Australian expatriates become residents of Australia, their foreign life assurance policies become foreign investment funds, taxed annually in cash on unrealised gains. In comparison with Australian offshore arrangements, the most that the Commissioner of Taxation is entitled to receive is tax on the internal growth of the foreign life policy after the non-resident becomes a resident.

As the legislation stands, residents with foreign life policies will be liable for foreign investment funds tax, in cash, on growth that has not yet been realised. Inevitably, the consequence of this legislation will be to drive foreign life policies underground. I have already heard of stories in places such as Hong Kong where expatriates are being advised that there are ways to avoid this legislation. If we have a situation where legislation is about to be introduced into the Australian Parliament and is about to become part of the law of taxation in this country, yet overseas Australian expatriates and people who are likely to migrate to this country are already being advised, and we are being told that they are being advised, that there are ways of avoiding this legislation by driving these schemes underground, then the whole purpose of the legislation is being avoided and this measure is of very little consequence.

TALK.START.PARA: —No commonsense.

—There is no commonsense in it, as my learned friend says. The foreign investment fund measures will yield 48.4c on any resident's foreign life policies that the Australian Taxation Office can locate, anywhere in the world. The alternative is to allow these policies to be transferred onshore. From the time the policyholder becomes resident, the transferred policy will no longer be a foreign investment fund and the resident policyholder will not be liable to FIF tax. Instead, 39c will be paid at source on the growth of the underlying investment.

PARA.TAB: There are three reasons why transfers onshore ought to be permitted: first, it is a sensible solution which gives taxpayers the space in which to comply with the tax laws of this country; secondly, there is equity with resident Australian policyholders, whose growth is taxed at 39c at source; and, thirdly, the proposal will yield more revenue than the existing FIF measures. Tax at 39c at source in Australia is worth more than tax at 48.4c wherever in the world the Australian Taxation Office can locate the policies of residents. Of course, to provide the incentive for transfer onshore, the 10-year clock needs to run from the commencement date of the original foreign life policy. Of course, Professor Arnold's recommendation is not provided for in this policy.

There are a series of problems in the legislation which I should flag in the debate tonight. With the matter under the guillotine all I can do is to flag a series of major concerns that have been raised in relation to this particular policy. I believe that some of these matters will be addressed in the other place.

The first is that the implementation date of this Bill should be delayed, we believe, until 1 July 1993. This would allow sufficient time to design and implement detailed systems to capture and record the information necessary to comply with the foreign investment fund legislation, which requires many months to implement. The delay in the introduction of the Bill will also assist taxpayers who have substituted accounting periods in lieu of the succeeding 30 June. Furthermore, it is significantly cheaper to implement a computer system change at the beginning of a financial year rather than halfway through the financial year. In relation to the implementation date of this legislation, I foreshadow that the coalition in the other place proposes that the commencement date be delayed from 1 January 1993 to 1 July 1993.

Secondly, the double taxation of income from interest in non-resident trust estates still exists where the foreign investment fund is sold during the year of income. This remains a problem in the legislation even with the changes that have been recommended by Professor Arnold and accepted by the Government.

Thirdly, there is a fundamental problem with the treatment of financial services. A series of companies—for example, American Express, Merrill Lynch and Salomon Inc.—are included in the Morgan Stanley capital index in the financial services category. There is no exemption in the Bill for legitimate investments in such companies, which is of concern since these investments often constitute 20 per cent of a foreign investment portfolio. Therefore, we believe that financial services should be exempt where the shares are listed on the approved exchange widely held and actively traded.

Fourthly, the balance sheet method is an impractical method to apply and assume that the taxpayer has access to detailed information. The annual set of accounts do not always provide sufficient information on the percentage of assets used relating to ineligible activities. Proposed section 500 provides that, under the balance sheet method, only 50 per cent or more owned subsidiaries of a holding company will be taken into account when applying the designated activities exemption. It is arguable that the consolidated balance sheet method of determining whether the active business exemption applies should include subsidiaries where there is a less than 50 per cent ownership, but where the holding company is actively involved in the management of the subsidiary, particularly in respect of joint venture companies. This may be limited to cases where the accounts clearly show that the holding company treats the investment in the less than 50 per cent subsidiary as an associated company or joint venture interest.

The exclusion in proposed section 500(3)(b) of the `gross value of the shares in the subsidiary company owned by the holding company' from the calculations involved in applying the balance sheet method, appears to only effectively operate to exclude the effect of the shares held by the holding company in a first tier subsidiary. It should be noted in this regard that the gross value of subsidiary assets to be applied in the formula is defined as `the gross value at the test time of all the subsidiary company's assets' which would thus include the shares in a second tier subsidiary held by a first tier subsidiary. To be consistent, that definition should exclude the value of any shares which such subsidiary holds in any other company which is also a subsidiary of the holding company.

In addition to that, proposed subsection 500(6) and proposed section 501 provide the mechanism for: firstly, determining whether a company is a subsidiary of a holding company; and, secondly, calculating what proportion of a subsidiary's assets should be taken into account in applying the balance sheet formula. It is arguable that while the mechanism is appropriate in determining the answer to the second point, it is not appropriate for determining whether a company is a subsidiary of the holding company for the purposes of applying the balance sheet method of active business exemption.

I refer to paragraph 5.4.4 of the press release put out by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) entitled Foreign investment fund (FIF) legislation: Government response to consultant's report, where it is stated that the basis for determining whether a company is a subsidiary of a holding company is to be determined solely upon the criterion of control. It would seem appropriate that a separate test be inserted for determining whether a company is a subsidiary of a holding company, using similar rules to those used in part X of the Assessment Act to determine whether a company is a controlled foreign company.

It would follow that, where a holding company owns more than 50 per cent of the issued share capital of a subsidiary—that is, the first subsidiary—in determining the holding company's interest in a company which is in turn a subsidiary—that is, the second subsidiary—of the first subsidiary, the whole amount of the first subsidiary's interest in the second subsidiary should be attributed to the parent company. Where less than 50 per cent interest was held by the holding company in the first subsidiary, the holding company's interest in the second subsidiary would be calculated as in proposed section 501, by multiplying the holding company's percentage interest in the first subsidiary by the first subsidiary's percentage interest in the second subsidiary. If anybody listening to this debate who does not have a degree in taxation law can understand what I am talking about, I suspect he or she is in the top 0.001 per cent of the Australian population.

A clear example of the inadequacy of the proposed test can be illustrated where a holding company owns, for example, 70 per cent of the paid-up share capital of the first subsidiary, which in turns owns 70 per cent of the paid-up share capital of the second subsidiary. Under any accepted accounting standard, and any other control test in the Assessment Act, the holding company would be taken to control the second subsidiary; but, applying the tests set out in proposed section 501, the holding company will be taken to have a 49 per cent interest in the second subsidiary, and the assets of the second subsidiary will thus not be taken into account in applying the active business exemption. However, the shares held by the first subsidiary in the second subsidiary and any advances by the holding company to the second subsidiary will probably be included as assets, not for use in designated activities in applying the balance sheet test to holding companies.

I could probably continue with problems associated with the balance sheet test in this proposed legislation for the next hour, but it seems to me that what I have been saying illustrates clearly not only the complexities of this legislation but also the real problems that have been isolated and identified by those who will be subject to the legislation. The fifth problem is that the life insurance exemption can be satisfied only by using the balance sheet method. Sixthly, the Morgan Stanley Capital Index does not differentiate between companies carrying on life insurance and those with general insurance businesses. Rather, there is only one classification of insurance. Hence, a taxpayer would have to use the balance sheet method to determine whether the foreign investment fund was exempt.

Seventhly, the trading stock exemption in proposed section 520 implies that all foreign investment funds have to be valued at market value under proposed section 31(5) for the foreign investment funds to be exempt. The exemption should be amended so that a taxpayer can elect to use the market value method under proposed section 31(5) in respect of a particular foreign investment fund to ensure that the foreign investment fund provisions do not apply. Eighthly, there is an argument for the introduction of a deemed disposal election similar to the amendments made to trading stock provisions for foreign investment funds held on capital and revenue account. This would significantly reduce compliance costs and would be used only where the 5 per cent exemption is not satisfied.

Ninthly, the exemption for multi-industries and conglomerates assumes that the taxpayer has sufficient information to satisfy the conditions in proposed section 523. This can be done only through the balance sheet method, because, for example, the Morgan Stanley Capital Index classifies these entities under `multi-industry'. Tenthly, the 5 per cent exemption should be amended to reflect 5 per cent of a total portfolio of assets held. The eleventh problem is that the adoption of a black-listed approach does not reduce the level of compliance and administrative work, since attribution accounts will still have to be maintained. In this regard, the compliance costs will not differ significantly because detailed systems will have to be designed and implemented to comply with the legislation for many clients.

Twelfthly, the use of an index to determine the international sectoral classification requires further consideration. The thirteenth problem is that the Bill does not address the problems associated with the distributions from resident public unit trusts where these trusts are subject to foreign investment fund attributions. Finally, the compliance issues identified by Professor Arnold have not been resolved. Costly systems have to be maintained to produce multiple sets of accounts for a particular foreign investment fund to enable unit holders to be provided with the correct tax information.

The amendments made to the original Bill are certainly an improvement on the legislation that was introduced into this House. However, as I have sought to illustrate in the last 25 minutes, there are still considerable problems with this legislation, particularly in relation to the administration of it. There are considerable problems in relation to the whole concept and in achieving the objectives that have been sought by the Government. As I have foreshadowed, it is the intention of the coalition to determine these matters in another place. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like briefly to address one or two issues raised by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) in respect of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Foreign Investment) Bill. I think it is important to point out to the honourable gentleman, as he rightly did chronicle, that there were considerable consultations undertaken by the Government in respect of this present legislation and other legislation which was the forerunner to it.

PARA.TAB: After the measures were first foreshadowed in April 1989, there was also a Budget announcement in August 1991 and further consultation after the release of a detailed information paper in April 1992. As the honourable member spent some considerable time indicating, there was further consultation in the form of an independent international expert, Professor Arnold, who brought down a report for the Government and, after the Bill was originally introduced in June 1992, made some recommendations to it. As has been pointed out, a number of those recommendations were acted upon.

The honourable member for Menzies has pointed out where he believes there are some shortcomings. One point that he made which I think is worthy of clarification is that Professor Arnold said that there was no need to provide for the transfer of foreign life policies onshore if a market value method of taxation was provided. The Government adopted that recommendation to provide a market value method of taxation, so one of the issues which he pointed to has been addressed.

The other issue of significance which the honourable member went to was the complexity of the legislation and its sheer bulk. He asked, `Why is this Bill necessary? Why is it so complex?'. I guess the answer to that comes from the fact that had he been here in the mid-1980s to see what the spivs and the failed entrepreneurs of the 1980s were doing in terms of the taxation system of this country, and to see the way in which tax havens in places such as the Cook Islands and other islands in the Caribbean were being used to get around the tax system of this country, he might understand why legislation of this nature has of necessity to be as complex as it is.

I do not really think one needs a PhD to understand that PAYE taxpayers in Australia were for a long time bearing an unfair burden of responsibility in terms of the amounts which they contributed through the tax system to provide for the services which by necessity government must provide. By employing the smart lawyers and the smart accountants, people were able to devise methods whereby, by setting up a shingle outside a hut in some of these faraway places with exotic names, they were able to route through the paperchase many millions of dollars and have it rerouted back into Australia through a variety of complex devices, and no tax was paid.

I might say to the honourable gentleman that this particular issue was the subject of two parliamentary inquiries in this Parliament. It led in part to the Government crackdown and the introduction of the legislation, this being the third part of that major legislation dealing with these issues. Some of the major corporations in the 1980s were singled out as being tremendous for Australia and doing the right thing, such as the Bond Corporation. But when we went to their annual report to see where most of their subsidies were incorporated, we found it was the Cook Islands or the Netherlands Antilles, and all those sorts of places. We had to scratch our heads and say, `What is it about these particular locations that make it attractive for multimillion dollars to be routed through them?'. The answer was, of course, that they had negligible tax; in fact, most of them had none. They had secrecy provisions so that the Australian Taxation Office could not get information on those companies. It simply came down to the fact that there were no tax treaties between the countries concerned and Australia, so it was impossible to trace the paper and money trails.

Other countries around the world have legislation of the sort that we are introducing tonight. I think it is fair that avoidance of fair and reasonable contributions by all taxpayers in this country should be eliminated. I think it is not fair simply to complain about the complexity of the legislation on one hand, and then to say that there were also some complaints about rorts that were invented offshore to get around the provisions which people were talking about. One of the unfortunate facts facing the Australian Taxation Office is that, as legislation is drafted to meet the needs of present circumstances, is debated in parliament and subsequently becomes law, there is always some smart spiv lawyer or accountant trying to be one step ahead of it and trying to work out ways in which it can be rorted.

I well remember in the course of those inquiries on tax havens, as it came before the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which I formally chaired, that we were taken aback. One day we were actually getting a briefing from some people from the Australian Taxation Office who were drafting the legislation to meet its needs and the next week we found out that he had been snaffled by Bond Corporation to work with it and to give it advice on how to do it. It is a bit difficult, then, to say that on one hand it has to be complex and on the other hand say there are people who are trying to rort the system to get around it.

The legislation is timely. It has come through extensive consultation with the industry and with other people. The various recommendations, which were made by a noted international lawyer, were in the main picked up. But the Government always has the right to review its own legislation and to put in place what it believes is going to meet the needs of the day. This clearly does that, and I commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs, upon notice, on 15 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: Who allocates the 11 000 tonne cheese tariff quota and how is it allocated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Quota on cheese and curd was first allocated by the Australian Customs Service (ACS) in 1987 to persons importing these goods in the 1985-86 financial year. Allocation was based on importers' clearances for home consumption during the 1985-

ANSWER.PARA: 86 financial year. The total tonnage of cheese and curd resulting from the allocation was 11 500 tonnes.

PARA.TAB: Eligible quota holders were invited by Australian Customs Notice No. 87/90 to apply for their quota entitlements.
Since 1987, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has requested that the ACS make annual allocations of the 11 500 tonne cheese and curd quota.
Accordingly, quota allocations have been made to the same recipients for the same quantities each year the cheese and curd quota scheme has operated.
